metadata.title: Markets Policy COP30 Leaders Summit Puts Sustainable Fuels And Carbon Markets In Focus
metadata.indicator: At the COP30 Leaders Summit in Belém, Brazil, 19 countries including India and Japan pledged to quadruple sustainable fuel use by 2035 through the Belém 4X Pledge, targeting biofuels, biogas, hydrogen, and e-fuels across transport and industry. A new Open Coalition on Compliance Carbon Markets was launched by the EU, UK, China, Canada, and Brazil to harmonize carbon market rules, align reporting standards, and explore border carbon adjustments. Additionally, a $5.5 billion Tropical Forests Forever Facility was established to incentivize tropical forest conservation through annual payments of at least $4 per hectare, with private sector involvement and bond-style funding mechanisms.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Sustainable Fuels, Carbon Markets, Forest Protection

metadata.title: Capture Pennsylvania’s Path To Industrial Decarbonization: A Focus On Steel With Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: Pennsylvania is advancing a strategic industrial decarbonization plan centered on the steel sector, leveraging carbon capture and storage (CCS) as an interim solution to reduce emissions from legacy facilities like US Steel’s Edgar Thomson plant and Cleveland-Cliffs’ furnace electrification pilot. The state is developing a tailored "CCS ladder" framework, capitalizing on the geographic proximity of steel, glass, and cement facilities to potential storage sites under the CarbonSAFE program, particularly in the Pittsburgh region. This approach enables the creation of carbon hubs that integrate CO2 transport, storage, and complementary infrastructure such as hydrogen hubs and advanced recycling networks, while emphasizing environmental justice and equitable community engagement.
metadata.categories: Energy Policy, Industrial Decarbonization, Carbon Capture and Storage, Steel Industry, Environmental Justice

metadata.title: Biomass Farming Removal CapChar Proposes New UK-Oriented Biochar Carbon Code
metadata.indicator: CapChar, a UK-based biochar technology company, has launched a new Biochar Carbon Code now in public consultation, designed as a tailored, end-to-end solution for UK-based biochar producers and farmers. The code integrates with CapChar’s pyrolysis technology and digital monitoring, reporting, and verification (dMRV) platform, offering streamlined carbon tracking and compliance through monthly elemental analysis and peer-reviewed scientific methodologies. It emphasizes local production, soil health improvement, and carbon removal, with specific applicability to diverse agricultural feedstocks and farm-scale implementation.
metadata.categories: Biotechnology, Environmental Policy, Carbon Capture, UK Agriculture

metadata.indicator: The remove India Accelerator Program is now accepting applications for an eight-month cohort focused on carbon dioxide removal (CDR) startups, offering mentorship, access to international experts, and connections to investors and policymakers. Selected founders will receive €15,000 in non-dilutive funding without equity exchange, and alumni gain ongoing support through fundraising tools and peer networks. The program targets scalable, innovative CDR solutions to address India’s climate challenges and is part of remove’s broader effort to advance climate-tech entrepreneurship globally.
metadata.categories: Climate Tech, Carbon Removal, Startups, India

metadata.title: Article 6 Capture Compliance Markets Japan And India Forge Strong Ties On Multiple Carbon Fronts
metadata.indicator: Japan and India have launched a joint carbon credit mechanism (JCM) under Article 6.2 of the Paris Agreement, enabling bilateral carbon trading and investment in low-carbon technologies, with credits eligible for international markets. The agreement, signed by India’s Environment Ministry and Japan’s government, aims to support India’s nationally determined contributions while advancing climate finance and technology transfer, and includes plans for 100 million tons of JCM credits by 2030 and 200 million tons by 2040. The partnership also includes cross-border collaboration in carbon capture, green hydrogen, and ammonia, with a proposed cross-border supply chain supported by shared standards and verified low-carbon benchmarks, and a focus on strengthening resilience and energy security in the Indo-Pacific region.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, International Cooperation, Renewable Energy

metadata.title: Capture Storage India Partners with Norway On Carbon Capture for Deepwater Energy Push
metadata.indicator: India is forging a strategic partnership with Norway to develop carbon capture and storage (CCS) capabilities for deepwater oil and gas exploration, inspired by Norway’s successful Northern Lights CCS project, which stores up to 100 million tonnes of CO2 beneath the seabed. Petroleum Minister Hardeep Singh Puri highlighted India’s intent to replicate Norway’s flexible CCS infrastructure to support decarbonization, particularly in deepwater basins like Krishna-Godavari and Mahanadi, as part of India’s broader push for offshore energy development. This initiative aligns with India’s upcoming Open Acreage Licensing Policy (OALP) Round 10, covering over 250,000 sq km and targeting enhanced subsea operations and drilling technologies.
metadata.categories: Energy Innovation, Carbon Capture and Storage, Deepwater Exploration, Oil and Gas

metadata.title: Farming Removal Varaha Locks In A Five-Year CDR Deal With Louis Dreyfus Company
metadata.indicator: Carbon dioxide removal (CDR) company Varaha has secured a five-year deal with Louis Dreyfus Company (LDC) to deliver 6,000 tons of annual carbon removal credits through improved agricultural land management in Uttar Pradesh, India. The project involves 430 smallholder farms implementing regenerative practices such as crop rotation, straw return, and reduced soil disturbance to avoid biomass burning, thereby reducing emissions and enhancing soil carbon sequestration. Varaha uses third-party verification under Verra’s improved agricultural land management methodology (v2.1) and integrates monitoring, soil sampling, and traceability from farm to warehouse, with the credits being delivered via insetting to support LDC’s sustainable supply chain.
metadata.categories: Carbon Removal, Sustainable Agriculture, Climate Change, Agriculture

metadata.title: Markets Climate-Smart Rice Farming Gets Boost From Mitti Labs–TNC Partnership
metadata.indicator: Mitti Labs, a climate-tech startup founded in 2023, has partnered with The Nature Conservancy (TNC) to advance climate-smart rice farming in Punjab through its AI-driven "soil-to-sky" digital Measurement, Reporting, and Verification (dMRV) platform. By integrating satellite and field-level data, the platform enables precise tracking of sustainable practices like Alternate Wetting and Drying (AWD), Direct Seeded Rice (DSR), and no-burn residue management, helping farmers conserve water, improve soil health, and reduce methane emissions. The system supports emission validation and access to climate finance, while scaling across 10 million hectares of Indian rice fields—equivalent to one-quarter of the country’s rice-farming land—within a digital twin framework.
metadata.categories: Climate-Smart Agriculture, AI and Satellite Monitoring, Sustainable Farming, Climate Change

metadata.title: Biomass Removal Varaha Registers Second Puro.earth Biochar Facility In India
metadata.indicator: Varaha, India’s leading carbon removal company, has registered its second industrial biochar facility with Puro.earth, the world’s largest carbon removal standard and registry, expanding its footprint in Southern India where it produces biochar from corn shanks—agricultural waste heated to create carbon-rich material that sequesters CO₂ for centuries. This marks India’s second Puro.earth-verified biochar project, following the first in October 2024, and underscores Varaha’s commitment to high-integrity, transparent carbon removal through a digital measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV) platform. The facility supports climate goals by preventing emissions from waste burning and fossil fuel use, while delivering co-benefits like improved soil fertility and biodiversity.
metadata.categories: Carbon Removal, Biochar, Climate Innovation, India

metadata.title: Forests Removal New Study Finds Protecting And Restoring EU Forests Is Key To Meeting CO2 Removal Goals
metadata.indicator: A new study by Wild Europe and the Climate Action Beacon at Griffith University reveals that protecting and restoring EU forests could remove over 300 million tonnes of CO2 annually, significantly contributing to the European Green Deal’s target of 310 million tonnes of net carbon removal by 2030. The research highlights that governments have underestimated carbon stocks in old-growth and primary forests, particularly due to their exclusion from current climate and forest management policies. By emphasizing the carbon storage capacity of diverse, biodiverse natural forests—including aboveground, belowground, and dead biomass—the study argues that intact forests are more effective and resilient carbon sinks than managed or monoculture systems.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Forests, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Policy Removal The EU Has Released Its Nearly $105B Clean Industrial Deal
metadata.indicator: The European Union has launched the EU Clean Industrial Deal, a $105 billion initiative to boost industrial competitiveness and decarbonization by investing in electrification, grid stability, and circular economy measures. The plan includes a voluntary carbon intensity labeling system for steel and cement, the creation of an EU Critical Raw Material Centre, and a 2030 target of 24% recycled material usage. However, critics argue the deal lacks a clear, urgent roadmap for scaling carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, missing key opportunities to establish European leadership in this emerging climate sector.
metadata.categories: Policy, Climate Change, Industrial Decarbonization, European Union

metadata.title: EU To Fund CDR Under The 2025 Edition Of Its LIFE Program
metadata.indicator: The European Union has launched a call for proposals under the 2025 edition of its LIFE Program for Climate Change Mitigation, allocating €28 million to fund carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, including biochar, enhanced rock weathering, ocean alkalinity enhancement, direct ocean capture, and small-scale bioCCS. The initiative aims to advance innovative, cost-effective CDR solutions and strengthen monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) capacities to support viable business models. This funding is part of a broader effort to reduce net greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% compared to 1990 levels by 2030, aligning with the European Green Deal’s goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.
metadata.categories: Climate Change Mitigation, Carbon Dioxide Removal, European Union, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Policy Removal New Report Provides Recommendations On Scaling CDR In The EU
metadata.indicator: The European Scientific Advisory Board on Climate Change has released a report recommending policy actions to accelerate carbon dioxide removal (CDR) deployment across the EU, including establishing separate legal targets for carbon emissions, temporary land-based removals, and permanent removals via innovative methods. The report calls for integrating permanent CDR into the EU Emissions Trading System to create high-integrity carbon credits and proposes an "extended emitter responsibility" requiring current emitters to fund future CO2 removals. It also advocates for increased funding, market incentives, and monitoring mechanisms, along with new pricing instruments to reward land managers for carbon sequestration.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Dioxide Removal (CDR), European Union

metadata.title: Policy Removal Updated Carbon Removal Policy Tracker By Carbon Gap Shows The EU Needs A Stronger Strategy
metadata.indicator: Carbon Gap has updated its Carbon Removal Policy Tracker to provide a comprehensive database of over 600 EU carbon dioxide removal (CDR) funding opportunities, highlighting that the EU is falling short of its climate neutrality goals due to insufficient and uneven national CDR policies and funding. While non-EU countries like the UK, Denmark, and Switzerland are leading in early-stage CDR research and development, the EU as a whole has only invested €950 million in CDR RD&I over decades, falling short of the required €2.6 billion over seven years. Denmark and Switzerland have established robust CDR strategies, whereas countries like Italy and France show minimal progress, indicating a significant imbalance in policy development across the EU.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Removal, European Union, Decarbonization

metadata.title: Markets EU Carbon Market Will Cause Diesel Prices To Soar
metadata.indicator: The European Union is implementing a new emissions trading system (ETS2) for transportation and housing sectors, starting in 2027, which mandates fuel providers to purchase carbon allowances to offset diesel emissions. Unlike the previous system, no free allowances will be distributed, leading to increased diesel costs—projected to rise from 14 cents per liter in 2027 to 54 cents per liter by 2031—potentially impacting consumer prices and fuel affordability. The policy includes funding for a "social climate fund" to support low-income households and small businesses with energy efficiency and insulation measures.
metadata.categories: Climate Regulations, European Union, Carbon Market, Fuel Prices

metadata.title: Biomass Direct Air Capture Farming Policy Removal EU To Provide $30M For Carbon Removal Projects
metadata.indicator: The European Commission has launched a €28.5 million (≈$30 million) funding call under the LIFE Programme to support carbon dioxide removal (CDR) projects across the EU, focusing on technologies such as biochar, bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS), and enhanced weathering (ERW). The funding aims to advance carbon farming by incentivizing projects along the entire value chain and encourages synergies with Horizon Europe and the "A Soil Deal for Europe" mission. Projects can receive up to 60% of their costs covered, with individual grants ranging from €1 to €5 million, and applications open until September 17, 2024, with funding expected to begin in mid-2025.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Carbon Removal, EU Funding, Climate Action

metadata.title: Policy Removal EU CBAM Portal For Third-Country Operators Goes Live
metadata.indicator: The European Commission has launched the CBAM Portal for Third-Country Operators (O3CI), enabling non-EU operators to register, submit installation and emissions data, and share carbon pricing information with EU authorities starting January 1, 2025. The portal facilitates secure data exchange between third-country operators and EU declarants, supporting compliance with the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) by addressing carbon leakage and promoting global decarbonization. Access is granted via the EU Login system and requires Commission approval, ensuring transparency and alignment with EU climate policy goals.
metadata.categories: Policy, Climate Change, EU Policies, Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism

metadata.title: Opinion: EU Should Use Carbon Credits As The Carrot To Counteract The Stick Of Carbon Border Tax
metadata.indicator: The EU should integrate high-quality carbon credits into its Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) as a complementary, market-based solution to counteract the regressive and economically uneven impacts of the CBAM’s carbon tax on importers. While the CBAM taxes imports based on carbon intensity, potentially undermining global economic equity and disadvantaging developing nations, carbon credits offer a more flexible and efficient alternative by allowing importers to offset liabilities through verified, independent climate projects—especially in sectors where decarbonization technology remains costly or nascent. Recent advancements in the voluntary carbon market, including independent carbon ratings, measurement tools, and carbon insurance, have significantly improved transparency and project integrity, creating a credible pathway for governments to trust and deploy carbon credits in compliance markets.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Market, EU Regulations, Sustainable Development

metadata.title: Markets India To Launch Carbon Market In 2026, Says Power Minister
metadata.indicator: India plans to launch a national carbon market by mid-2026, enabling industries to buy and sell carbon credits based on fossil fuel usage, with emission-intensive sectors like steel and cement expected to benefit from financial incentives to adopt cleaner energy sources. The market will support compliance with international regulations, including the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), and is built on the 2022 Energy Conservation (Amendment) Bill that established the legal framework for carbon trading.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Carbon Markets, India, Climate Change

metadata.title: Markets EU And India Join Forces On Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM)
metadata.indicator: The European Union and India are collaborating on the implementation of a Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) to ensure imported goods face equivalent carbon costs as domestic products, aiming to prevent carbon leakage and promote global decarbonization. The initiative focuses on creating a level playing field by applying carbon pricing to imports, with discussions emphasizing fair implementation, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in India. Both sides are also advancing cooperation in carbon trading, emissions pricing, clean technologies, and customs issues, including cross-border e-commerce and drug precursor controls, under the existing EU-India Customs Cooperation Agreement.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, International Cooperation, Climate Change, Trade and Customs

metadata.title: Capture Policy Removal U.S. Bill Proposes Carbon Fees On Imports, CO2 Capture And Removal Considered As Mitigators
metadata.indicator: A new U.S. legislative proposal, the Foreign Pollution Fee Act of 2025, introduces a tariff-based mechanism that imposes fees on imported goods based on their carbon intensity relative to U.S. manufacturing standards, targeting countries like China, Russia, Vietnam, and India for disproportionately high emissions. The bill allows companies to reduce these fees by investing in carbon capture and removal (CDR) technologies or purchasing certified, durable carbon removal credits—such as direct air capture or marine-based removal—while excluding temporary forest-based offsets and those linked to "foreign entities of concern." This approach mirrors the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) and could incentivize global investment in carbon mitigation, while also reshaping international trade dynamics and pressuring foreign nations to adopt stricter environmental standards.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Removal, International Trade, Environmental Regulation

metadata.title: Markets Vietnam To Run Carbon Market Pilot Program From 2025 To 2028
metadata.indicator: Vietnam will launch a domestic carbon credit market pilot program from 2025 to 2028, initially allocating emission quotas to around 200 facilities in the power, iron and steel, and cement sectors—representing about 45% of total emissions. The program, overseen by the government and discussed at a meeting led by Deputy Prime Minister Tran Hong Ha, will operate without allowing direct carbon trading with foreign entities, except under existing international agreements. The initiative aims to help Vietnamese industries comply with the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) and strengthen domestic climate governance under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, with plans to expand nationwide and explore future global market integration by 2029.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Carbon Market, Vietnam, Climate Change

metadata.title: Markets UK Government Confirms CBAM Rollout In 2027
metadata.indicator: The UK government has confirmed the rollout of a Cross-Border Carbon Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) starting in January 2027, targeting imported goods from industries such as aluminium, cement, fertilizers, iron, steel, and hydrogen, with exemptions for ceramics and glass due to ongoing assessment. The mechanism will levy carbon charges on scope 1 and 2 emissions, as well as select precursor emissions, and will link directly with the UK Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) to ensure alignment and free allocation coordination. Unlike the EU CBAM, which requires emission certificates, the UK will not mandate them, and the two mechanisms are expected to align in future, with both aiming to reduce carbon leakage by discouraging fossil-fuel-based production exports.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Adjustment Mechanisms, UK Government

metadata.title: Markets EU Set To Reduce Carbon Tax Weight On Industrial Exporters
metadata.indicator: The European Commission is proposing a temporary exemption from carbon tax for EU exporters in high-emissions sectors like steel, aluminum, and cement, aimed at preventing "carbon leakage" by deterring production relocation to countries with laxer climate regulations. This measure, part of a broader strategy to support industrial competitiveness, will be implemented alongside the rollout of the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) and tied to the 2026 ETS reform, with the exemption initially time-limited and subject to review. The plan seeks to balance climate goals with industrial stability by providing financial relief to exporters during the transition from the old carbon allowance system to a more stringent, market-based emissions trading regime.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, European Union, Carbon Tax, Emissions Trading System, Industrial Competitiveness

metadata.title: Carbon Accounting Markets Press Release New CBAM Software Offers Cost-Effective Carbon Reporting For SMEs And Enterprises
metadata.indicator: The Sustainability Cloud has launched EU CBAM Importer software, a cost-effective carbon accounting solution designed to help SMEs and enterprises meet EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) reporting requirements. The software addresses key challenges in data collection from global supply chains, carbon cost forecasting, and access to affordable technology by offering a free tier with plans starting at €0, enabling importers to automate reporting, reduce errors, and save time without disrupting operations. By facilitating seamless collaboration between importers and exporters, the platform bridges data gaps in supply chain emissions and supports compliance for businesses across the EU.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Accounting, Sustainability Software

metadata.indicator: Russia has filed a formal complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) challenging the European Union’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), arguing that it constitutes protectionism disguised as environmental policy and threatens global trade fairness. The complaint asserts that the EU is using green credentials to impose carbon tariffs on imports like steel, aluminum, cement, and fertilizers, effectively leveling the playing field for EU producers while disadvantaging foreign exporters. Russia seeks to establish clear boundaries under international trade law to prevent other nations from adopting similar measures, and has requested consultations with the EU; if unresolved within 60 days, it will escalate the dispute to a WTO panel.
metadata.categories: Markets Policy, WTO, Environmental Trade Measures

metadata.title: South Korea Launches Ambitious Plan To Boost CCU
metadata.indicator: South Korea’s Ministry of Science and ICT has launched a comprehensive Carbon Capture and Utilization (CCU) Initiative to accelerate the nation’s path to carbon neutrality by fostering private-sector innovation and collaboration. The initiative includes establishing dedicated research labs, launching a global flagship project for joint CCU development, and initiating large-scale demonstration projects in carbon-intensive sectors like cement and petrochemicals. It also aims to create a robust industrial ecosystem by linking CO₂ supply chains to marketable products, while advancing legal and institutional reforms to support private sector participation and technology certification.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Utilization, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture Policy South Korea Passes New Law To Support Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: South Korea has passed a new law to support the development and expansion of carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), establishing administrative and financial frameworks for CCUS operations, including the identification and management of offshore carbon storage sites. The legislation aligns with the country’s commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% from 2018 levels by 2030 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy confirmed that the law will facilitate industry growth by providing clear procedures for infrastructure deployment and operational oversight.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture, Environmental Legislation, South Korea

metadata.title: Markets KiudaEX Carbon Credit Exchange To Be Launched In Sri Lanka
metadata.indicator: South Korean company Kiuda Digital Holdings, in partnership with Sri Lankan tech startup Xeptagon, is launching KiudaEX, a blockchain-enabled carbon credit exchange in Sri Lanka, designed to streamline the purchase and trading of carbon offset credits for businesses in Asia. The platform leverages blockchain technology, automated processes, and enhanced security to improve transparency, reduce fraud, eliminate duplicate transactions, and cut paperwork, directly addressing inefficiencies in current carbon markets. The initiative, backed by investments from South Korean financial firms and conglomerates, aims to support regional decarbonization efforts and position Sri Lanka as a key player in Asia’s growing carbon trading ecosystem.
metadata.categories: Climate Finance, Carbon Markets, Blockchain Technology, Environmental Sustainability

metadata.title: Capture Energy Utilization South Korea To Explore Feasibility Of Carbon Capture And Utilization At Five New Sites
metadata.indicator: South Korea has selected five industrial sites across the country—including cement, steel, and coal facilities—for pilot projects testing carbon capture and utilization (CCU) technology, with the goal of overcoming economic barriers to commercialization. The sites include GS Caltex in Yeosu, Hanwha TotalEnergies in Seosan, Halla and Sampyo Cements in Gangwon, Pohang Steelworks, and Korea Midland Power in Boryeong. The projects, set to begin in 2026 after a feasibility study, aim to create viable commercial models by integrating CCU into existing industrial operations, with support from major players like Posco, KNOC, and Hyundai.
metadata.categories: Energy, Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Utilization, South Korea

metadata.title: Capture Bureau Veritas And Samsung Heavy Industries Partner To Advance CCS
metadata.indicator: Bureau Veritas and Samsung Heavy Industries have partnered to advance carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, specifically focusing on the development and certification of Floating CO2 Storage Units (FCSU) for deployment in the Republic of Korea. The collaboration combines Bureau Veritas’s expertise in testing, inspection, and certification with Samsung Heavy Industries’s innovative offshore and maritime engineering capabilities to validate, assess, and commercialize sustainable CCS solutions. The partnership includes pilot projects to evaluate technical and economic viability, along with comprehensive environmental studies and risk management plans to ensure the safety and sustainability of FCSU operations.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture and Storage, Maritime Industry, Environmental Technology, Sustainability

metadata.title: Markets Voluntary Xpansiv, Korea Exchange Strike Deal To Develop Voluntary Carbon Market
metadata.indicator: Carbon market infrastructure firm Xpansiv has signed a strategic agreement with the Korea Exchange (KRX) to co-develop a voluntary carbon market (VCM) in South Korea, leveraging Xpansiv’s CBL platform—the leading global spot exchange for carbon credits—integrated with KRX’s existing compliance carbon market infrastructure. The collaboration aims to create a transparent, liquid VCM that connects Korean buyers and sellers to a global order book, enhancing access to high-quality carbon credits for corporate clients and aligning with international frameworks like Article 6 of the Paris Agreement and CORSIA. The partnership will boost market efficiency, streamline credit access, and support South Korea’s broader climate goals, including the development of carbon emission futures.
metadata.categories: Markets, Voluntary Carbon Markets, Korea Exchange, Carbon Credits

metadata.title: Capture Storage Pilot Energy Welcomes Korean Delegation To Showcase CCS Progress In Australia
metadata.indicator: Pilot Energy, an Australian clean energy company, is showcasing its Mid West Clean Energy Project (MWCEP) near Geraldton, Western Australia, to a Korean delegation during the Australia-Korea CCUS Industry Seminar, highlighting advancements in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology. The project will convert the depleted Cliff Head offshore oil field into a permanent CO2 storage facility, with an initial capacity of over 1 million tonnes per year starting in 2026, and a total potential storage capacity exceeding 50 million tonnes—ranking among the top 10 global CCS projects. The initiative is supported by the Australian government’s Future Gas Strategy, which allocates additional greenhouse gas acreage for CCS and includes a $566 million investment in offshore mapping for identifying new CCS and clean hydrogen sites.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Companies Markets U.S. Tycoon Mark Cuban And dClimate To Back $1 Billion Congo Carbon Plan
metadata.indicator: dClimate, a U.S.-based startup leveraging AI and blockchain technology, has signed a preliminary $1 billion carbon credit deal with the Democratic Republic of Congo to prevent deforestation and protect 500,000 hectares of peatlands—critical carbon sinks—over ten years. The initiative aims to generate carbon credits by demonstrating deforestation prevention and establishing a transparent carbon credit registry, with the goal of selling credits at $7 to $10 per ton, significantly above the current $5 market rate. The plan addresses concerns around additionality by proving that the carbon sequestration would not have occurred without intervention, and relies on dClimate’s open data tools and technology to verify and monitor forest protection.
metadata.categories: Climate Initiatives, Carbon Credits, Environmental Sustainability

metadata.title: Markets J.P. Morgan’s Kinexys Advances Blockchain For Tokenized Carbon Markets
metadata.indicator: J.P. Morgan’s blockchain unit, Kinexys, is partnering with S&P Global Commodity Insights, EcoRegistry, and the International Carbon Registry (ICR) to develop a blockchain-based platform for tokenizing carbon credits using its Kinexys Digital Assets platform. The initiative focuses on registry-layer tokenization to enhance transparency, standardization, and efficiency in the voluntary carbon market by enabling digital, verifiable, and portable carbon credits throughout their lifecycle. Initial integration tests have been completed by EcoRegistry and ICR, with S&P Global beginning testing its Environmental Registry solution, aiming to resolve fragmentation, inconsistent data standards, and interoperability challenges in current carbon market infrastructure.
metadata.categories: Finance, Blockchain Technology, Environmental Markets

metadata.indicator: Carbon Clean has successfully completed the first industrial deployment of its CycloneCC technology, a breakthrough in carbon capture and removal, marking a significant step toward scalable and operational carbon capture solutions. The technology represents a new approach to capturing carbon dioxide from industrial flue gases, with demonstrated effectiveness in real-world industrial settings. This achievement advances the field of direct air capture and carbon removal, offering a potential pathway for large-scale carbon mitigation in industrial processes.
metadata.categories: Technology, Capture Technology, Energy Technology, Removal Technology, Startups, Direct Air Capture, Investment

metadata.title: Compliance Farming Markets Removal Voluntary Rio Tinto Joins A$250M Soil Carbon Platform In Australia
metadata.indicator: A $250 million Australian agricultural and carbon platform, Meldora, launched by the Clean Energy Finance Corporation (CEFC) and La Caisse, is pioneering integrated farming with soil carbon sequestration through the Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCUs) scheme. Managed by Gunn Agri Partners, Meldora will restore native vegetation on a 15,000-hectare farm in Central Queensland, generating long-term carbon credits maintained for 25 to 100 years, while also producing agricultural commodities to diversify revenue. Rio Tinto has been confirmed as a foundation off-taker, signaling strong industry demand for high-integrity, verifiable carbon credits and marking a shift toward sustainable, nature-based farming models.
metadata.categories: Carbon Offset Platforms, Sustainable Farming, Environmental Investment, Australian Carbon Market

metadata.title: Biomass Removal Pyrocal And Canada’s Capital Regional District Team Up On Biochar Production
metadata.indicator: Australian company Pyrocal has been selected by Canada’s Capital Regional District (CRD) to deploy its Continuous Carbonization Technology (CCT) at the Hartland Landfill in British Columbia, marking the first national-scale biochar production project in Canada. The technology will convert 100% of CRD’s Class A biosolids into biochar, reducing CO2 emissions and enhancing soil health through improved nutrient retention and water absorption. This initiative aligns with CRD’s long-term biosolids management strategy and represents a cross-border advancement in waste-to-resource technologies, with Pyrocal having previously deployed the same system in Australia.
metadata.categories: Biomass, Biochar, Environmental Technology, Canada, Australia

metadata.title: Capture Storage Moomba CCS Marks Milestone With Historic Australian Carbon Credit Allocation
metadata.indicator: Santos' Moomba carbon capture and storage (CCS) project in South Australia has achieved a record allocation of 614,133 Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCUs) after its first year of operations, sequestering 1.3 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent—approaching its full 1.7 million tonnes annual capacity. The project, which began CO2 injection in late 2024, demonstrates commercial-scale effectiveness, with the capacity to capture more CO2 in four days than 10,000 electric vehicles would prevent from emitting over a year. This milestone underscores the potential of CCS to deliver large-scale, cost-competitive emission reductions and positions Australia as a potential APAC carbon storage hub under the country’s robust geological and regulatory framework.
metadata.categories: Energy, Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Forests Markets Removal Voluntary Cibus Capital Launches A$300M Fund Targeting Forest Carbon Credits Across Australia
metadata.indicator: Cibus Capital has launched a $300 million fund, Cibus Carbon, targeting Australian forest carbon credit markets by investing in large-scale planted forestry projects across Australia. The fund aims to generate 11.25 million Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCUs) over 30 years, leveraging proprietary models to identify high-yield, low-cost planting sites with diverse native tree species. Backed by operational expertise from its ownership of Withcott Seedlings, the fund aligns with growing global demand for high-quality carbon offsets amid regulatory and voluntary market pressures.
metadata.categories: Environmental Investment, Carbon Credits, Forestry, Natural Capital

metadata.title: Capture Storage Utilization GAS LAB Asia And Evo Energy Partner To Accelerate Carbon Capture In Australasia
metadata.indicator: GAS LAB Asia and Evo Energy Technologies Pty Ltd have formed a strategic partnership to accelerate the deployment of carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) solutions across Australia and New Zealand, focusing on heavy-emitting industries such as cement, steel, power generation, and waste-to-energy. The collaboration leverages GAS LAB Asia’s modular, skid-based CO₂ capture systems and Evo Energy’s on-ground project execution capabilities to deliver scalable, ready-to-deploy solutions that integrate directly with downstream applications like CO₂-enriched agriculture, beverage production, and water remineralization. The initiative also targets biogenic CO₂ from biomass and biogas operations, with plans to establish demonstration units before scaling to commercial operations, supporting regional decarbonization and advancing Australia’s CCUS ambitions.
metadata.categories: Energy, Decarbonization, Carbon Capture

metadata.title: Markets REED/REDD+ Brazil’s Piauí State And Silvania Launch Jurisdictional REDD+ Program
metadata.indicator: The Brazilian state of Piauí has launched a jurisdictional REDD+ (JREDD) program in partnership with global natural capital platform Silvania, marking a significant public-private initiative to combat deforestation and generate carbon credits. Silvania, committed with a $500 million upfront investment, will provide financing, certification under the ART TREES standard, and act as the exclusive buyer of carbon credits generated from forest protection efforts. The program, led by Geonoma with technical support from Brazilian environmental firm Systemica, aims to reduce deforestation by 10% annually, potentially generating over 20 million carbon credits by 2030, and aligns with Silvania’s broader Race to Belém campaign to attract private investment ahead of COP30.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Credits, REDD+, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Prices REED/REDD+ Silvania Launches $1.5B Initiative To Protect The Amazon
metadata.indicator: Silvania, a carbon markets investor backed by Mercuria, has launched the “Race to Belém” initiative—a $1.5 billion initiative to protect the Amazon rainforest through Jurisdictional Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (JREDD+) carbon credits—collaborating with Conservation International and The Nature Conservancy. The project will engage Brazilian states, farmers, and local communities to generate carbon credits, with Silvania pledging up to $100 million in upfront capital per ton of credits purchased, and aims to generate hundreds of millions of tons of carbon savings over the next three to five years. This effort responds to the Amazon's tipping point risk due to record-breaking temperatures, offering a scalable, jurisdictional approach to deforestation mitigation that enhances environmental and social impact tracking.
metadata.categories: Environmental Conservation, Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Indigenous Rights

metadata.title: Afforestation/Reforestation (ARR) Markets Press Release Prices REED/REDD+ Earth Blox Partners With Chloris Geospatial To Expand Forest Carbon Assessments And Compliance Solutions
metadata.indicator: Earth Blox, a spatial intelligence platform for climate and nature risk management, has partnered with Chloris Geospatial to integrate high-resolution, machine-learning-enhanced forest carbon data into its platform. Chloris, founded by scientists from top U.S. research institutions, uses advanced satellite remote sensing to deliver accurate above-ground biomass and forest cover change metrics, enabling businesses to assess and validate carbon credits under regulations like the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR). This collaboration enhances Earth Blox’s capabilities for providing rapid, scalable, and actionable forest carbon data to enterprises managing sustainability compliance and nature-based solutions.
metadata.categories: Climate Tech, Forest Carbon, Remote Sensing, Environmental Compliance

metadata.title: Markets REED/REDD+ ICVCM Sees Expert Resignations Over REDD Methodologies
metadata.indicator: Two prominent sustainability experts, Jürg Füssler of INFRAS and Dr. Lambert Schneider of Oeko-Institut, have resigned from the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Market (ICVCM) following criticism that three newly approved REDD+ carbon credit methodologies—TREES v2.0, VCS VM0048, and JNR v4.1—fail to meet core principles of additionality, robust quantification, and permanence. They argue the methodologies risk over- or under-estimating baseline emissions and undermine market integrity, especially given the practice of project developers setting their own baselines. Despite ICVCM’s assertion that these methods align with its Core Carbon Principles and represent a necessary step toward market trust, the resignations highlight deep concerns within the scientific and policy community over the validity and transparency of voluntary carbon market standards.
metadata.categories: Markets, REDD+, Carbon Credits, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Bayer Announces ‘Project Enhanced S3’ To Enable Companies To Realize Additional Sustainability Value From Carbon Removal Projects
metadata.indicator: Bayer has launched "Project Enhanced S3," an expanded initiative within its carbon sequestration and regenerative agriculture programs, designed to help food and beverage companies quantify and report the co-benefits of carbon removal projects across their supply chains. By integrating data from digital farming tools like ForGround and Climate FieldView™, the project captures additional value from regenerative practices—including soil health, water efficiency, biodiversity, and farmer economic support—beyond carbon sequestration. The initiative enables businesses to measure, verify, and report on these broader sustainability outcomes without imposing extra administrative burdens on farmers, leveraging Bayer’s agronomic expertise and existing field-level data infrastructure.
metadata.categories: Environmental Sustainability, Climate Change, Regenerative Agriculture

metadata.title: REED/REDD+ MORFO Launches Call For ARR Projects To Scale Reforestation In Brazil
metadata.indicator: Franco-Brazilian company MORFO is launching a call for Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation (ARR) projects to scale large-scale restoration in Brazil, targeting the Amazon, Atlantic Forest, and Cerrado biomes. The initiative seeks to identify and support projects of at least 1,000 hectares—with a preference for over 5,000 hectares—offering developers cost-efficient, scalable, and ecologically sound solutions using advanced AI and drone technology capable of restoring up to 50 hectares per day. The program emphasizes transparency, financial predictability, and long-term partnerships, with MORFO providing end-to-end support including native seed supply, land assessment, project design, planting, and monitoring, and offering free expert reviews and connections to carbon buyers.
metadata.categories: Afforestation, Reforestation, Carbon Markets, Environmental Initiatives

metadata.title: Afforestation/Reforestation (ARR) Markets Press Release REED/REDD+ Irish Remote Sensing Company Signs $950,000 Contract With European Space Agency
metadata.indicator: Proveye, an Irish remote sensing company based at NovaUCD in Dublin, has secured a $950,000 contract with the European Space Agency (ESA) under the ARTES Business Applications and Space Solutions Programme to further develop its AI-powered platform that integrates satellite and drone imagery for high-precision monitoring of grassland ecosystems, carbon sequestration, and biodiversity. The technology enables stakeholders—including farmers, carbon credit buyers, and natural capital investors—to verify and quantify the environmental impact of regenerative grazing and nature-based solutions through metric-based, scalable data collection. This advancement addresses the critical challenge of monitoring vast grassland areas, which cover 54% of Earth’s surface and store over 20% of global soil carbon, by delivering actionable, empirical data to support climate resilience and sustainable food production.
metadata.categories: Environmental Monitoring, Remote Sensing, Climate Change, Sustainable Food Production

metadata.title: Carbon Accounting Markets Gold Standard Unveils Certification Framework Updates To Boost Paris Agreement Alignment
metadata.indicator: Gold Standard, a leading carbon registry organization, has introduced updated certification framework rules effective January 1, 2026, to improve environmental integrity and align with the Paris Agreement. Key updates include revised baseline setting, a new Additionality Demonstration V1.0 framework, and updated accounting methods for non-renewable biomass (fNRB), replacing outdated CDM Tool 30 with more transparent and Paris-aligned approaches such as MoFuSS and CDM Tool 33. These changes aim to ensure that carbon credits reflect genuine emission reductions beyond business-as-usual and support compliance with Article 6 of the Paris Agreement.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Markets, Environmental Certification

metadata.title: Biomass Removal Utilization Cowboy Clean Fuels’ New Methodology Combines CDR With Renewable Energy
metadata.indicator: Cowboy Clean Fuels (CCF), a Denver-based renewable energy and CO2 technology company, has developed a novel, industry-first methodology called BiCRS+RNG that integrates Biomass Carbon Removal and Storage (BiCRS) with Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) production. The approach involves injecting carbon-rich biomass into geologic formations, where microbial action converts it into biomethane and permanently sequesters carbon through durable adsorption, preventing atmospheric CO2 release. This process enables the production of low-carbon RNG for commercial use while meeting stringent verification standards, including ISO 14064-2:2019, and provides a verifiable pathway for high-integrity carbon removal credits.
metadata.categories: Renewable Energy, Carbon Removal, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture Removal Endress+Hauser And Mangrove Systems Partner On Next-Gen Carbon Monitoring
metadata.indicator: Endress+Hauser and Mangrove Systems have partnered to develop a next-generation carbon monitoring solution by integrating Endress+Hauser’s precision measurement instrumentation—such as flow, level, pressure, and temperature sensors—with Mangrove Systems’ digital measurement, reporting, and verification (dMRV) platform. The collaboration aims to improve data accuracy and transparency in carbon removal and carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects by enabling precise CO₂ measurement and streamlined data management from collection to monetization through mechanisms like the 45Q production tax credit and voluntary carbon markets.
metadata.categories: Carbon Monitoring, Climate Change, Environmental Technology, Decarbonization

metadata.title: Capture Fuels Utilization Can Sustainable Aviation Fuel Fulfill Its Potential?
metadata.indicator: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has approved a $782 million loan for Montana Renewables’ biofuel refinery in Great Falls, enabling it to scale production to 315 million gallons per year—supplying approximately half of North America’s sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). This project, alongside Gevo’s Net-Zero 1 facility in South Dakota, which will produce jet fuel from corn starch, forms part of a $3 billion federal and private investment push to achieve commercial-scale SAF production and reduce aviation emissions by up to 75%. However, uncertainty persists due to the stalled 45Z tax credit, lack of long-term offtake agreements (currently limited to 1–2 year contracts), and political resistance—such as the DOE's objection to ICAO’s recommendation on multi-cropping—potentially undermining U.S. progress. In contrast, the EU is driving demand through its RefuelEU Aviation Regulation, mandating 2% SAF blending by 2025 and increasing to 70% by 2050, backed by 20 million carbon allowances worth $1.73 billion, while ICAO’s proposed Finvest Hub aims to facilitate global investment in SAF and low-carbon aviation fuels.
metadata.categories: Aviation, Renewable Energy, Sustainable Fuel, Climate Policy

metadata.title: Utilization Sustainable Aviation Fuel Pioneer XCF Global Takes Flight With Ambitious IPO Amid Industry Tailwinds
metadata.indicator: XCF Global, a leading sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) company, is preparing for an IPO amid growing global demand for low-carbon aviation fuels, bolstered by international mandates and market expansion. The company has secured a 15-year agreement with Phillips 66 for feedstock supply and off-take, providing operational stability and pricing flexibility, while navigating uncertainty around the expiration of U.S. federal incentives under the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) in 2027. In response, XCF is betting on state-level incentives—such as California’s AB 481 and emerging programs in Nevada, Illinois, Minnesota, and others—to drive domestic production, and is expanding its project pipeline to align with global demand, including Europe’s 2% to 70% SAF mandate by 2050 and international CORSIA requirements.
metadata.categories: Sustainable Aviation Fuel, Aviation Industry, Renewable Energy, Climate Policy

metadata.title: Capture Storage INEOS And Royal Wagenborg Launch “Carbon Destroyer 1,” Europe’s First Offshore CO2 Carrier
metadata.indicator: INEOS Energy and Royal Wagenborg have launched Carbon Destroyer 1, Europe’s first offshore liquefied CO2 carrier, designed to transport captured carbon dioxide from emission sources to permanent storage sites in the North Sea. The vessel, built on the Wagenborg EasyMax platform, will operate as a “virtual pipeline” between the Esbjerg CO2 terminal and the Nini West platform, transporting CO2 under pressure and low temperature for safe, deep-sea injection 1,800 meters below the seabed. It marks a key milestone for Project Greensand, the EU’s first commercial-scale carbon capture and storage (CCS) value chain, with initial operations expected by late 2025 or early 2026 and a projected annual capacity of up to 8 million tons of CO2 by 2030.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture and Storage, Offshore Transportation, Europe Climate Initiatives

metadata.title: Capture Storage Norway Awards Equinor, Harbour Energy and Aker BP New CO2 Storage Permits
metadata.indicator: Norway has awarded new offshore CO2 storage permits to Equinor, Harbour Energy, and Aker BP, expanding its existing network of carbon capture and storage (CCS) infrastructure in the North Sea. The permits cover Blocks EXL012 and EXL013, with Equinor operating both and already operating in previous CCS projects, including the Smeaheia/CO2 Highway Europe site where drilling of the first carbon storage well has begun. The permits come with binding work programs and conditions for relinquishment if development milestones are not met, underscoring regulatory oversight and commitment to project accountability in Norway's CCS strategy.
metadata.categories: Energy, Climate and Environment, Carbon Capture and Storage

metadata.title: Markets Carbon Offsets, CCUS To See Trillion-Dollar Surge By 2050, Wood Mackenzie Says
metadata.indicator: Carbon Capture, Utilization and Storage (CCUS) and carbon offset markets are projected to reach combined trillion-dollar valuations by 2050, with CCUS capacity expanding 28-fold to 2,061 million tonnes per year and attracting $1.2 trillion in investment, while the carbon offset market is expected to surpass $150 billion, growing sixfold and seeing carbon removals account for over 40% of total offsets by mid-century. The convergence of CCUS and carbon offsets is becoming central to global net-zero strategies, especially in hard-to-abate sectors like cement, refining, and steel, driven by corporate climate commitments, evolving carbon pricing, and stricter regulations on offset quality and permanence. Wood Mackenzie highlights the need for infrastructure development, standardization, and continued government support—particularly for CCUS—to ensure market resilience and trust.
metadata.categories: Carbon Markets, CCUS, Carbon Offsets, Climate Policy

metadata.title: Capture Energy Stanford Study: Renewable Energy Beats Carbon Capture On Cost And Climate Impact
metadata.indicator: A Stanford University study published in Environmental Science & Technology demonstrates that a global transition to wind, solar, geothermal, and hydropower by 2050 is significantly more cost-effective and environmentally beneficial than relying on carbon capture technologies. The research shows that such a renewable-only transition could cut global energy use by over half, lower energy costs by nearly 60%, and prevent millions of premature deaths from air pollution, while carbon capture—whether from industrial sources or ambient air—adds energy demand, costs, and limited environmental benefits. Lead author Mark Jacobson emphasizes that capturing emissions after combustion is inefficient and diverts clean energy away from directly replacing fossil fuels, concluding that the only way to eliminate climate-warming gases is to eliminate combustion entirely.
metadata.categories: Energy, Climate Change, Renewable Energy

metadata.title: Markets Climate Impact Partners Cuts 150M Tonnes Of CO2e In 2025, Commits To Deep Emissions Reductions
metadata.indicator: Climate Impact Partners achieved a global reduction of over 150 million tonnes of CO2e in 2025 through 600+ projects across 60+ countries, equivalent to the annual emissions of the Netherlands. The company, a leader in high-integrity carbon market solutions, reported 5.6 million MWh of clean energy generated—enough to power over half a million UK homes—and committed to a 42% reduction in Scope 1 and 3 emissions, zero Scope 2 emissions via 100% renewable energy, and a 51.6% drop in business travel emissions. These achievements are part of a broader effort to scale credible carbon removals and strengthen carbon markets through partnerships in climate initiatives like clean cooking in Bangladesh, reforestation in Ghana, and UK seagrass restoration.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Environmental Impact

metadata.title: Markets DelAgua And Oka Join Forces In Compliance Carbon Markets With New Product
metadata.indicator: Oka and DelAgua have launched a new carbon insurance product, Corresponding Adjustment Protect™, designed to mitigate financial risk for buyers and sellers of carbon credits in compliance markets by providing compensation if a Corresponding Adjustment—required under ICAO’s CORSIA rules—fails due to a country withdrawing or not submitting its authorization. The product, underwritten by Oka Syndicate 1922 at Lloyd’s and developed in partnership with DelAgua, which holds the first Corresponding Adjustment-tagged credits on the VERRA platform in Rwanda, offers protection against "Article 6 revocation" risks. This innovation enhances confidence in voluntary carbon markets by addressing a key compliance vulnerability tied to double-counting and international credit validity.
metadata.categories: Carbon Market, Insurance, Climate Finance

metadata.title: Capture Utilization Again Breaks Ground On Pioneering Carbon Transformation Facility In Texas
metadata.indicator: Carbon transformation company Again has broken ground on its first commercial-scale U.S. facility in Texas City, where it will convert industrial CO2 emissions into sustainable chemicals like acetic acid and sustainable fertilizers using a proprietary biomanufacturing process. The facility leverages on-site CO2 from an industrial emitter, eliminating the need for energy-intensive transport and enabling a plug-and-play integration with existing operations. By deploying bacteria in industrial bioreactors to ferment CO2 and hydrogen into market-ready chemicals, Again aims to decarbonize the petrochemical sector and strengthen domestic supply chains for key industrial and agricultural inputs.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, Chemical Industry, Sustainability, Decarbonization

metadata.title: Forests Removal New Study: EU Forests Are Losing Their Carbon Absorbing Capacity
metadata.indicator: A new study by the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre reveals that EU forests are losing their ability to absorb atmospheric CO2, with annual carbon uptake declining from 456.9 million tonnes (2010–2014) to 332.6 million tonnes (2020–2022), due to increased tree harvesting, rising temperatures, and climate-related stressors like droughts and heatwaves that promote wildfires and insect infestations. The research warns that this degradation threatens the EU’s climate goals—reducing emissions by 90% by 2040 and achieving net-zero by 2050—by undermining the reliability of forests as carbon sinks. The study recommends leveraging AI and satellite technology for improved forest carbon monitoring and modeling to better predict and manage carbon fluxes in a warming climate.
metadata.categories: Environmental Science, Climate Change, Forestry

metadata.title: Afforestation/Reforestation (ARR) Forests Markets Removal
metadata.indicator: Northern Trust has entered into a service agreement with Ecosystem Certification Organization (ECO) to administer the recordation and settlement of digital carbon credits certified under ECO’s Natural Forest Standard (NFS), marking a key step in separating governance from operational functions in the voluntary carbon market. This move leverages Northern Trust’s digital platform, the Northern Trust Carbon Ecosystem™, to provide lifecycle management for carbon credits tied to afforestation and reforestation projects that prevent deforestation and forest degradation. By outsourcing registry and settlement services, ECO can focus on project-level support and standard governance, while Northern Trust ensures secure, transparent, and efficient transaction processing for digital carbon credits.
metadata.categories: Forests, Carbon Credits, Environmental Standards

metadata.title: Afforestation/Reforestation (ARR) Forests Removal New Project By Biomas Wil Restore Native Forests In Brazil
metadata.indicator: Eco-restoration startup Biomas has launched a large-scale reforestation project in Brazil, known as Muçununga, to restore 1,200 hectares of degraded Atlantic rainforest in the Bahia region by planting over 2 million native trees. The initiative, funded by a $9.7 million (R$55 million) investment, partners with cellulose company Veracel, which provides land previously used for pulp production, and will proceed in phases including community engagement, soil preparation, and tree planting. The project will generate around 500,000 carbon removal credits over 40 years, with monitoring and transparent reporting to support carbon credit validation and market access.
metadata.categories: Environmental Conservation, Reforestation, Climate Change, Brazil

metadata.title: Microsoft Inks 30-Year Carbon Credit Deal With Afforestation Project In India
metadata.indicator: Microsoft has signed a 30-year agreement with UK-based Climate Impact Partners to purchase 1.5 million carbon removal credits from a large-scale afforestation project in Madhya Pradesh, India, covering 20,000 hectares and targeting the planting of up to 11.6 million trees. The project, developed by Terra Natural Capital and implemented in the Panna region, leverages Verra’s latest methodology for afforestation, reforestation, and revegetation, and will generate an estimated three million carbon removal credits over its lifetime. The initiative supports local farmers by providing direct shares of carbon credit proceeds, promotes sustainable farming, water conservation, and biodiversity through indigenous species, and marks Microsoft’s first large-scale carbon removal project in India and its largest in the APAC region.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Afforestation, Reforestation

metadata.title: Afforestation/Reforestation (ARR) Forests Removal Mombak Secures $30M In Series A Funding To Scale Up CDR Operations
metadata.indicator: Brazilian startup Mombak has secured $30 million in Series A funding, led by Union Square Ventures, to scale its afforestation and reforestation (ARR) operations, focusing on planting native trees on degraded farmland and pasture in the Amazon region. The company has already planted five million trees across over 45,000 acres and secured $150 million in carbon removal contracts, with ambitions to quadruple this volume by 2025 and reach eight million trees by June. Mombak’s efforts aim to restore biodiversity, support local economies, and generate high-integrity carbon removal credits for the voluntary carbon market.
metadata.categories: Environmental Sustainability, Reforestation, Carbon Removal, Climate Change, Startups

metadata.title: Afforestation/Reforestation (ARR) Forests Press Release Prices Removal Land Life And Colorado State Land Board To Reforest Wildfire-Affected Ecosystems
metadata.indicator: Land Life, a global restoration company, has announced a first-of-its-kind partnership with the Colorado State Land Board to reforest up to 1,000 acres of wildfire-affected land across Grand, Huerfano, and Larimer counties. The project, focused on afforestation, reforestation, and revegetation (ARR), will plant native tree species to enhance biodiversity, improve watershed health, and generate high-integrity carbon credits certified by Verra. A portion of the carbon revenue will be returned to public funds, directly supporting public schools, and the initiative marks Land Life’s first public-sector collaboration in North America.
metadata.categories: Reforestation, Climate Change, Public Lands, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: Markets Removal BeZero Sees $1.3B In Tax Revenue, 135,000 New Jobs In UK Carbon Market By 2035
metadata.indicator: The UK carbon credit market could generate up to $1.334 billion in tax revenue and 135,000 skilled jobs by 2035, according to BeZero Carbon’s report “From Risk to Reward,” with 80,000 jobs in nature-based projects, 30,000 in engineered carbon removal like Direct Air Capture, and 25,000 in market infrastructure. The report recommends integrating carbon removals into the UK Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) to drive investment and support climate goals, with the potential to channel $13.3 billion annually into high-impact carbon projects—nearly matching the UK’s 2024 international aid budget.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, UK Economy, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Markets Calyx Global Opens Carbon Credit Ratings Platform To the Public
metadata.indicator: Calyx Global has launched a public carbon credit ratings platform that evaluates the environmental and social integrity of carbon credits based on criteria such as additionality, permanence, and SDG impacts, offering transparent, peer-reviewed ratings to enhance market trust and enable stakeholders to make informed decisions. The platform provides searchable, intuitive tools to assess GHG integrity and community benefits, with advanced subscription features including detailed project scores (AAA to D), data analytics, and API integration for enterprise use.
metadata.categories: Environmental Sustainability, Carbon Markets, Climate Change

metadata.title: Energy Mineralization Removal ON Power & Carbfix Officially Launch CDR At Geothermal Plant, Backed By EU Funding
metadata.indicator: Carbfix and On Power have launched Steingerður, a carbon capture and mineralization facility at the Hellisheiði geothermal plant in Iceland, as part of the Silverstone project. The facility captures 95% of greenhouse gases—including CO₂ and H₂S—from geothermal steam using direct water capture, then mineralizes the CO₂ by dissolving it in water and injecting it underground, where it reacts to form solid rock over two years. Backed by €3.87 million from the EU Innovation Fund, the project aims to capture and store 30,000 tonnes of CO₂ annually, contributing to 10% of Iceland’s 2030 climate targets and advancing the country’s goal of a 55% emissions reduction by 2030.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Geothermal Energy, Climate Change

metadata.title: Uncategorized Utilization Mitsubishi Electric To Test Carbon Capture & Utilization On Brewery
metadata.indicator: Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, in collaboration with Taiwan’s Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the Taiwan Tobacco & Liquor Corporation’s Jhunan Brewery, is conducting demonstration tests of carbon capture and utilization (CCU) to recycle CO2 emitted during beer production. The captured CO2 will be purified and reused within the brewery’s manufacturing processes, marking a step toward industrial decarbonization and carbon recycling. This follows prior joint R&D efforts between Mitsubishi Electric and ITRI in Japan, where a CO2 capture system was tested on gas boiler flue gas, with the new Taiwan project advancing toward commercial-scale CCU deployment in the beverage industry.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, Utilization, Sustainability, Industrial Decarbonization

metadata.indicator: Agreena has launched AgreenaGro, a digital platform that supports UK farmers in transitioning to regenerative agriculture by providing tools for monitoring soil health, measuring carbon sequestration, and monetizing environmental benefits through carbon credits and supply chain partnerships. The platform features tools like Map My Farm, RegenAg Score, and Field Rotation Score to track sustainability progress and offers real-time insights and peer networking via RegenMatch, while integrating with farm management systems like fieldmargin. An AI-powered farm assistant is planned for future rollout to deliver tailored agronomic advice, enhancing decision-making and resilience amid climate pressures and rising input costs.
metadata.categories: Agriculture, Regenerative Agriculture, Climate Policy

metadata.title: Uncategorized Atal Solutions Launches $123.7M Retrofit Project To Cut Shipping Emissions
metadata.indicator: Atal Solutions has launched a $123.7 million retrofit project in collaboration with Damen Shipyards Group, Blue Astra Maritime Shipping, and the Besiktas Group to upgrade four shipping vessels in Istanbul, integrating ten advanced technologies including carbon capture systems, air lubrication, closed-loop scrubbers, and energy-saving LEDs to reduce CO2, SOₓ, and NOₓ emissions while improving fuel efficiency and eliminating vessel waste. Early results show at least 25% fuel savings, and the project leverages an innovative financing model where suppliers cover 85% of costs, highlighting a commercially viable pathway for decarbonizing shipping amid tightening regulatory pressures like the EU Emissions Trading System.
metadata.categories: Energy, Maritime, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Uncategorized OQGN Targets Ibri Power Plant For Carbon Capture In Partnership With Oxy Oman
metadata.indicator: OQ Gas Networks (OQGN) has identified Oman’s 1,509 MW Ibri Power Plant as a priority site for carbon capture and utilization in partnership with Occidental (Oxy) Oman, advancing the Sultanate’s Net Zero 2050 goals through carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) and hydrogen transport initiatives. The collaboration includes joint development of hydrogen infrastructure with Fluxys, a Belgian energy group holding a 4.9% stake in OQGN, and expands OQGN’s efforts to integrate CCUS and blue hydrogen into its existing gas network. The project is part of a broader “House of Expertise” initiative with the Ministry of Energy and Minerals and Hydrom to establish regulatory frameworks and open-access pipeline networks for green hydrogen and CO₂ transport.
metadata.categories: Energy, Climate Change, Carbon Capture, Oil and Gas, Hydrogen

metadata.title: Capsol To Study BECCS Integration At European Biomass CHP Plant
metadata.tech: BECCS (Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage)
metadata.indicator: Norwegian carbon capture specialist Capsol Technologies is conducting a feasibility study to integrate its CapsolEoP technology into a European biomass-fired combined heat and power (CHP) plant, aiming to enable bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) that can achieve net-negative emissions by removing over 200,000 metric tons of CO2 annually. The study focuses on overcoming technical and economic challenges, including energy efficiency penalties from CO2 capture, variability in biomass fuel composition, and underutilization of capture equipment during low-demand periods. By leveraging waste heat and flexible capture systems, the project seeks to maintain operational reliability while expanding the CHP plant’s role in district heating and generating durable carbon removal credits.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture, Bioenergy, Renewable Energy

metadata.title: Farming Markets Removal Uncategorized Perennial Launches First Verra-Approved AI Tool For Soil Carbon Quantification
metadata.indicator: Perennial has launched VT0014, the first Verra-approved AI-driven tool for soil carbon quantification, leveraging its proprietary ATLAS-SOC model trained on over 350,000 soil samples and enhanced by machine learning and biogeochemical predictors. The tool enables digital soil mapping by extrapolating soil organic carbon (SOC) data from limited local samples, generating hundreds to thousands of times more data points than traditional field sampling—reducing costs, minimizing farm disruption, and expanding access to underserved regions. By aligning with Verra’s Agricultural Land Management methodologies and integrating with the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS), VT0014 establishes new benchmarks for digital soil carbon measurement and facilitates scalable, cost-effective carbon project development in regenerative agriculture.
metadata.categories: Soil Carbon Measurement, AI Technology, Climate Solutions, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: Uncategorized Utilization HYCO1 And Malaysia LNG Team Up For Landmark Carbon Utilization Project
metadata.indicator: HYCO1 has entered into a Memorandum of Understanding with Malaysia LNG (MLNG), a PETRONAS subsidiary, to develop a large-scale carbon capture and utilization (CCU) facility in Bintulu, Sarawak, leveraging HYCO1’s proprietary CUBE™ technology to convert captured carbon dioxide into industrial-grade syngas. The project marks a shift from traditional carbon capture and storage (CCS) by instead recycling CO2 into marketable fuels and chemicals, creating economic value while reducing emissions. The joint feasibility study aims to establish a low-carbon syngas production pathway for industrial use, with the facility expected to be completed by 2029, representing one of the largest CCU initiatives globally.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture and Utilization, Industrial Sustainability, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture Fuels Japan Airlines Wraps First Phase Of SAF Market Trial
metadata.indicator: Japan Airlines, in collaboration with six major partners including ITOCHU Corporation, ENEOS, NIPPON EXPRESS, Mizuho Bank, Mizuho Research & Technologies, and Narita International Airport, has successfully completed the first phase of a pilot program to trade the environmental value of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) through a digital platform integrated with a Scope 3 emissions trading system. The eight-month trial at Narita Airport demonstrated the feasibility of bilateral contract negotiations, verified trade data, and transparent digital exchange, with independent validation by ClassNK confirming the platform’s functionality and transparency. The project now advances to Phase 2 to expand participation, enhance awareness of Scope 3 carbon accounting, and evaluate pathways for broader industry adoption in decarbonizing aviation.
metadata.categories: Aviation, Sustainable Aviation Fuel, Carbon Trading, Decarbonization

metadata.title: Removal Mitsubishi Launches Japan CDR Coalition To Accelerate Carbon Removal
metadata.indicator: Mitsubishi Research Institute and Mitsubishi Corporation have launched the Japan CDR Coalition to accelerate the development and deployment of carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, aiming to support Japan’s net-zero goals by fostering collaboration among public and private stakeholders. The coalition will advance practical CDR solutions, establish market infrastructure, and create a favorable investment environment, with a focus on technologies like enhanced rock weathering and mineralization. It responds to Japan’s GX Promotion Law and “GX2040 Vision,” positioning CDR as a driver of industrial growth and regional revitalization in hard-to-abate sectors.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Removal, Japan, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Biomass Removal Japan’s MOL Takes Landmark Step In Carbon Removal With Biochar Credits From Exomad Green
metadata.indicator: Mitsui O.S.K. Lines (MOL) has become the first Japanese shipping company to officially retire 2,000 tons of technology-based carbon dioxide removal (CDR) credits from a biochar project in Bolivia, operated by Exomad Green. The credits are derived from biomass-to-biochar conversion, a process that sequesters carbon for long durations. This marks a strategic shift in MOL’s climate efforts from emission reduction to active carbon removal, aligning with its Environmental Vision 2.2 goal of removing 2.2 million tons of CO₂ by 2030. Meanwhile, NYK has entered into a three-year agreement with Climeworks to purchase CDR credits across multiple technologies—including biochar, direct air capture, and enhanced rock weathering—and is set to receive marine fuel with CDR credits from ENEOS starting in 2028.
metadata.categories: Biomass, Carbon Removal, Maritime Sustainability, Biochar, Environmental Strategy

metadata.title: Capture Fuels Japan Introduces World’s First Carrier For Both LCO2 And Methanol
metadata.indicator: Mitsui O.S.K. Lines (MOL) and Mitsubishi Shipbuilding have developed the world’s first dual-purpose maritime carrier capable of transporting both liquefied carbon dioxide (LCO2) and methanol, receiving the first Approval in Principle (AiP) from ClassNK. The vessel operates with a low-pressure LCO2 framework modified to handle methanol, enabling it to carry LCO2 outbound and synthetic methanol on return trips, eliminating empty ballast and improving operational efficiency. This innovation supports a circular, low-carbon maritime economy by enabling carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) through the transport of synthetic methanol derived from captured CO2.
metadata.categories: Maritime Innovation, Carbon Capture and Storage, Sustainable Shipping, Alternative Fuels

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal NYK Signs Second Carbon Removal Agreement With 1PointFive
metadata.indicator: Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK), a major Japanese shipping company, has signed a second agreement to purchase carbon dioxide removal (CDR) credits through 1PointFive’s Direct Air Capture (DAC) technology, specifically from its STRATOS facility in Texas. This marks NYK’s continued commitment to addressing residual operational emissions in shipping, which it estimates at around 100 million tons annually despite efficiency improvements and fuel transitions. The deal underscores the growing role of DAC in hard-to-abate sectors, with NYK combining fuel supply with carbon removal credits, as seen in a prior partnership with ENEOS.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, Decarbonization, Shipping

metadata.title: Capture Companies Press Release MHI & Worley Awarded FEED Contract For Heidelberg Materials’ Carbon Capture Project
metadata.indicator: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI), in partnership with Worley, has been awarded a Front End Engineering Design (FEED) contract by Heidelberg Materials UK to develop a carbon capture and storage (CCS) project at the Padeswood Cement Works in Flintshire, UK. The project will deploy MHI’s proprietary Advanced KM CDR Process™ technology to capture up to 800,000 tons of CO₂ annually from cement production, storing it in a depleted gas field off Liverpool Bay as part of the HyNet CCUS cluster. The project, expected to begin operations in 2028, supports Heidelberg Materials UK’s net-zero by 2050 commitment and contributes to decarbonizing the UK construction industry through carbon-neutral cement production.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, Industrial Decarbonization, CCUS, Construction Industry

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal Aircapture Secures $50M In Series A Funding To Scale Its Modular DAC Tech
metadata.indicator: California-based direct air capture (DAC) startup Aircapture has secured $50 million in Series A funding, led by the Larsen Lam Climate Change Foundation, to scale its modular DAC technology. The company’s system captures atmospheric CO₂ on-site at industrial facilities, purifies it, and delivers high-purity carbon dioxide directly for industrial use—offering a reliable, on-demand alternative to volatile supply chains tied to oil & gas byproducts. Recognized as a winner in the XPRIZE Carbon Removal competition through Project Hajar, Aircapture is now expanding manufacturing capacity for containerized DAC units and accelerating commercial deployment across North America, Europe, and Asia.
metadata.categories: Environmental Technology, Carbon Removal, Climate Change

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal Storage Utilization Mission Zero Technologies Debuts Internationally By Launching A DAC Unit At Deep Sky Alpha
metadata.indicator: Mission Zero Technologies (MZT) has deployed a direct air capture (DAC) unit at Deep Sky Alpha in Alberta, Canada, marking a significant expansion of its carbon removal capabilities with a six-fold increase in capture capacity—up to 250 tonnes of CO2 annually—compared to its pilot system, and a 60% reduction in operational cost. The unit, powered by solar energy, captures atmospheric CO2 for either underground storage or direct use in producing sustainable aviation fuel and carbon-negative building materials through partnerships with O.C.O Technology and the UK Department of Energy Security and Net Zero. This deployment represents the third DAC facility in MZT’s portfolio and serves as a key testbed for optimizing low-cost, low-energy DAC technologies.
metadata.categories: Direct Air Capture, Carbon Removal, Climate Technology

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal Deep Sky Alpha Is Now Live And Operational In Canada
metadata.indicator: Deep Sky has launched Deep Sky Alpha, the first direct air capture (DAC) and underground CO2 storage facility in North America, located in Innisfail, Alberta.
