metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal DACLab Launches Kelvin – A New DAC System Stated To Be The Most Cost-Efficient So Far
metadata.indicator: Climate startup DACLab has launched the Kelvin Direct Air Capture (DAC) system, a cost-efficient technology that captures carbon dioxide from ambient air using a patent-pending Temperature Vacuum Swing Adsorption (TVSA) cycle, operating at as low as 70°C during regeneration—50% less energy than conventional DAC systems. The system achieves a capture cost of $500/tonne at 10,000 tonnes per year, with a projected reduction to $250/tonne at scale without subsidies, and has demonstrated continuous operation for over 2,000 hours on pilot units. It features a "moving-bed" design that optimizes adsorption and desorption phases, reducing pressure drop and enabling efficient, low-energy carbon removal with a proven energy demand below 1800 kWh per tonne of CO2 captured.
metadata.categories: Climate Technology, Carbon Capture, Environmental Innovation

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal New Study Looks Into The Role Of DAC Technology In Sustainable Aviation
metadata.indicator: A study by the Institute for Environmental Decisions in Zürich evaluates the potential of Direct Air Capture (DAC) technologies—specifically DACCS (capture and storage) and DACCU (capture and utilization)—to support climate-neutral aviation by 2050, with findings indicating that DACCU is more cost-effective for achieving climate neutrality due to its ability to mitigate non-CO2 effects like contrails through synthetic fuels, while DACCS remains cheaper for CO2 neutrality due to lower green hydrogen production costs. The research highlights that DACCU’s cost competitiveness is highly sensitive to electricity prices, fossil kerosene prices, policy support, and additional mitigation measures, and suggests a portfolio approach combining DAC with biofuels and other carbon dioxide removal (CDR) methods is essential for decarbonizing aviation.
metadata.categories: Environmental Research, Climate Change, Aviation, Carbon Capture Technology

metadata.title: Article 6 Compliance Markets Verra And S&P Global Unveil Next-Generation Carbon Registry
metadata.indicator: Verra and S&P Global Commodity Insights are launching a next-generation carbon registry that merges Verra’s project hub with S&P Global’s Environmental Registry software, enhancing traceability, automation, and compliance with Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. The system will enable seamless, transparent credit tracking and prevent double-counting through integration with the Meta Registry®, significantly improving market integrity and efficiency. The platform aims to support Africa’s high-integrity climate projects—such as mangrove restoration and forest protection—by providing credible, verifiable mechanisms to attract international buyers and ensure community benefits.
metadata.categories: Environmental Markets, Climate Finance, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: BECCS Capture American Biogas Council Launches Carbon Accounting Tool For Biogas Projects
metadata.indicator: The American Biogas Council (ABC), in collaboration with EcoEngineers, has launched the Biogas Carbon Accounting Tool (Biogas CAT), a specialized tool that enables biogas project developers to accurately measure full lifecycle emissions, addressing gaps in existing carbon accounting systems like GREET, which primarily focuses on transportation fuels and overlooks biogas’s broader environmental benefits. The tool supports voluntary carbon markets by providing reliable, project-specific emissions data, allowing companies to meet climate reporting obligations and fairly value biogas as a low-carbon energy source.
metadata.categories: Biogas, Carbon Accounting, Environmental Technology, Climate Change

metadata.title: Capture Storage Carbon Storage Growth Rate Questioned By Imperial College Study
metadata.indicator: A new study by Imperial College London challenges existing projections for the pace of carbon storage deployment, arguing that current estimates of 1–30 gigatonnes of CO2 per year by 2050 are unfeasible. Using a novel modeling approach that incorporates geological suitability, institutional capacity, and growth patterns from industries like mining and renewables, the researchers propose a more realistic target of 6–16 gigatonnes per year. The study highlights the lack of governmental and international support as a key barrier to scaling up carbon storage, and emphasizes the need for more grounded, data-driven projections to inform climate policy.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Storage, Environmental Research

metadata.title: Policy Removal Researchers Warn Of Legal Risks If We Rely Too Much On Carbon Removal
metadata.indicator: Researchers from the University of Oxford and Imperial College London warn that governments relying heavily on carbon dioxide removal (CDR) to meet climate targets may violate international law and face legal challenges, citing precedents like *Urgenda Foundation v. State of the Netherlands*. The study, published in *Science*, argues that overdependence on CDR—especially without substantial near-term emissions reductions—poses risks including leakage, overshooting climate goals, and land-use conflicts with agriculture, undermining commitments to "fair and ambitious" net-zero targets. It calls for urgent policy action to prioritize emissions cuts over future removals, warning that such reliance could become a focal point for climate litigation ahead of COP28.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Legal Risks, Carbon Removal, Environmental Law

metadata.title: Capture Cory And Imperial College London Join Forces To Advance Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: Cory Group is partnering with Imperial College London to advance carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, combining Cory’s industrial expertise in waste management and energy recovery with Imperial’s leading academic research in chemical engineering. The collaboration centers on Cory’s Riverside energy-from-waste site in London, where it aims to capture 1.4 million metric tons of CO₂ annually from two facilities, transporting the captured carbon by ship to the Port of Immingham for storage in depleted gas fields—a potential first in CO₂ shipping. The initiative leverages Imperial’s four-floor Carbon Capture Pilot Plant to provide hands-on training and promote STEM education, while also addressing workforce development and the UK’s low-carbon transition.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, Environmental Technology, Sustainability, Research and Development

metadata.title: Capture Peak Cluster Taps Arup For Largest Cement Decarbonization Scheme
metadata.indicator: Arup has been appointed as lead consultant for the Peak Cluster project, a large-scale decarbonization initiative targeting the UK’s cement and lime sector, which accounts for over 3 million metric tons of annual CO₂ emissions. The project will install carbon capture units at facilities operated by Tarmac, Buxton Lime, Breedon, and Holcim, with captured CO₂ transported via an underground pipeline to Spirit Energy’s Morecambe Net Zero (MNZ) project in the Irish Sea for permanent storage in depleted reservoirs. The initiative includes comprehensive environmental impact assessments and development consent processes, supported by investment from the UK National Wealth Fund and aimed at creating low-carbon cement products while preserving regional jobs and advancing industrial decarbonization.
metadata.categories: Decarbonization, Cement Industry, Carbon Capture

metadata.title: Capture DNV Skylark Project Targets Safer CO2 Pipelines Expansion For Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: DNV is leading the Skylark project, a three-year joint industry initiative aimed at improving the safety of carbon dioxide (CO2) pipelines as carbon capture and storage (CCS) networks expand globally. The project, developed in collaboration with the UK Health and Safety Executive, University of Arkansas, Ricardo, NCAS, and the UK Department for Energy Security and Net Zero, conducts full-scale pipeline failure tests and wind tunnel experiments to study CO2 dispersion and crater formation under varied conditions. Results will inform risk assessments, refine dispersion models, and support the development of regulatory frameworks to ensure safe, large-scale deployment of CO2 pipelines.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Climate Change

metadata.title: Capture Opinion: Net Zero By 2050 May Be Out Of Reach, But The World Must Still Face Up To Its Carbon Challenge
metadata.indicator: DNV’s Energy Transition Outlook 2025 warns that achieving net zero global emissions by 2050 is no longer feasible, with the world instead projected to reach net zero around 2090, resulting in a 2.2°C global temperature rise. The report attributes this delay to persistent emissions from fossil fuels, slow decarbonisation in hard-to-abate sectors like steel and cement, and insufficient scaling of carbon capture and storage (CCS) and carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies. While CCS and BECCS are expected to grow significantly—capturing up to 2.6 GtCO₂ annually by 2060—these efforts will still fall short of offsetting emissions, and CDR technologies like direct air capture remain expensive and limited, at USD 350 per tonne by 2060.
metadata.categories: Energy Transition, Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Capture DNV And Shipbuilding Giants To Develop Onboard Carbon Capture Tech
metadata.indicator: DNV has partnered with HD Korea Shipbuilding and Offshore Engineering (HD KSOE) and HD Hydrogen to develop and validate Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) technology for carbon capture in marine environments, specifically integrating it with Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC). The joint effort, part of a Joint Industry Project (JIP), targets a 40% improvement in energy efficiency over traditional marine CO₂ absorption systems and aims to support maritime decarbonization by enabling onboard carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). This initiative responds to global emissions regulations and leverages the efficiency of SOFCs, which can operate on natural gas, ammonia, or hydrogen, to reduce carbon emissions in shipping operations.
metadata.categories: Maritime Industry, Carbon Capture Technology, Climate Change

metadata.title: DNV: Carbon Capture Hits Inflection Point, Set To Quadruple By 2030
metadata.indicator: Global carbon capture and storage (CCS) is entering a critical growth phase, with DNV forecasting a fourfold increase in capture and storage capacity by 2030 and an annual global capture volume rising from 41 million to 1.3 billion metric tons by 2050—equivalent to 6% of global emissions. The expansion is being driven primarily by North America and Europe, with natural gas processing as the current dominant application, while long-term deployment will be essential for decarbonizing hard-to-abate industries like steel and cement, which are expected to account for 41% of total captured CO2 by 2050. Onboard carbon capture in shipping is projected to begin in the 2040s, and technologies like bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) are expected to dominate due to cost efficiency, while direct air capture (DAC), despite higher costs of $350 per ton, will contribute 84 million tons annually by 2050 through compliance and voluntary markets.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy Transition, Environmental Technologies

metadata.title: Capture DNV Inspection To Oversee Quality For Two Pioneering UK CCS Projects
metadata.indicator: DNV Inspection has been appointed to provide quality assurance, site inspections, and on-the-ground support for two pioneering UK carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects: Net Zero Teesside Power (NZT Power) and the Northern Endurance Partnership (NEP). The contracts cover verification of equipment and materials against strict industry standards as the projects transition from construction to operation, with NZT Power aiming to become the world’s first gas-fired power station with integrated carbon capture, delivering up to 742 megawatts of low-carbon electricity. NEP, a joint venture between bp, Equinor, and TotalEnergies, is developing offshore pipelines and facilities to transport captured CO2 from Teesside and Humber to North Sea storage sites.
metadata.categories: Energy Transition, Carbon Capture and Storage, UK Energy Infrastructure

metadata.title: Opinion: Crunch Time In The UK’s Quest To Collar Its Carbon Emissions
metadata.indicator: The UK is advancing its carbon capture, utilisation, and storage (CCUS) initiatives, with key projects like the Northern Endurance Partnership and Net Zero Teesside Power securing final investment decisions, but current capacity is far below target—projected at just 5 MtCO2/year by 2030 versus a government goal of 20–30 MtCO2/year. Delays in Track 1 cluster developments and inconsistent policy support have undermined progress, while carbon prices remain low, with emissions from fossil fuels still cheaper than capture costs until the mid-2030s. Despite £21.7 billion in government funding and a growing pipeline, the sector faces significant implementation gaps, risking missed carbon budgets and failure to meet its 2050 net-zero pledge.
metadata.categories: Energy Transition, Carbon Capture and Storage, UK Climate Policy, Renewable Energy

metadata.title: The Vita Group Receives Outstanding Platinum EcoVadis Rating
metadata.indicator: The Vita Group, a UK-based foam manufacturer, has earned a platinum EcoVadis sustainability rating, scoring 83 out of 100 and ranking in the top 1% of global companies assessed by the benchmarking platform. This recognition is based on evaluations across environmental, labor, ethical, and procurement practices, with a key innovation being its Orbis sustainable foam, which uses recycled raw materials from end-of-life foams to achieve a closed-loop circular model in flexible polyurethane production. The company has also developed a custom Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) tool to enhance supply chain transparency and align supplier performance with sustainability goals.
metadata.categories: Technology, Sustainability, EcoVadis, Corporate Social Responsibility

metadata.title: Companies Sublime Systems Taps Industry Veteran Rob Davies As CEO To Lead Commercial Expansion
metadata.indicator: Sublime Systems, a Massachusetts-based startup developing low-carbon cement through electrochemical technology, has appointed Rob Davies, a veteran with 30+ years in industrial manufacturing and cement operations, as its new CEO to drive commercial expansion. Davies, formerly of Blue Circle, Lafarge, and Holcim, joins from a role as Chief Operating Officer and brings extensive experience in scaling industrial technologies, while co-founder Dr. Leah Ellis remains involved to support the transition. The company has secured a multi-year deal with Microsoft for up to 622,500 metric tons of Sublime Cement® and received $75 million in funding from global cement giants Holcim and CRH to advance pilot production and plant expansion.
metadata.categories: Industry Leadership, Construction Materials, Low-Carbon Technology

metadata.title: Companies Markets Removal Developing Countries Call On SBTi To Push For Companies To Be Able To Use Carbon Offsets
metadata.indicator: A group of 10 West African countries, including Burkina Faso, Senegal, and Ghana, has urged the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBTi) to allow corporations to use carbon offsets—particularly for Scope 3 emissions—to meet their net-zero goals, arguing that such mechanisms are essential for financing climate and conservation initiatives in developing nations. The request comes amid growing debate over the credibility and transparency of carbon offset projects, with the UN Secretary-General warning against "dubious carbon offsets" that fail to deliver real climate benefits. SBTi has acknowledged the possibility of allowing offsets under strict rules, but experts emphasize the need for scientific validation and clear accountability to prevent greenwashing and ensure that offset projects genuinely contribute to emission reductions.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Environmental Policy, Sustainability

metadata.title: Companies Ocean Removal Equatic Gears Up For Gigaton CO2 Removal Scale With New Leadership
metadata.indicator: Ocean-based carbon removal company Equatic is scaling up to achieve gigaton-level CO2 removal by appointing Edward Sanders as CEO and Jarred W. Guthrie as Chief Project Officer, with Sanders bringing experience in climate and commercial operations and Guthrie expertise in renewable energy and hydrogen projects. The company is reinforcing its technical and strategic oversight with the addition of Dame Dervilla Mitchell to its Industry Advisory Board and establishing a first-ever Science Advisory Board of eight academic and public sector experts to ensure responsible and high-quality carbon removal. Equatic aims to deliver the world’s largest ocean-based CO2 removal plant, targeting cost-effective carbon removal at under $30 per tonne by the end of the decade.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Removal, Ocean Technology, Renewable Energy

metadata.title: Aon Unveils Industry-First Insurance For Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: Aon has launched the industry's first international insurance product tailored for carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects, addressing key financial and operational risks associated with transporting and storing CO₂. The policy, developed over 18 months with collaboration from leading underwriters and legal experts, provides comprehensive coverage across construction, asset repurposing, and operational phases of CCS projects. The product supports major energy players like Eni UK, bp, Equinor, and TotalEnergies through the HyNet North West and Northern Endurance Partnership initiatives, helping to de-risk investment and promote net-zero ambitions in energy and industrial sectors.
metadata.categories: Environmental, Insurance, Energy

metadata.title: Markets Removal Uncategorized Swiss Re And Goodcarbon Introduce Pioneering Insurance For Carbon Credit Investments
metadata.indicator: Swiss Re and goodcarbon have launched a first-of-its-kind insurance product for 5-year forward carbon credit portfolios, offering “in-kind replacements” or refunds to investors if carbon credits fail to deliver promised emissions reductions. The insurance covers non-delivery risks from political instability, natural catastrophes, and weather events, with initial focus on afforestation and reforestation projects. By pooling a small percentage of credits into a buffer mechanism and providing refunds if the buffer is insufficient, the product enhances investor confidence and addresses key market risks in nature-based carbon removal.
metadata.categories: Finance, Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Insurance

metadata.title: Capture Companies Press Release Aker Carbon Capture Secures Pre-FEED Contract From Statkraft
metadata.indicator: Aker Carbon Capture has secured a pre-FEED contract with Statkraft to implement carbon capture at the Heimdal waste-to-energy facility in Trondheim, Norway, targeting the capture of approximately 220,000 tons of CO2 annually—potentially reducing Trondheim’s CO2 emissions by 25%. The project will involve full engineering design for carbon dioxide compression, purification, liquefaction, temporary storage, and potential transportation to permanent geological storage. This collaboration marks a significant advancement in integrating carbon capture into waste-to-energy operations, supporting Norway’s goal of a 55% emissions reduction by 2030 and demonstrating a scalable model for decarbonizing industrial sectors.
metadata.categories: Environment, Climate Change, Renewable Energy, Carbon Capture

metadata.title: Capture Companies Investment Captura Gets Two New Investors, Reaches $45.3M In Series A Funding
metadata.indicator: Direct ocean capture (DOC) startup Captura has secured $45.3 million in Series A funding, with new investors National Grid Partners and Japan Airlines Innovation Fund joining existing backers. The company’s technology directly extracts carbon dioxide from seawater, leveraging the ocean’s natural carbon absorption capacity without adding chemicals or by-products, offering a cost-effective and environmentally sustainable approach to carbon removal. With two operational pilot plants in California and a planned facility in Norway in partnership with Equinor, Captura aims to remove tens of thousands of tons of CO2 annually, with potential for CO2 reuse in low-carbon fuel production to support hard-to-abate sectors like aviation and shipping.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Heidelberg Materials Announces Milestone With The Edmonton Carbon Capture Project
metadata.indicator: Heidelberg Materials North America has awarded front-end engineering design (FEED) contracts to MHI-LCSC (a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries) and Kiewit for the development of carbon capture technology at its Edmonton, Alberta CCUS project, marking a key milestone toward deploying the world’s first full-scale net-zero cement plant. The project will utilize MHI’s Advanced KM CDR Process™ with the KS-21™ solvent, designed in collaboration with Kansai Electric Power Co., Inc., to capture and store up to 1 million metric tons of CO₂ annually—equivalent to removing 220,000 cars from roads. The initiative represents a pioneering effort in the cement industry to achieve carbon neutrality through carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), with a final investment decision expected in 2024 pending federal and provincial funding agreements.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Sustainable Industry

metadata.title: Capture Companies Exterra, Énergir Join Forces To Advance Carbon Sequestration In Quebec
metadata.indicator: Exterra Carbon Solutions, a Quebec-based startup, has formed a strategic partnership with Énergir Development to advance carbon capture and sequestration efforts, leveraging Exterra’s innovative technology that uses mining residues to store carbon dioxide (CO2). The collaboration aims to develop decarbonization solutions for high-emission industries like aluminum smelters and cement factories, with a pilot project currently sequestering 300 tons of CO2 annually and targeting a 3,000-ton pre-commercial demonstration plant by 2025. By 2026, Exterra plans to launch Hub 1, the world’s largest surface-based CO2 sequestration site, capable of removing emissions equivalent to 100,000 gasoline vehicles annually.
metadata.categories: Environmental Technology, Carbon Capture and Sequestration, Renewable Energy, Industrial Decarbonization

metadata.title: Companies Markets Removal ClimateHQ Releases Its First Report Revealing Key Corporate Climate Action Data by Petya Trendafilova
metadata.indicator: ClimateHQ, a new market intelligence startup, has released its first report analyzing corporate climate action data for 100 U.S. Fortune 100 companies with revenues exceeding $11 trillion, examining their sustainability reports, net zero targets, and voluntary carbon market activities. The report reveals that only 33 of the 100 companies have set a net zero target, with 11 having pending SBTI commitments, and highlights a stark disparity in financial performance per ton of CO2 emitted—commercial banks and financials earn $39,942 per ton, while oil, mining, and refining sectors earn just $329 per ton. The analysis leverages over one million data points across 99 reports and covers more than 50,000 companies and 20,000 sustainability reports, offering a comprehensive view of corporate climate commitments and emissions transparency.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Corporate Sustainability, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: Carbon Accounting Companies Watershed Introduces Specialized Software For EU CSRD Reporting
metadata.indicator: Enterprise climate software platform Watershed has launched Watershed for CSRD, a specialized software solution designed to help companies comply with the European Union’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which mandates comprehensive ESG disclosures and aligns sustainability data with financial reporting standards. The tool enables organizations to collect, calculate, and manage over 1,100 ESG data points, identify reporting gaps, and ensure audit readiness, while integrating with frameworks like CDP and TCFD. It is already deployed in leading global firms and supports the upcoming 2024–2025 CSRD reporting wave, marking a key development in standardized, transparent, and leadership-driven ESG reporting.
metadata.categories: Sustainability, Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG), Climate Reporting

metadata.title: Artio Secures $709,000 To Revolutionize Early-Stage Carbon Insurance
metadata.indicator: Climate insurtech startup Artio has raised £550k (~$709k) to develop insurance products for early-stage carbon removal projects using a proprietary risk modelling platform, addressing the delivery and financing risks that prevent investment in these high-potential but uncertain projects. The funding, led by Lifetime Ventures and co-invested by SFC Capital, will accelerate product development and support the launch of its first carbon removal insurance products in early 2025, in partnership with Lloyd’s Lab. By providing risk mitigation from day one, Artio aims to boost investor confidence and scale high-integrity carbon credits essential for net-zero commitments.
metadata.categories: Climate Tech, Insurance, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: Biomass Direct Air Capture Mineralization Removal Startups Remove Announces New Cohort Of CDR Startups For Its Europe Accelerator Program
metadata.startup: https://www.remove.com; https://www.artio.com; https://www.atmosfuture.com; https://www.bloomineral.com; https://www.kumo.com; https://www.neo-fossil.com; https://www.ninaenergy.com; https://www.octavia-carbon.com; https://www.superdac.com
metadata.indicator: remove has launched Cohort 7 of its Europe Accelerator Program, selecting eight carbon dioxide removal (CDR) startups—including Octavia Carbon, Atmosfuture, SuperDAC, Bloomineral, and neo-fossil—to receive mentorship and operational guidance over five months. The cohort spans direct air capture (DAC), carbon mineralization, biochar, climate fintech, and insurance, with innovations such as Atmosfuture’s Reverse Fractionation of Carbon Capture (REVFRACC) using liquid nitrogen to liquefy and repurpose CO2 and nitrogen, and Octavia Carbon building the first DAC facility in the Global South in Kenya. Selected startups will receive expertise in policy, life cycle assessment, fundraising, and IP management, with a focus on scaling CDR technologies in Europe and beyond.
metadata.categories: Carbon Dioxide Removal, Direct Air Capture, Carbon Mineralization, Climate Tech, Accelerator Programs

metadata.title: Markets Artio Launches Carbon Insurance With Lloyd’s Coverholder Status
metadata.indicator: Artio, a carbon project insurance firm founded by Bilal Hussain and Ibrahim Sarwar, has been granted Lloyd’s coverholder status, enabling it to issue insurance policies for early-phase carbon projects before any activities begin. Backed by major insurers including Tokio Marine HCC, Markel, and Apollo, Artio offers a data-driven risk assessment model that evaluates financial, climatic, political, and technical risks to underwrite projects at inception, addressing a critical gap in the carbon market. The company currently insures afforestation, reforestation, and biochar projects and plans to expand into direct air capture and enhanced rock weathering in 2025.
metadata.categories: Finance, Climate Change, Insurance, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: Markets Removal Gold Standard Releases Framework For High-Integrity Engineered Carbon Removals
metadata.indicator: Gold Standard has released the Engineered Removals Activity Requirements, a new framework to certify high-integrity carbon dioxide removal (CDR) projects through rigorous scientific and stakeholder validation. The framework mandates safeguards for sustainable development, buffer contributions, and reversal risk mitigation, and aligns with international standards including the EU Carbon Removal Certification Framework, CORSIA, and Article 6.4 of the Paris Agreement. It supports projects such as accelerated carbonation of concrete aggregate, carbon mineralisation using reactive mineral waste, and biomass fermentation with carbon capture and geologic storage, with at least three Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) required per project.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Removal, Voluntary Carbon Market

metadata.title: Markets Removal Gold Standard Hosts Webinar On New Nature Responsibility Framework
metadata.indicator: Gold Standard has launched a new Nature Responsibility Framework to help companies integrate biodiversity and ecosystem stewardship into their core operations, offering guidance on minimizing environmental harm, delivering place-based benefits, and ensuring credible reporting of nature-related actions. The framework supports corporate decision-making by promoting best practices in claims-making and communication, and will be further explained in a free webinar on September 4, 2025, featuring experts from Gold Standard and external organizations including Shared Planet, Barry Callebaut, and Fauna & Flora.
metadata.categories: Carbon Market, Nature Responsibility, Corporate Responsibility, Environmental Framework

metadata.title: Markets Removal ICVCM Approves Six New Carbon Removal Methodologies
metadata.indicator: The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) has approved six engineered carbon dioxide removal (CDR) methodologies, including Gold Standard’s Accelerated Carbonation of Concrete Aggregate and Isometric’s Biomass Geological Storage, Bio-oil Geological Storage, Subsurface Biomass Carbon Removal, Biogenic Carbon Capture and Storage, and Direct Air Capture. These methodologies now qualify for CCP-labelled credits, with Isometric’s frameworks already supporting 24 registered projects and potential annual issuance of over 3.2 million credits, while Gold Standard’s approach could generate more than 9,000 credits annually. Additionally, two land-based methods—CAR Mexico Forest Protocol v3 and VM0047 v1.1—received full approval, expanding eligibility for forest and reforestation projects with potential for nearly 10 million annual credits.
metadata.categories: Carbon Removal, Climate Policy, Voluntary Carbon Market

metadata.title: Markets Ecuador Partners With Gold Standard To Advance National Carbon Offset Program
metadata.indicator: Ecuador has formalized a partnership with Gold Standard to advance its national carbon offset program, PECC (Ecuador Carbono Cero – PECC), through a two-year Memorandum of Understanding signed by the Ministry of Environment, Water, and Ecological Transition (MAATE). The collaboration aims to establish credible carbon offset standards, address procedural gaps, develop certification protocols, and build local auditor capacity, all aligned with international best practices and the Paris Agreement. The partnership strengthens Ecuador’s Zero Carbon Program by integrating transparent, internationally recognized verification mechanisms into its climate strategy.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Offset, International Collaboration

metadata.title: Markets Xpansiv Introduces Spot Contract to Boost CORSIA Trading
metadata.indicator: Xpansiv has launched the CBL GEO® CORSIA Phase 1 (GEO CP1) standardized spot contract, enabling trading of CORSIA-eligible emissions units (EEUs) on its CBL Spot Exchange and through affiliated platforms including the Aviation Carbon Exchange (ACE) and the JSE Ventures Carbon Market. The contract aligns with ICAO’s CORSIA compliance framework and offers standardized, transparent access to EEUs from registries such as ART TREES, ACR, Climate Action Reserve, Gold Standard, and Verra, with an innovative sub-account system allowing participants to trade without requiring primary registry accounts. The launch follows ICAO’s approval of new methodologies and responds to market demand for 100–150 million tons of EEUs in the first compliance phase (2024–2026), while addressing procedural delays in issuing Letters of Authorization that have previously hampered compliance.
metadata.categories: Carbon Markets, Climate Neutrality, Energy Transition

metadata.title: Markets Nonprofits Urge EU To Include International Flights Emissions In Carbon Market
metadata.indicator: Two major climate nonprofits, Opportunity Green and Carbon Market Watch, are urging the European Union to include international flight emissions in its Emissions Trading System (ETS), ending a 2012 exemption that allowed over 1.1 billion tonnes of CO2—equivalent to more than Greece’s total emissions—to go unregulated. They argue that the current global aviation offset mechanism, CORSIA, is ineffective and that the EU must act decisively during its 2026 ETS review to reclaim climate leadership and put a price on aviation pollution. The nonprofits highlight that this exemption resulted in $30 billion in lost climate revenue and warn against succumbing to pressure from the U.S. and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), which they say failed to act for over three decades.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, European Union, Aviation, Emissions Trading System

metadata.title: Markets Removal Vietnam To Join Global Aviation Carbon Offset Scheme By 2026
metadata.indicator: Vietnam will join the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) beginning January 1, 2026, marking its commitment to achieving carbon-neutral growth in international aviation through market-based mechanisms. The Civil Aviation Authority of Vietnam (CAAV) has submitted a formal proposal to the Ministry of Construction and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), having already implemented a Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (MRV) system for aviation CO2 emissions and established regulations for fuel use and emissions tracking. Vietnam’s participation aligns with its broader climate goals and signals readiness for the mandatory CORSIA phase beginning in 2027, with annual carbon offset expenditures estimated between USD 5.6 million and USD 37.5 million.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Aviation, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Markets Removal Isometric Receives Landmark ICAO Approval To Issue Credits Under CORSIA
metadata.indicator: Isometric, a carbon registry, has received landmark approval from the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) to issue carbon dioxide removal credits under the CORSIA framework, a globally mandated program requiring airlines to offset emissions above 2019 levels. The approval recognizes Isometric’s adherence to high standards of transparency, integrity, and scientific rigor, making it one of a select group of registries authorized to issue verified carbon removal credits. This milestone enables airlines to access credible, science-based carbon removals, with British Airways highlighting its role as the largest global buyer of such credits and planning for a third of its future emissions reductions to come from removals.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Carbon Markets, Aviation

metadata.title: Markets Voluntary TEM’s Papua New Guinea Cookstove Project First To Earn Credits Under Verra’s VM0050
metadata.indicator: Tasman Environmental Markets (TEM) has achieved a landmark milestone by becoming the first organization to issue Verified Carbon Units (VCUs) under Verra’s VM0050 methodology in Papua New Guinea, where its "Healthier Homes, Healthier Forests" cookstove project delivers improved cookstoves to households in the Southern Highlands at no cost. The project reduces indoor air pollution, decreases firewood consumption, and prevents nearly 3 million tonnes of CO2 emissions over ten years, while also supporting deforestation reduction and community health. The initiative, supported by local governments and PNG’s Climate Change and Development Authority, aims to distribute 200,000 stoves to reach 50,000 households by 2026, aligning with PNG’s Nationally Determined Contribution and delivering co-benefits in social and economic development.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Credits, Renewable Energy, Community Projects

metadata.title: Markets New Study Suggests Carbon Credits From Cookstoves Are Worthless
metadata.indicator: A peer-reviewed study by UC Berkeley researchers reveals that cookstove-based carbon credits in the voluntary carbon market (VCM) are significantly overstated, with emissions avoided being 9.2 times lower than claimed—despite representing 20% of all VCM credits. The study scrutinized 40% of these cookstove projects and found systemic flaws in emission measurement, raising concerns about the credibility of carbon offsetting in the sector. While major registries like Verra and Gold Standard have responded with criticism and plans to improve methodologies, the findings have prompted major buyers—including British Airways and easyJet—to pause or halt purchases, underscoring the market’s growing instability.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Article 6 Markets Zimbabwe Breaks Ground With Carbon Credits With Corresponding Adjustments Under Article 6
metadata.indicator: Zimbabwe has launched the first private-sector-generated Article 6 carbon credits with Corresponding Adjustments (CAs) through the Gold Standard registry, driven by a clean cookstove project led by Cicada Carbon, a member of the Zimbabwe Carbon Association. The project generated 112,000 CAs, with up to 3 million projected over five years, marking a global first in private-sector CAs and positioning Zimbabwe to access international compliance markets like CORSIA. The CA mechanism ensures no double-counting of emissions reductions, and if approved, the project could become only the second globally to meet CORSIA eligibility, following Guyana’s REDD+ initiative.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Markets Removal Aviation Industry Turns To CDR In Race To Net Zero By 2050
metadata.indicator: The aviation industry is increasingly turning to carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, particularly direct air capture (DAC), to address residual emissions in its path to net zero by 2050, with IATA’s new 2025 guide outlining the role of DAC and other CDR methods like bio-based and enhanced rock weathering solutions. The guide, co-developed with Climeworks, highlights how captured CO₂ can be used in power-to-liquid (PtL) fuel production and emphasizes the growing market for CDR credits, including their certification and trading mechanisms. Despite challenges around scalability, cost, and regulatory alignment, the report signals a rising trend in market activity and calls for coordinated efforts across airlines, technology providers, financiers, and regulators to advance CDR adoption.
metadata.categories: Aviation, Carbon Removal, Climate Change, Sustainable Aviation

metadata.title: Capture Storage CATF Roadmap Charts Cost-Effective CCS Deployment For Central and Eastern Europe
metadata.indicator: A new policy brief by the Clean Air Task Force (CATF) outlines a strategic roadmap for reducing the cost of carbon capture and storage (CCS) deployment in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) through coordinated government action, including alignment of capture, transport, and storage planning, blending EU and national funding mechanisms, and supporting early-stage projects. The report highlights that developing regional CO2 storage could cut transport and storage costs by up to 48%, and avoid annual subsidies of up to €23.5 million for a 500,000-metric-ton CO2 project without domestic storage. CATF recommends that CEE governments prioritize policy clarity, permitting efficiency, and revenue certainty to de-risk CCS investment and ensure industrial decarbonization without sacrificing competitiveness or jobs.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Storage, European Energy, Industrial Decarbonization

metadata.title: Capture Companies Technip Energies To Direct FEED Phase For Viking CCS Project
metadata.indicator: Technip Energies has been appointed to lead the front-end engineering design (FEED) phase for the Viking Link CCS project in the UK, responsible for designing the CO2 transportation system. This marks a critical step toward a final investment decision in Q1 2025, with the project aiming to capture and store 10 million tonnes of CO2 annually by 2030—equivalent to one-third of the UK’s overall CCS target. The initiative, led by Harbour Energy and BP, will transport CO2 from the Humber region to depleted Viking gas fields, with a total storage capacity of 300 million tonnes and potential to generate £7 billion in investment and £4 billion in gross value added to the local economy.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy, UK, Climate Change

metadata.title: Capture Policy Storage Utilization Malaysia Enacts CCUS Act 2025 With Royal Endorsement
metadata.indicator: Malaysia has enacted the Carbon Capture, Utilization and Storage (CCUS) Act 2025 with royal assent, establishing a comprehensive legal framework for the capture, transport, reuse, and long-term storage of carbon dioxide. The legislation aims to mitigate climate change impacts while promoting the development of Malaysia’s carbon management sector as a catalyst for economic growth. The law was approved during the First Meeting of the Fourth Session of the 15th Parliament and formally announced with endorsement from Sultan Ibrahim.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Climate Change, Legislation, Malaysia

metadata.title: Capture Storage Petronas CEO Sees Carbon Capture As Future Revenue Stream
metadata.indicator: Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned energy company, is positioning carbon capture and storage (CCS) as a future revenue stream, with CEO Tengku Muhammad Taufik Tengku Aziz highlighting the company's efforts to advance low-carbon technologies. The firm is also preparing Malaysia to handle liquefied natural gas imports, while the government has introduced a CCUS Bill to establish a competitive levy and support carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) infrastructure. The bill, set for a second reading in Parliament, marks a significant step toward Malaysia's leadership in low-carbon energy solutions.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Malaysia

metadata.title: Capture Energy Can Carbon Capture Clean Up Natural Gas For The Data Center Boom?
metadata.indicator: A new whitepaper by Carbon Direct proposes natural gas with carbon capture and storage (CCS) as a cost-competitive, rapidly deployable solution to meet the surging electricity demand of U.S. data centers, with captured CO₂ being stored in geologic formations. The model offers a “capture-commited” approach—delivering clean power within 18 months, followed by full decarbonization within 18–24 months—enabling rapid deployment without sacrificing emissions goals. At $70–$100 per MWh, CCS for natural gas competes with new nuclear, and retrofitting existing plants could reduce costs to $40–$60/MWh, leveraging existing infrastructure and federal incentives like the Inflation Reduction Act’s 45Q tax credit. However, the strategy is highly policy-dependent, with risks of increased costs and project delays if key incentives like 45Q are repealed, and a growing capability gap among utilities and corporate buyers limits in-house development.
metadata.categories: Energy, Decarbonization, Natural Gas, Carbon Capture and Storage, Data Centers

metadata.title: Capture Policy Singapore Backs Carbon Capture To Cut Power Sector Emissions
metadata.indicator: Singapore’s Energy Market Authority (EMA) has awarded co-funding to five feasibility studies on carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, selected from three local power companies—Keppel, PacificLight Power, and YTL PowerSeraya. The projects explore two CCS approaches: post-combustion capture at natural gas power plants and pre-combustion capture during hydrogen production, both aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions from power generation. The initiative, launched in October 2024 with a completion target of 2026, will assess technical viability, infrastructure needs, and site-specific requirements to support future large-scale deployment.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy Innovation, Singapore

metadata.title: UAE Researchers Turn Used Coffee Grounds Into Carbon Capture Material
metadata.indicator: Researchers at the University of Sharjah in the UAE have developed a patented carbon capture technology that transforms spent coffee grounds and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic waste into a high-surface-area activated carbon using potassium hydroxide as an activating agent. The process, involving co-pyrolysis of coffee and plastic waste, produces a porous material capable of efficiently adsorbing carbon dioxide from industrial flue gases, offering a low-cost, circular economy solution that tackles both waste management and carbon emissions.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Capture, Waste Management, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture Energy Storage Carbon TerraVault And Net Power Partner For 1GW Natural Gas California Project With Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: California Resources Corporation and Carbon TerraVault have entered a partnership with Net Power Inc. to develop up to 1 GW of ultra-low emission natural gas power plants in Northern California, leveraging Net Power’s modular, near-zero-emission power technology and CTV’s existing underground carbon storage vaults for permanent CO₂ sequestration. The collaboration aims to reduce transportation and midstream costs by siting the plants near CTV’s storage reservoirs, with the potential to capture up to 3.6 MMTPA of CO₂ annually and support 2.1 GW of new low-carbon power capacity in the state.
metadata.categories: Energy Storage, Carbon Capture, Natural Gas, Power Generation, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture Fuels BASF And Forestal Pave Way For E-Methanol Via CO2 Capture
metadata.indicator: BASF and Spanish chemicals company Forestal del Atlántico have launched an early disclosure agreement to develop a pilot-scale e-methanol production facility in Galicia, Spain, using BASF’s OASE blue gas technology to capture carbon dioxide from flue gases. The captured CO2 will be converted into e-methanol through reaction with renewable hydrogen, with the Triskelion project targeting 156 metric tons of e-methanol per day, scalable to 40,000 tons annually. The project, expected to begin operations in January 2028, will support front-end engineering design and assess both technical and economic viability of sustainable fuel production.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture, Sustainable Fuels, Chemicals

metadata.title: Capture Markets Houston-Based CO2 Energy Transition Goes Public With $69M IPO
metadata.indicator: Houston-based CO2 Energy Transition Corp. (Nasdaq: NOEM), a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), has completed its $69 million IPO by raising funds through the sale of 6 million units at $10 each, with an additional 900,000 units exercised under the underwriter’s over-allotment option. The SPAC aims to acquire or merge with mid-sized carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) companies valued between $150 million and $250 million, targeting the growing market for carbon reduction technologies. The offering includes warrants and contingent share rights, and the company highlights bipartisan support for CCUS legislation, positioning itself at the intersection of climate policy and emerging clean energy solutions.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, SPAC, Energy Transition, Sustainable Energy

metadata.title: Markets Removal BlueLayer To Provide dMRV & Project Data Infrastructure For Puro.earth
metadata.indicator: BlueLayer has partnered with Puro.earth to integrate its digital monitoring, reporting, and verification (dMRV) platform into Puro.earth’s carbon dioxide removal (CDR) credit infrastructure, enabling CDR suppliers to streamline and automate data collection, verification, and credit issuance across project lifecycles. The platform centralizes machine, sensor, and operational data, offering standardized, methodology-specific templates that enhance data accuracy and accelerate verification for buyers and investors. This collaboration aims to improve transparency, efficiency, and trust in the carbon market by providing a scalable, digital dMRV solution for CDR project developers.
metadata.categories: Carbon Markets, Digital Monitoring and Verification, Carbon Removal

metadata.title: Article 6 Markets Singapore Teams With Mongolia For 10th Bilateral Carbon Credit Deal
metadata.indicator: Singapore and Mongolia have signed a legally binding Article 6 carbon credit agreement, marking Singapore’s 10th such deal under the Paris Agreement’s framework, with the agreement enabling high-integrity carbon credit transfers for emission offsetting in both countries. The deal includes a 2% cancellation of initially issued credits to ensure they are not counted toward national targets, and a commitment to allocate 5% of credit value to climate adaptation efforts in Mongolia, supporting local development, job creation, and pollution reduction. The agreement expands Singapore’s International Carbon Credits (ICC) portfolio and strengthens bilateral cooperation in climate action, aligning with global efforts to build a transparent and verifiable carbon market under Article 6.4.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Credits, International Cooperation

metadata.title: Markets Carbon Market Watchdog ICVCM Sets Up First Physical Hub In Singapore
metadata.indicator: The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) has established its first physical office in Singapore, marking a significant step in enhancing oversight and credibility for Asia’s emerging carbon markets. The regional hub, co-developed with Singapore’s Economic Development Board, will focus on evaluating carbon credit methodologies aligned with regional priorities such as coal power retirement and peatland restoration, using its ten science-based Core Carbon Principles (CCPs) that emphasize environmental integrity and human rights, especially Indigenous rights. The office supports regional carbon market development by working with governments and domestic programs and strengthens alignment with Article 6 of the Paris Agreement and multilateral initiatives like the Coalition to Grow Carbon Markets.
metadata.categories: Carbon Market, Environmental Policy, Asia-Pacific

metadata.title: Markets Policy Pennsylvania Governor Wants To Create Independent Cap-and-trade Program
metadata.indicator: Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro has announced plans to withdraw the state from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) and establish an independent cap-and-trade program known as the Pennsylvania Climate Emissions Reduction Initiative (PACER). The new program would impose a carbon fee on energy industry emissions, with 70% of revenues redirected to electricity bill rebates and the remainder allocated to low-income support, energy efficiency, renewable energy, and carbon capture for existing natural gas plants. This move follows a 2023 working group recommendation and responds to a prior Commonwealth Court ruling that challenged RGGI’s constitutionality, with Shapiro’s office appealing the decision.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Climate Change, Energy

metadata.title: Farming Removal Groundwork BioAg And Anew Climate To Commercialize 500,000 Tons Of Soil CDR Credits
metadata.indicator: Groundwork BioAg, a soil carbon removal company, has partnered with Anew Climate to commercialize 500,000 tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e) credits through its Rootella Carbon® program, which uses mycorrhizal fungi to sequester carbon in agricultural soils. The program, verified by SCS Global, reports an average of 3.89 tCO2e per acre over one year from 9,000 acres and offers farmers up to 70% of net credit sales, creating a new revenue stream tied to soil health and climate mitigation. The initiative aligns with Verra’s VM0042 methodology and aims to scale carbon removal across 270 million acres of reduced-tillage farmland in the U.S., Canada, and Brazil, enhancing farm resilience, water retention, and biodiversity.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Soil Carbon Removal, Carbon Credits, Sustainable Agriculture

metadata.title: Farming Removal Key Carbon & InSoil Launch $114M Partnership To Accelerate Regenerative Agriculture In Europe
metadata.indicator: Key Carbon, a Vancouver-based climate-focused private equity firm, has launched a $114 million partnership with InSoil, a Lithuania-based regenerative agriculture technology company, to accelerate soil-based carbon removal across Europe. The funding supports InSoil’s zero-interest Green Loans to small and medium-sized farms, with an additional $4.2 million allocated to expand operations across 2.5 million acres by 2026, enabling the sequestration of over 35 million tons of CO2. The initiative leverages InSoil’s lab-grade soil sampling, remote sensing, and MRV (Measurement, Reporting, and Verification) platform to deliver transparent, science-backed carbon credits aligned with the EU Carbon Removals Certification Framework.
metadata.categories: Climate Finance, Regenerative Agriculture, Carbon Markets, Sustainable Farming

metadata.title: Markets Policy COP30 Leaders Summit Puts Sustainable Fuels And Carbon Markets In Focus
metadata.indicator: At the COP30 Leaders Summit in Belém, Brazil, 19 countries including India and Japan pledged to quadruple sustainable fuel use by 2035 through the Belém 4X Pledge, targeting biofuels, biogas, hydrogen, and e-fuels across transport and industry. A new Open Coalition on Compliance Carbon Markets was launched by the EU, UK, China, Canada, and Brazil to harmonize carbon market rules, align reporting standards, and explore border carbon adjustments. Additionally, a $5.5 billion Tropical Forests Forever Facility was established to incentivize tropical forest conservation through annual payments of at least $4 per hectare, with private sector involvement and bond-style funding mechanisms.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Sustainable Fuels, Carbon Markets, Forest Protection

A new Open Coalition on Compliance Carbon Markets was launched by the EU, UK, China, Canada, and Brazil to harmonize carbon market rules, align reporting standards, and explore border carbon adjustments. **Summary (Indicator):**
At the COP30 Leaders Summit in Belém, Brazil, 19 countries including India and Japan pledged to quadruple sustainable fuel use by 2035 through the Belém 4X Pledge, targeting biofuels, biogas, hydrogen, and e-fuels across transport and industry. A new Open Coalition on Compliance Carbon Markets was launched by the EU, UK, China, Canada, and Brazil to harmonize carbon market rules, align reporting standards, and explore border carbon adjustments. Additionally, a $5.5 billion Tropical Forests Forever Facility was established to incentivize tropical forest conservation through annual payments of at least $4 per hectare, with private sector involvement and bond-style funding mechanisms.

metadata.title: Capture Pennsylvania’s Path To Industrial Decarbonization: A Focus On Steel With Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: Pennsylvania is advancing a strategic industrial decarbonization plan centered on the steel sector, leveraging carbon capture and storage (CCS) as an interim solution to reduce emissions from legacy facilities like US Steel’s Edgar Thomson plant and Cleveland-Cliffs’ furnace electrification pilot. The state is developing a tailored "CCS ladder" framework, capitalizing on the geographic proximity of steel, glass, and cement facilities to potential storage sites under the CarbonSAFE program, particularly in the Pittsburgh region. This approach enables the creation of carbon hubs that integrate CO2 transport, storage, and complementary infrastructure such as hydrogen hubs and advanced recycling networks, while emphasizing environmental justice and equitable community engagement.
metadata.categories: Energy Policy, Industrial Decarbonization, Carbon Capture and Storage, Steel Industry, Environmental Justice

metadata.title: Biomass Farming Removal CapChar Proposes New UK-Oriented Biochar Carbon Code
metadata.indicator: CapChar, a UK-based biochar technology company, has launched a new Biochar Carbon Code now in public consultation, designed as a tailored, end-to-end solution for UK-based biochar producers and farmers. The code integrates with CapChar’s pyrolysis technology and digital monitoring, reporting, and verification (dMRV) platform, offering streamlined carbon tracking and compliance through monthly elemental analysis and peer-reviewed scientific methodologies. It emphasizes local production, soil health improvement, and carbon removal, with specific applicability to diverse agricultural feedstocks and farm-scale implementation.
metadata.categories: Biotechnology, Environmental Policy, Carbon Capture, UK Agriculture

The program targets scalable, innovative CDR solutions to address India’s climate challenges and is part of remove’s broader effort to advance climate-tech entrepreneurship globally.

metadata.title: Article 6 Capture Compliance Markets Japan And India Forge Strong Ties On Multiple Carbon Fronts
metadata.indicator: Japan and India have launched a joint carbon credit mechanism (JCM) under Article 6.2 of the Paris Agreement, enabling bilateral carbon trading and investment in low-carbon technologies, with credits eligible for international markets. The agreement, signed by India’s Environment Ministry and Japan’s government, aims to support India’s nationally determined contributions while advancing climate finance and technology transfer, and includes plans for 100 million tons of JCM credits by 2030 and 200 million tons by 2040. The partnership also includes cross-border collaboration in carbon capture, green hydrogen, and ammonia, with a proposed cross-border supply chain supported by shared standards and verified low-carbon benchmarks, and a focus on strengthening resilience and energy security in the Indo-Pacific region.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, International Cooperation, Renewable Energy

metadata.title: Capture Storage India Partners with Norway On Carbon Capture for Deepwater Energy Push
metadata.indicator: India is forging a strategic partnership with Norway to develop carbon capture and storage (CCS) capabilities for deepwater oil and gas exploration, inspired by Norway’s successful Northern Lights CCS project, which stores up to 100 million tonnes of CO2 beneath the seabed. Petroleum Minister Hardeep Singh Puri highlighted India’s intent to replicate Norway’s flexible CCS infrastructure to support decarbonization, particularly in deepwater basins like Krishna-Godavari and Mahanadi, as part of India’s broader push for offshore energy development. This initiative aligns with India’s upcoming Open Acreage Licensing Policy (OALP) Round 10, covering over 250,000 sq km and targeting enhanced subsea operations and drilling technologies.
metadata.categories: Energy Innovation, Carbon Capture and Storage, Deepwater Exploration, Oil and Gas

metadata.title: Farming Removal Varaha Locks In A Five-Year CDR Deal With Louis Dreyfus Company
metadata.indicator: Carbon dioxide removal (CDR) company Varaha has secured a five-year deal with Louis Dreyfus Company (LDC) to deliver 6,000 tons of annual carbon removal credits through improved agricultural land management in Uttar Pradesh, India. The project involves 430 smallholder farms implementing regenerative practices such as crop rotation, straw return, and reduced soil disturbance to avoid biomass burning, thereby reducing emissions and enhancing soil carbon sequestration. Varaha uses third-party verification under Verra’s improved agricultural land management methodology (v2.1) and integrates monitoring, soil sampling, and traceability from farm to warehouse, with the credits being delivered via insetting to support LDC’s sustainable supply chain.
metadata.categories: Carbon Removal, Sustainable Agriculture, Climate Change, Agriculture

metadata.title: Markets Climate-Smart Rice Farming Gets Boost From Mitti Labs–TNC Partnership
metadata.indicator: Mitti Labs, a climate-tech startup founded in 2023, has partnered with The Nature Conservancy (TNC) to advance climate-smart rice farming in Punjab through its AI-driven "soil-to-sky" digital Measurement, Reporting, and Verification (dMRV) platform. By integrating satellite and field-level data, the platform enables precise tracking of sustainable practices like Alternate Wetting and Drying (AWD), Direct Seeded Rice (DSR), and no-burn residue management, helping farmers conserve water, improve soil health, and reduce methane emissions. The system supports emission validation and access to climate finance, while scaling across 10 million hectares of Indian rice fields—equivalent to one-quarter of the country’s rice-farming land—within a digital twin framework.
metadata.categories: Climate-Smart Agriculture, AI and Satellite Monitoring, Sustainable Farming, Climate Change

metadata.title: Biomass Removal Varaha Registers Second Puro.earth Biochar Facility In India
metadata.indicator: Varaha, India’s leading carbon removal company, has registered its second industrial biochar facility with Puro.earth, the world’s largest carbon removal standard and registry, expanding its footprint in Southern India where it produces biochar from corn shanks—agricultural waste heated to create carbon-rich material that sequesters CO₂ for centuries. This marks India’s second Puro.earth-verified biochar project, following the first in October 2024, and underscores Varaha’s commitment to high-integrity, transparent carbon removal through a digital measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV) platform. The facility supports climate goals by preventing emissions from waste burning and fossil fuel use, while delivering co-benefits like improved soil fertility and biodiversity.
metadata.categories: Carbon Removal, Biochar, Climate Innovation, India

metadata.title: Forests Removal New Study Finds Protecting And Restoring EU Forests Is Key To Meeting CO2 Removal Goals
metadata.indicator: A new study by Wild Europe and the Climate Action Beacon at Griffith University reveals that protecting and restoring EU forests could remove over 300 million tonnes of CO2 annually, significantly contributing to the European Green Deal’s target of 310 million tonnes of net carbon removal by 2030. The research highlights that governments have underestimated carbon stocks in old-growth and primary forests, particularly due to their exclusion from current climate and forest management policies. By emphasizing the carbon storage capacity of diverse, biodiverse natural forests—including aboveground, belowground, and dead biomass—the study argues that intact forests are more effective and resilient carbon sinks than managed or monoculture systems.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Forests, Environmental Policy

**Summary (Indicator):**
A new study by Wild Europe and the Climate Action Beacon at Griffith University reveals that protecting and restoring EU forests could remove over 300 million tonnes of CO2 annually, significantly contributing to the European Green Deal’s target of 310 million tonnes of net carbon removal by 2030. The research highlights that governments have underestimated carbon stocks in old-growth and primary forests, particularly due to their exclusion from current climate and forest management policies. By emphasizing the carbon storage capacity of diverse, biodiverse natural forests—including aboveground, belowground, and dead biomass—the study argues that intact forests are more effective and resilient carbon sinks than managed or monoculture systems.

metadata.title: Policy Removal The EU Has Released Its Nearly $105B Clean Industrial Deal
metadata.indicator: The European Union has launched the EU Clean Industrial Deal, a $105 billion initiative to boost industrial competitiveness and decarbonization by investing in electrification, grid stability, and circular economy measures. The plan includes a voluntary carbon intensity labeling system for steel and cement, the creation of an EU Critical Raw Material Centre, and a 2030 target of 24% recycled material usage. However, critics argue the deal lacks a clear, urgent roadmap for scaling carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, missing key opportunities to establish European leadership in this emerging climate sector.
metadata.categories: Policy, Climate Change, Industrial Decarbonization, European Union

**Summary (Indicator):**
The European Union has launched the EU Clean Industrial Deal, a $105 billion initiative to boost industrial competitiveness and decarbonization by investing in electrification, grid stability, and circular economy measures. The plan includes a voluntary carbon intensity labeling system for steel and cement, the creation of an EU Critical Raw Material Centre, and a 2030 target of 24% recycled material usage. However, critics argue the deal lacks a clear, urgent roadmap for scaling carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, missing key opportunities to establish European leadership in this emerging climate sector.

metadata.title: EU To Fund CDR Under The 2025 Edition Of Its LIFE Program
metadata.indicator: The European Union has launched a call for proposals under the 2025 edition of its LIFE Program for Climate Change Mitigation, allocating €28 million to fund carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, including biochar, enhanced rock weathering, ocean alkalinity enhancement, direct ocean capture, and small-scale bioCCS. The initiative aims to advance innovative, cost-effective CDR solutions and strengthen monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) capacities to support viable business models. This funding is part of a broader effort to reduce net greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% compared to 1990 levels by 2030, aligning with the European Green Deal’s goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.
metadata.categories: Climate Change Mitigation, Carbon Dioxide Removal, European Union, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Policy Removal New Report Provides Recommendations On Scaling CDR In The EU
metadata.indicator: The European Scientific Advisory Board on Climate Change has released a report recommending policy actions to accelerate carbon dioxide removal (CDR) deployment across the EU, including establishing separate legal targets for carbon emissions, temporary land-based removals, and permanent removals via innovative methods. The report calls for integrating permanent CDR into the EU Emissions Trading System to create high-integrity carbon credits and proposes an "extended emitter responsibility" requiring current emitters to fund future CO2 removals. It also advocates for increased funding, market incentives, and monitoring mechanisms, along with new pricing instruments to reward land managers for carbon sequestration.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Dioxide Removal (CDR), European Union

- Published: 2025-02-24
- TRL: 6
- Dimension: Pol

**Summary (Indicator):**
The European Scientific Advisory Board on Climate Change has released a report recommending policy actions to accelerate carbon dioxide removal (CDR) deployment across the EU, including establishing separate legal targets for carbon emissions, temporary land-based removals, and permanent removals via innovative methods. The report calls for integrating permanent CDR into the EU Emissions Trading System to create high-integrity carbon credits and proposes an "extended emitter responsibility" requiring current emitters to fund future CO2 removals. It also advocates for increased funding, market incentives, and monitoring mechanisms, along with new pricing instruments to reward land managers for carbon sequestration.

metadata.title: Policy Removal Updated Carbon Removal Policy Tracker By Carbon Gap Shows The EU Needs A Stronger Strategy
metadata.indicator: Carbon Gap has updated its Carbon Removal Policy Tracker to provide a comprehensive database of over 600 EU carbon dioxide removal (CDR) funding opportunities, highlighting that the EU is falling short of its climate neutrality goals due to insufficient and uneven national CDR policies and funding. While non-EU countries like the UK, Denmark, and Switzerland are leading in early-stage CDR research and development, the EU as a whole has only invested €950 million in CDR RD&I over decades, falling short of the required €2.6 billion over seven years. Denmark and Switzerland have established robust CDR strategies, whereas countries like Italy and France show minimal progress, indicating a significant imbalance in policy development across the EU.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Removal, European Union, Decarbonization

metadata.title: Markets EU Carbon Market Will Cause Diesel Prices To Soar
metadata.indicator: The European Union is implementing a new emissions trading system (ETS2) for transportation and housing sectors, starting in 2027, which mandates fuel providers to purchase carbon allowances to offset diesel emissions. Unlike the previous system, no free allowances will be distributed, leading to increased diesel costs—projected to rise from 14 cents per liter in 2027 to 54 cents per liter by 2031—potentially impacting consumer prices and fuel affordability. The policy includes funding for a "social climate fund" to support low-income households and small businesses with energy efficiency and insulation measures.
metadata.categories: Climate Regulations, European Union, Carbon Market, Fuel Prices

metadata.title: Biomass Direct Air Capture Farming Policy Removal EU To Provide $30M For Carbon Removal Projects
metadata.indicator: The European Commission has launched a €28.5 million (≈$30 million) funding call under the LIFE Programme to support carbon dioxide removal (CDR) projects across the EU, focusing on technologies such as biochar, bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS), and enhanced weathering (ERW). The funding aims to advance carbon farming by incentivizing projects along the entire value chain and encourages synergies with Horizon Europe and the "A Soil Deal for Europe" mission. Projects can receive up to 60% of their costs covered, with individual grants ranging from €1 to €5 million, and applications open until September 17, 2024, with funding expected to begin in mid-2025.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Carbon Removal, EU Funding, Climate Action

metadata.title: Policy Removal EU CBAM Portal For Third-Country Operators Goes Live
metadata.indicator: The European Commission has launched the CBAM Portal for Third-Country Operators (O3CI), enabling non-EU operators to register, submit installation and emissions data, and share carbon pricing information with EU authorities starting January 1, 2025. The portal facilitates secure data exchange between third-country operators and EU declarants, supporting compliance with the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) by addressing carbon leakage and promoting global decarbonization. Access is granted via the EU Login system and requires Commission approval, ensuring transparency and alignment with EU climate policy goals.

metadata.title: Opinion: EU Should Use Carbon Credits As The Carrot To Counteract The Stick Of Carbon Border Tax
metadata.indicator: The EU should integrate high-quality carbon credits into its Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) as a complementary, market-based solution to counteract the regressive and economically uneven impacts of the CBAM’s carbon tax on importers. While the CBAM taxes imports based on carbon intensity, potentially undermining global economic equity and disadvantaging developing nations, carbon credits offer a more flexible and efficient alternative by allowing importers to offset liabilities through verified, independent climate projects—especially in sectors where decarbonization technology remains costly or nascent. Recent advancements in the voluntary carbon market, including independent carbon ratings, measurement tools, and carbon insurance, have significantly improved transparency and project integrity, creating a credible pathway for governments to trust and deploy carbon credits in compliance markets.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Market, EU Regulations, Sustainable Development

- Published: 2024-05-16
- Technology: Carbon Markets
- TRL: 7
- Dimension: Tech

**Summary (Indicator):**
The EU should integrate high-quality carbon credits into its Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) as a complementary, market-based solution to counteract the regressive and economically uneven impacts of the CBAM’s carbon tax on importers. While the CBAM taxes imports based on carbon intensity, potentially undermining global economic equity and disadvantaging developing nations, carbon credits offer a more flexible and efficient alternative by allowing importers to offset liabilities through verified, independent climate projects—especially in sectors where decarbonization technology remains costly or nascent. Recent advancements in the voluntary carbon market, including independent carbon ratings, measurement tools, and carbon insurance, have significantly improved transparency and project integrity, creating a credible pathway for governments to trust and deploy carbon credits in compliance markets.

metadata.title: Markets India To Launch Carbon Market In 2026, Says Power Minister
metadata.indicator: India plans to launch a national carbon market by mid-2026, enabling industries to buy and sell carbon credits based on fossil fuel usage, with emission-intensive sectors like steel and cement expected to benefit from financial incentives to adopt cleaner energy sources. The market will support compliance with international regulations, including the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), and is built on the 2022 Energy Conservation (Amendment) Bill that established the legal framework for carbon trading.

metadata.title: Markets EU And India Join Forces On Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM)
metadata.indicator: The European Union and India are collaborating on the implementation of a Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) to ensure imported goods face equivalent carbon costs as domestic products, aiming to prevent carbon leakage and promote global decarbonization. The initiative focuses on creating a level playing field by applying carbon pricing to imports, with discussions emphasizing fair implementation, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in India. Both sides are also advancing cooperation in carbon trading, emissions pricing, clean technologies, and customs issues, including cross-border e-commerce and drug precursor controls, under the existing EU-India Customs Cooperation Agreement.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, International Cooperation, Climate Change, Trade and Customs

__data__.text:
# Markets EU And India Join Forces On Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM)

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/eu-and-india-join-forces-on-carbon-border-adjustment-mechanism-cbam
- Published: 2024-07-09
- TRL: 7
- Dimension: Env&S

**Summary (Indicator):**
The European Union and India are collaborating on the implementation of a Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) to ensure imported goods face equivalent carbon costs as domestic products, aiming to prevent carbon leakage and promote global decarbonization. The initiative focuses on creating a level playing field by applying carbon pricing to imports, with discussions emphasizing fair implementation, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in India. Both sides are also advancing cooperation in carbon trading, emissions pricing, clean technologies, and customs issues, including cross-border e-commerce and drug precursor controls, under the existing EU-India Customs Cooperation Agreement.

metadata.title: Capture Policy Removal U.S. Bill Proposes Carbon Fees On Imports, CO2 Capture And Removal Considered As Mitigators
metadata.indicator: A new U.S. legislative proposal, the Foreign Pollution Fee Act of 2025, introduces a tariff-based mechanism that imposes fees on imported goods based on their carbon intensity relative to U.S. manufacturing standards, targeting countries like China, Russia, Vietnam, and India for disproportionately high emissions. The bill allows companies to reduce these fees by investing in carbon capture and removal (CDR) technologies or purchasing certified, durable carbon removal credits—such as direct air capture or marine-based removal—while excluding temporary forest-based offsets and those linked to "foreign entities of concern." This approach mirrors the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) and could incentivize global investment in carbon mitigation, while also reshaping international trade dynamics and pressuring foreign nations to adopt stricter environmental standards.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Removal, International Trade, Environmental Regulation

The bill allows companies to reduce these fees by investing in carbon capture and removal (CDR) technologies or purchasing certified, durable carbon removal credits—such as direct air capture or marine-based removal—while excluding temporary forest-based offsets and those linked to "foreign entities of concern." metadata.title: Markets Vietnam To Run Carbon Market Pilot Program From 2025 To 2028
metadata.indicator: Vietnam will launch a domestic carbon credit market pilot program from 2025 to 2028, initially allocating emission quotas to around 200 facilities in the power, iron and steel, and cement sectors—representing about 45% of total emissions. The program, overseen by the government and discussed at a meeting led by Deputy Prime Minister Tran Hong Ha, will operate without allowing direct carbon trading with foreign entities, except under existing international agreements. The initiative aims to help Vietnamese industries comply with the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) and strengthen domestic climate governance under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, with plans to expand nationwide and explore future global market integration by 2029.

# Markets Vietnam To Run Carbon Market Pilot Program From 2025 To 2028
