metadata.title: Mineralization Removal Puro.earth Starts Public Consultation On Its Updated ERW Methodology
metadata.indicator: Puro.earth has launched a public consultation on its updated enhanced rock weathering (ERW) methodology, which introduces five key changes to improve scientific rigor and practicality. The updated framework includes six measurable ERW approaches, requiring the combination of one for CO2 quantification and another for validation, with detailed soil chemistry and control plot requirements to ensure accuracy. It introduces explicit rules for quantifying and accounting for CO2 losses—such as secondary mineral formation and plant loss—and mandates uncertainty analysis via frequentist or Bayesian methods, with an uncertainty discount mechanism. The methodology aligns with the Puro General Rules and the ICVCM CCP, and is informed by input from academic, industry, and non-profit experts through workshops and field interviews.
metadata.categories: Environmental Science, Carbon Removal, Climate Change

- URL: https://carbonherald.com/puro-earth-starts-public-consultation-on-its-updated-erw-methodology
- Published: 2025-09-09
- TRL: 7
- Dimension: Env&S

**Summary (Indicator):**
Puro.earth has launched a public consultation on its updated enhanced rock weathering (ERW) methodology, which introduces five key changes to improve scientific rigor and practicality. The updated framework includes six measurable ERW approaches, requiring the combination of one for CO2 quantification and another for validation, with detailed soil chemistry and control plot requirements to ensure accuracy. It introduces explicit rules for quantifying and accounting for CO2 losses—such as secondary mineral formation and plant loss—and mandates uncertainty analysis via frequentist or Bayesian methods, with an uncertainty discount mechanism. The methodology aligns with the Puro General Rules and the ICVCM CCP, and is informed by input from academic, industry, and non-profit experts through workshops and field interviews.

metadata.title: Farming Mineralization Removal The Data Quarry Platform By Cascade Climate Is Now Live, Offering Real-World Info On ERW
metadata.indicator: Cascade Climate has launched Data Quarry, a live, permissioned data-sharing platform for enhanced rock weathering (ERW), enabling stakeholders to securely share and access real-world ERW data while complying with data privacy regulations. The platform now hosts datasets from 10 leading ERW companies—including Alt Carbon, Flux, InPlanet, and Carbon Drawdown Initiative—and additional contributors like the University of Illinois and Varaha, supporting transparency, research validation, and operational learning in the field. By standardizing data schemas and infrastructure, Data Quarry aims to address key uncertainties and cost barriers in ERW deployment, advancing the technology’s potential as a decarbonization solution.
metadata.categories: Environmental Technology, Decarbonization, Climate Change

metadata.title: Mineralization Removal The Carbon Drawdown Initiative Unlocks Testing Innovation For ERW Effectiveness
metadata.indicator: The Carbon Drawdown Initiative has developed a 48-hour laboratory test method to rapidly evaluate the effectiveness of enhanced rock weathering (ERW) by measuring changes in electrical conductivity as a proxy for alkalinity and carbon removal. This method replaces the previous 200–250 day process, using a standardized 30g rock, 80g soil, and 150g distilled water mixture shaken in an Erlenmeyer flask, with results showing strong correlation to long-term alkalinity trends. The innovation significantly accelerates development and deployment of ERW solutions by enabling faster feedback on soil-rock combinations.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Removal, Enhanced Rock Weathering, Environmental Innovation

metadata.title: Removal Frontier Picks Nine Carbon Removal Startups For $4.5M Funding by Vasil Velev
metadata.startup: https://alithic.com; https://altcarbon.com; https://anvilcarbon.com; https://capture6.com; https://exterracarbon.com; https://fluxcarbon.com; https://nulife.com; https://planeteers.com; https://silica.com
metadata.indicator: Frontier, a market-driven advance commitment platform, has awarded $4.5 million in funding—$500,000 to each of nine carbon removal startups—to accelerate the deployment of diverse carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies. The selected startups—including Alithic, Alt Carbon, Anvil, Capture6, Exterra Carbon Solutions, Flux, NULIFE, Planeteers, and Silica—are advancing innovative, scalable methods such as enhanced rock weathering, mineralization, and hydrothermal liquefaction, many of which integrate with existing industrial infrastructure like agriculture, cement production, and wastewater management. These technologies aim to reduce costs and scale carbon removal by leveraging low-energy, co-beneficial processes that also produce valuable materials or by-products, such as clean metals, bio-oil, or carbon credits.
metadata.categories: Carbon Removal, Startups, Climate Change Funding

The selected startups—including Alithic, Alt Carbon, Anvil, Capture6, Exterra Carbon Solutions, Flux, NULIFE, Planeteers, and Silica—are advancing innovative, scalable methods such as enhanced rock weathering, mineralization, and hydrothermal liquefaction, many of which integrate with existing industrial infrastructure like agriculture, cement production, and wastewater management. These technologies aim to reduce costs and scale carbon removal by leveraging low-energy, co-beneficial processes that also produce valuable materials or by-products, such as clean metals, bio-oil, or carbon credits.

metadata.title: Removal Alt Futures Summit Successfully Wraps Up Its Second Edition In India
metadata.indicator: The second edition of the Alt Futures Summit convened in India, bringing together global experts, investors, and policymakers to advance carbon dioxide removal (CDR) initiatives in the Global South, with a focus on South Asia. The summit, held in Bengaluru and Darjeeling, highlighted the potential of philanthropic and concessionary capital to fund early-stage CDR technologies, emphasizing the need for developers to articulate how such funding benefits the entire pathway rather than just investors. A key outcome was the announcement of remove's second India Accelerator Cohort to support innovative CDR startups, alongside a field visit to Alt Carbon’s Darjeeling site, where a basalt spreading and biochar production project revitalizes local tea farms and improves farmer livelihoods.
metadata.categories: Climate Action, Carbon Removal, Sustainability, India Events

metadata.title: Forests Markets Removal Ecosystem Restoration Standard Is Now Equitable Earth
metadata.indicator: The Ecosystem Restoration Standard (ERS) has rebranded to Equitable Earth, expanding its focus from forest carbon conservation to include both conservation and restoration initiatives, with a strong emphasis on community-led projects and social equity. The rebranding marks a strategic evolution to unify forest conservation and restoration under one standard, incorporating indigenous and local population priorities, while maintaining rigorous digital Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (dMRV) and environmental safeguards. As an approved standard under the ICVCM Core Carbon Principles, Equitable Earth now offers a global carbon market framework that prioritizes integrity, inclusivity, and measurable co-benefits for people and the environment.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Forests, Environmental Standards

metadata.title: Biomass Removal New Puro.earth Report Tracks The Rise Of Biochar As A Leading CDR Approach

metadata.title: Removal Carbon Removal Prices To Continue Going Down According To Report From AlliedOffsets And Carbon Herald
metadata.indicator: Carbon removal (CDR) market prices are projected to decline from $630 per ton in 2023 to $450 per ton by 2030, with further reductions anticipated by 2040 and 2050, as the industry matures and scales. The market has seen exponential growth in the number of companies—now exceeding 600—driven by $3.5 billion in total investment, with strong demand signaled by pre-purchase commitments from top buyers. The report analyzes 11 CDR technologies including direct air capture, carbon mineralization, biochar, enhanced rock weathering, and ocean-based methods, and highlights that demand and investment are growing faster than in most climate tech sectors, despite a 30% drop in overall climate tech investment in 2023.
metadata.categories: Investment Markets, Carbon Removal, Climate Tech

metadata.title: Markets Prices Viridios AI And Carbon Herald Partner To Provide Carbon Credit Price Data
metadata.indicator: Viridios AI and Carbon Herald have partnered to provide public, transparent, and easily accessible carbon credit price data, addressing long-standing concerns about lack of transparency and fair valuation in voluntary carbon markets. The collaboration offers weekly carbon price curves across key market segments—VCM and retirements, REDD+, afforestation/reforestation, blue carbon, and cookstoves—making it a centralized, reliable resource for market participants. This initiative, described as a step toward "Carbon Markets 2.0," aims to build trust by enabling stakeholders to make informed decisions based on verifiable pricing data.
metadata.categories: Carbon Markets, Environmental Data, Climate Change

This initiative, described as a step toward "Carbon Markets 2.0," aims to build trust by enabling stakeholders to make informed decisions based on verifiable pricing data.

metadata.title: Markets Nigeria Initiates ‘National Carbon Market Activation Plan’ To Tap Into $2.5 Billion Opportunity
metadata.indicator: Nigeria is launching a National Carbon Market Activation Plan, spearheaded by the Federal Government in collaboration with the Africa Carbon Market Initiative (ACMI), to establish a sustainable and transparent carbon market valued at $2.5 billion. The plan, led by co-chairs Zacch Adedeji of FIRS and Dr. Dahiru Salisu of NCCC, involves multiple ministries and aims to create a credible, investor-friendly ecosystem that generates carbon credits through green initiatives like the Electric Buses Rollout Programme. The initiative emphasizes inclusivity, ensuring local communities and indigenous groups are integrated into the planning and benefits of the market.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Nigeria

metadata.title: Markets Gold Standard Begins Testing Digital Measurement, Reporting and Verification (dMRV) Solutions
metadata.indicator: Gold Standard has launched a pilot program to test digital Measurement, Reporting, and Verification (dMRV) solutions for carbon credit projects, aiming to enhance data integrity, accelerate impact reporting, and enable faster access to funding through an "interim issuance track." The initiative, set to begin in November 2024 and run for two years, will evaluate real-world operational challenges and benefits of dMRV technologies, with support provided to project developers to ensure compliance with GS4GG standards. Participating projects may issue credits more frequently, while a new expert working group composed of technical and sector specialists will assess feasibility and performance.
metadata.categories: Climate Technology, Carbon Markets, Digital Measurement and Verification

metadata.title: Companies Investment BURN To Receive $12M Investment From Key Carbon For Distribution Of Clean Cookstoves
metadata.indicator: BURN Manufacturing, a leading producer of clean cookstoves in developing countries, has secured a $12 million investment from Key Carbon Ltd., a major financier in the voluntary carbon market, as part of a broader $18 million deal with private equity firm Cartesian. The funding will support the distribution of electric cookstoves in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia, and biomass stoves in Nigeria, DRC, Tanzania, and Mozambique over two years, with the goal of reducing emissions and improving household health. The investment builds on a prior $25 million financing from Key Carbon in 2023, bringing BURN closer to its $1 billion goal of delivering clean cooking solutions to vulnerable communities across Africa.
metadata.categories: Clean Cookstoves, Renewable Energy, Climate Finance

metadata.title: Markets Science Project Developer Forum Responds To New Study Claiming 9.2 Times Over-crediting Of Clean Cookstove Projects
metadata.indicator: A recent study in *Nature Sustainability* claims that clean cookstove carbon credit projects are over-credited by as much as 9.2 times due to outdated methodologies and misaligned assumptions, particularly in estimating fuel consumption and stove adoption rates. The study criticizes the use of outdated data, non-representative project types (e.g., NGO-distributed stoves), and default values for non-renewable biomass, while arguing that Gold Standard’s metered methodology results in only 1.5 times over-crediting. In response, the Project Developer Forum—representing carbon project developers—contends the analysis is flawed, citing outdated literature, lack of validation with project developers, and a failure to account for recent randomized control trials and real-world adoption rates (e.g., 86% adoption in Nairobi vs. claimed 58%).
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Credits, Sustainable Development, Environmental Policy

# Markets Science Project Developer Forum Responds To New Study Claiming 9.2 Times Over-crediting Of Clean Cookstove Projects

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/project-developer-forum-responds-to-new-study-claiming-9-2-times-over-crediting-of-clean-cookstove-projects
- Published: 2024-04-12
- TRL: 6
- Dimension: Env&S

**Summary (Indicator):**
A recent study in *Nature Sustainability* claims that clean cookstove carbon credit projects are over-credited by as much as 9.2 times due to outdated methodologies and misaligned assumptions, particularly in estimating fuel consumption and stove adoption rates. The study criticizes the use of outdated data, non-representative project types (e.g., NGO-distributed stoves), and default values for non-renewable biomass, while arguing that Gold Standard’s metered methodology results in only 1.5 times over-crediting. In response, the Project Developer Forum—representing carbon project developers—contends the analysis is flawed, citing outdated literature, lack of validation with project developers, and a failure to account for recent randomized control trials and real-world adoption rates (e.g., 86% adoption in Nairobi vs. claimed 58%).

metadata.title: Markets New Indices Show Carbon Credit Quality Improving
metadata.indicator: A new pair of pioneering indices—the Calyx Carbon Integrity Index™ and the Calyx-ClearBlue Carbon Price-Integrity Index—has been launched to improve transparency and assess quality and price dynamics in the voluntary carbon market (VCM). Developed by Calyx Global and ClearBlue Markets, these are the first standardized tools to evaluate carbon credit quality and pricing, addressing long-standing market concerns over inconsistency and lack of trust. The indices show a clear market shift toward prioritizing integrity over volume, with stabilized prices and premium demand for removal-based credits indicating growing investor confidence in high-quality carbon offsets.
metadata.categories: Market Analysis, Carbon Markets, Sustainability, Climate Change

metadata.title: Markets Press Release Kita And ClearBlue Partner To Radically Change Insurance For The Voluntary Carbon Market
metadata.indicator: ClearBlue and Kita have partnered to enhance the Voluntary Carbon Market (VCM) by integrating ClearBlue’s carbon market analysis and delivery risk assessment (DRA) into Kita’s carbon credit insurance underwriting model, providing buyers, investors, and lenders with a risk-mitigated, transparent approach to purchasing carbon credits. The DRA evaluates hundreds of nature-based projects—such as Improved Forest Management and afforestation—using location, registry, and historical data to quantify delivery risk and estimate issuance volumes, directly improving the accuracy of carbon credit valuation and risk prediction. This synergy enables a new insurance product, the Carbon Purchase Protection Cover (CPPC), which safeguards against delivery shortfalls, counterparty risk, and methodological changes, thereby increasing trust and confidence in VCM transactions.
metadata.categories: Environmental Responsibility, Carbon Markets, Insurance, Sustainability

metadata.title: Biomass Removal Charm Industrial To Scale Operations With New Manufacturo Tech Partnership
metadata.indicator: Charm Industrial, a carbon removal company specializing in converting agricultural and forestry waste into CO2-dense bio-oil via fast pyrolysis, has partnered with software firm Manufacturo to enhance operational scalability and data accuracy. The integration of Manufacturo’s API-driven process control and data management tools with Charm’s custom carbon ledger enables real-time, traceable tracking of carbon removal outputs, improving transparency and reliability in carbon credit reporting. This partnership supports Charm’s goal of achieving gigaton-scale carbon removal by enabling efficient, precise, and verifiable operations.
metadata.categories: Climate Technology, Carbon Removal, Environmental Innovation

metadata.title: Removal New Carbon Console Tool Showcases The CDR Sector In Canada
metadata.indicator: Carbon Removal Canada has launched the Carbon Console, a real-time digital dashboard that tracks and displays carbon dioxide removal (CDR) projects, capacity, and technologies across Canada, highlighting 11 megatonnes of planned or announced CDR capacity. The tool provides province-level insights into CDR development, policy progress, and local energy mixes, serving as a centralized resource for developers, investors, and policymakers. By showcasing Canada’s growing CDR sector and its potential to generate 89,000 jobs and $140 billion in GDP by 2050, the console positions Canada as a global leader in climate mitigation and decarbonization innovation.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Removal, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal Skyrenu Secures Govt And Private Support In Pre-Seed Funding Round
metadata.indicator: Quebec-based direct air capture (DAC) startup Skyrenu has secured pre-seed funding from Investissement Québec under the Impulsion PME program and private investor CarbonFix, enabling it to scale its on-site DAC technology and advance its award-winning carbon removal solution developed in partnership with the University of Sherbrooke. The funding follows the deployment of Skyrenu’s first on-site DAC unit at Deep Sky Alpha in Alberta and strengthens its ecosystem through strategic partnerships with PRIMA Québec, 2 Degrés, and Axelys, which supported technological maturation.

metadata.title: Capture Storage Norway Expands Northern Lights Carbon Storage Capacity To 5M Tons
metadata.indicator: Norway has expanded its Northern Lights carbon capture and storage (CCS) project to a capacity of 5 million tons of CO₂ per year, nearly tripling its existing 1.5 million-ton annual throughput. The expansion includes new injection wells, enhanced onshore storage tanks at the Øygarden terminal, and additional shipping infrastructure to receive CO₂ from industrial emitters in Germany, the Netherlands, and potentially Poland by 2028. Captured CO₂ is liquefied, transported by ship, and injected 2,600 meters below the North Sea into deep saline aquifers, where it is monitored in real time using advanced sensors and satellite systems to ensure long-term containment and safety.
metadata.categories: Environmental Technology, Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy Industry

metadata.indicator: Carbon Clean has opened a 77,000-square-foot Global Innovation Centre in Navi Mumbai, India, dedicated to advancing next-generation carbon capture technologies, including its CycloneCC modular system designed for hard-to-abate industries. The facility features two operational units and advanced labs for solvent development, supporting over 100 specialists with plans to expand to 350, and is already supporting pilot projects with major Indian industrial players like BHP, JSW, NTPC, and Tata Steel. The centre marks a key expansion of Carbon Clean’s global footprint and aligns with India’s emerging national CCUS strategy, accelerating industrial decarbonization through scalable carbon capture and storage.

metadata.title: Capture Storage Finland And Norway Deepen Climate Cooperation With Cross-Border Carbon Storage Deal
metadata.indicator: Finland and Norway have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to enable the cross-border transport of captured carbon dioxide (CO2) from Finland to Norway for permanent geological storage beneath the seabed, addressing Finland's lack of suitable geological conditions for long-term storage. The agreement leverages Norway’s 28 years of experience in CO2 storage and positions both countries to expand regional cooperation in carbon capture and storage (CCS), supporting the development of a commercial market for cross-border CO2 transport.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Environmental Cooperation, Nordic Countries

**Summary (Indicator):**
Finland and Norway have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to enable the cross-border transport of captured carbon dioxide (CO2) from Finland to Norway for permanent geological storage beneath the seabed, addressing Finland's lack of suitable geological conditions for long-term storage. The agreement leverages Norway’s 28 years of experience in CO2 storage and positions both countries to expand regional cooperation in carbon capture and storage (CCS), supporting the development of a commercial market for cross-border CO2 transport.

metadata.title: Capture Storage Trudvang CCS Project Gets Key Feasibility Clearance In Norway
metadata.indicator: The Trudvang carbon capture and storage (CCS) project in Norway has received feasibility clearance (DG1), a critical milestone in its development, with the project poised to store up to 10 million tonnes of CO2 annually for at least 25 years—equating to over 300 million tonnes in total. Operated by Vår Energi, Storegga, and INPEX Idemitsu Norge, the project leverages over 25 years of carbon storage expertise from the nearby Sleipner site, the world’s first commercial CCS project. Located in the Utsira formation of the North Sea, Trudvang is strategically positioned to support Europe’s decarbonization goals and is set to become a major hub for industrial CO2 storage.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture China Installs First Centrifugal Onboard Carbon Capture On Bulk Carrier
metadata.indicator: China has installed the world's first centrifugal onboard carbon capture system (OCCS) on the 57,000 dwt bulk carrier Yue Dian 56, marking a major milestone in maritime decarbonization. Developed by Headway Technology Group in collaboration with Zhoushan Free Trade Zone Administration, Guangdong Energy Group, CHN Energy’s New Energy Technology Research Institute, Longshan Shipyard, and the China Classification Society, the system captures over 90% of emissions with CO2 purity exceeding 99.6%, using centrifugal separation and GNX-3 absorber technology. The captured liquid CO2 is transferred at Zhoushan’s pilot port and will be utilized in sustainable fuel production, including hydrogen, methanol, and ammonia, forming a closed-loop carbon utilization cycle.
metadata.categories: Maritime Decarbonization, Carbon Capture Technology, Sustainable Shipping

metadata.title: Capture Utilization Japan’s MUCC Invests $5M In MCi Carbon To Advance Cement Decarbonization
metadata.indicator: Mitsubishi UBE Cement Corporation (MUCC) has invested $5 million in MCi Carbon, a Australian cleantech firm developing mineral carbonation technology, marking MUCC’s first foray into carbon capture and utilization (CCU). The investment, part of a $20 million funding round, strengthens MCi’s commercialization efforts with a long-term collaboration leveraging MUCC’s cement industry expertise and MCi’s mineral carbonation process. The funding supports the launch of MCi’s "Myrtle" demonstration plant in Australia, demonstrating the commercial viability of converting CO2 into stable mineral form, while MUCC also explores direct carbonation of waste concrete under Japan’s Green Innovation Fund.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Decarbonization, Cement Industry, Carbon Capture and Utilization

metadata.indicator: Tencent, in partnership with GenZero, a Temasek-owned investment platform, has secured a 15-year agreement to purchase at least one million verified carbon credits to offset greenhouse gas emissions, with credits sourced from nature-based carbon removal projects verified under international standards such as Verra, Gold Standard, or Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. The initiative emphasizes transparency, real-world impact, and co-benefits for local communities, leveraging monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) technologies to ensure credibility and reduce project risk. This marks a significant step toward credible corporate climate financing and reflects a broader trend of major tech firms investing in high-integrity carbon markets.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Credits, Sustainability, Corporate Sustainability

metadata.title: Capture Removal Utilization The Global CarbonX Program 2.0 By Tencent Now Accepting Applications
metadata.indicator: Tencent has launched the CarbonX Program 2.0, a global initiative accepting applications from early-stage companies developing carbon dioxide removal (CDR), long-duration energy storage (LDES), carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS)—particularly for decarbonizing steel— and carbon capture and utilization (CCU) for chemical and consumer product production. Selected innovators will receive multimillion-dollar grants and pilot deployments in Kenya, the Maldives, Serbia, and through the CarbonXmade consortium, with support from a network of industry, academic, and venture partners including Africa Climate Ventures, China Merchants Venture, and Lightspeed China Partners.

metadata.title: Capture Direct Air Capture Mineralization Removal Calcarea’s Unique Approach Captures CO2 From Ships And Sequesters It Directly Into The Ocean
metadata.indicator: Calcarea, a CalTech-founded start-up, has developed a direct air capture and removal technology that captures carbon dioxide (CO2) from ship exhaust and converts it into stable, ocean-safe bicarbonate ions by reacting CO2 with limestone in a seawater-based reactor. The process mimics natural ocean carbon cycling but accelerates it, storing CO2 in dissolved form that is safely released into the ocean without disrupting pH balance or contributing to ocean acidification. The technology is designed for onboard use, allowing retrofitting onto existing ships with lower energy, cost, and infrastructure demands compared to traditional carbon capture and storage methods, and recently secured a collaboration with Lomar’s venture lab, lomarlabs, to accelerate testing and commercialization through maritime engineering and at-sea trials.
metadata.categories: Climate Technology, Carbon Capture, Maritime Industry

**Metadata:**

- Published: 2024-05-21
- Technology: Carbon Capture & Removal
- TRL: 6
- Dimension: Tech

**Summary (Indicator):**
Calcarea, a CalTech-founded start-up, has developed a direct air capture and removal technology that captures carbon dioxide (CO2) from ship exhaust and converts it into stable, ocean-safe bicarbonate ions by reacting CO2 with limestone in a seawater-based reactor. The process mimics natural ocean carbon cycling but accelerates it, storing CO2 in dissolved form that is safely released into the ocean without disrupting pH balance or contributing to ocean acidification. The technology is designed for onboard use, allowing retrofitting onto existing ships with lower energy, cost, and infrastructure demands compared to traditional carbon capture and storage methods, and recently secured a collaboration with Lomar’s venture lab, lomarlabs, to accelerate testing and commercialization through maritime engineering and at-sea trials.

metadata.title: Forests Removal New Xilva MONITOR Tool Detects Early Risks In Nature-Based And Forest CDR Projects
metadata.indicator: Swiss company Xilva has launched the Xilva MONITOR, a sophisticated monitoring tool designed to detect and mitigate risks in forest and nature-based carbon dioxide removal (CDR) projects by integrating satellite imagery, performance reports, and government watch lists to identify early warning signs across six risk categories: Impact, Financial Viability, Leadership & Team, Project Design, ESG Safeguards, and Growth Potential. The tool provides investors with structured progress reports, real-time alerts, and expert advisory support to address risks such as environmental hazards, compliance failures, or greenwashing, thereby enhancing transparency and accountability in nature-based CDR investments.
metadata.categories: Forest CDR, Risk Mitigation, Natural Climate Solutions

metadata.title: Ocean Removal Dutch Startup SeaO2 Secures Over $2M In Seed Funding For Its Direct Ocean Capture Tech
metadata.indicator: SeaO2, a Dutch startup based in Amsterdam, has secured over $2 million in seed funding to advance its Direct Ocean Capture (DOC) technology, which extracts carbon dioxide from seawater and returns filtered, CO2-free water to the ocean, enhancing the ocean’s natural ability to absorb atmospheric CO2. The funding comes from DOEN Participaties B.V., NEW-TTT, Future Tech Ventures, CarbonFix, and angel investors including Eduard Talman and Siddharth Kambe, and will support the transition from prototype to pilot deployment by 2025, with an expected annual removal capacity of 250 tons of CO2. The company aims to scale to removing one megaton of CO2 by 2030 and one gigaton by 2045, supported by partnerships with XPRIZE, TU Delft, Wetsus, and others, and will implement a Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (MRV) system for transparency and credibility.
metadata.categories: Climate Tech, Carbon Capture, Ocean Conservation

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal Utilization Soletair Power And Carbonaide Successfully Produce Concrete With Captured CO2
metadata.indicator: Soletair Power and Carbonaide have partnered to produce carbon-negative concrete by capturing CO2 from building ventilation systems and mineralizing it into concrete, effectively converting harmful emissions into a stable, long-term carbon sink. Soletair Power’s HVAC-integrated CO2 capturing unit captures up to 20 tons of CO2 annually per unit, while Carbonaide uses a VTT-originated mineralization technology to transform captured CO2 into low-carbon, carbon-negative concrete by combining it with low-carbon binders. The collaboration marks a significant step in decarbonizing the construction sector, reducing reliance on high-carbon cement and offering cost savings and compliance benefits under tightening EU ETS regulations.
metadata.categories: Decarbonization, Construction, Carbon Capture and Utilization

metadata.title: Investment Removal Startups Avnos Attracts Additional $36M In Series A To Expand HDAC™ Technology
metadata.indicator: Avnos, Inc., a Los Angeles-based direct air capture company, has secured $36 million in Series A funding to scale its HDAC™ technology, a hybrid system that simultaneously captures carbon dioxide and water from the atmosphere. The funds will support the expansion of HDAC assets across North America and Europe, the construction of a 20,000-square-foot R&D facility outside New York City, and the hiring of 20 new employees, with the lab expected to operate fully in February 2024. The financing was led by NextEra Energy Resources, with additional investment from Envisioning Partners and Rusheen Capital Management, and follows strategic partnerships with ConocoPhillips, JetBlue Technology Ventures, and Shell Ventures, as well as support from the U.S. Department of Energy and Office of Naval Research.
metadata.categories: Climate Technology, Carbon Capture, Renewable Energy

The funds will support the expansion of HDAC assets across North America and Europe, the construction of a 20,000-square-foot R&D facility outside New York City, and the hiring of 20 new employees, with the lab expected to operate fully in February 2024. The financing was led by NextEra Energy Resources, with additional investment from Envisioning Partners and Rusheen Capital Management, and follows strategic partnerships with ConocoPhillips, JetBlue Technology Ventures, and Shell Ventures, as well as support from the U.S. Department of Energy and Office of Naval Research.

metadata.title: Companies Press Release Removal Avnos Partners With Deep Sky For HDAC Deployment In Canada
metadata.indicator: Avnos, a Los Angeles-based company developing Hybrid Direct Air Capture (HDAC™) technology, has partnered with Deep Sky, a Montreal-based carbon removal developer, to deploy its HDAC system in Canada. The deployment will include a Hybrid DAC Air Handling Unit (AHU) at Deep Sky Labs in Quebec, capable of removing 450 tons of CO2 annually, marking Avnos’ first international project outside the U.S. Avnos’ HDAC technology uniquely captures both carbon dioxide and water from the atmosphere, using the captured water to regenerate moisture-responsive sorbents, reducing energy costs and offering economic and community benefits through water co-generation and local job creation.

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal DACLab Launches Kelvin – A New DAC System Stated To Be The Most Cost-Efficient So Far
metadata.indicator: Climate startup DACLab has launched the Kelvin Direct Air Capture (DAC) system, a cost-efficient technology that captures carbon dioxide from ambient air using a patent-pending Temperature Vacuum Swing Adsorption (TVSA) cycle, operating at as low as 70°C during regeneration—50% less energy than conventional DAC systems. The system achieves a capture cost of $500/tonne at 10,000 tonnes per year, with a projected reduction to $250/tonne at scale without subsidies, and has demonstrated continuous operation for over 2,000 hours on pilot units. It features a "moving-bed" design that optimizes adsorption and desorption phases, reducing pressure drop and enabling efficient, low-energy carbon removal with a proven energy demand below 1800 kWh per tonne of CO2 captured.
metadata.categories: Climate Technology, Carbon Capture, Environmental Innovation

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Removal New Study Looks Into The Role Of DAC Technology In Sustainable Aviation
metadata.indicator: A study by the Institute for Environmental Decisions in Zürich evaluates the potential of Direct Air Capture (DAC) technologies—specifically DACCS (capture and storage) and DACCU (capture and utilization)—to support climate-neutral aviation by 2050, with findings indicating that DACCU is more cost-effective for achieving climate neutrality due to its ability to mitigate non-CO2 effects like contrails through synthetic fuels, while DACCS remains cheaper for CO2 neutrality due to lower green hydrogen production costs. The research highlights that DACCU’s cost competitiveness is highly sensitive to electricity prices, fossil kerosene prices, policy support, and additional mitigation measures, and suggests a portfolio approach combining DAC with biofuels and other carbon dioxide removal (CDR) methods is essential for decarbonizing aviation.
metadata.categories: Environmental Research, Climate Change, Aviation, Carbon Capture Technology

The research highlights that DACCU’s cost competitiveness is highly sensitive to electricity prices, fossil kerosene prices, policy support, and additional mitigation measures, and suggests a portfolio approach combining DAC with biofuels and other carbon dioxide removal (CDR) methods is essential for decarbonizing aviation.

metadata.title: Article 6 Compliance Markets Verra And S&P Global Unveil Next-Generation Carbon Registry
metadata.indicator: Verra and S&P Global Commodity Insights are launching a next-generation carbon registry that merges Verra’s project hub with S&P Global’s Environmental Registry software, enhancing traceability, automation, and compliance with Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. The system will enable seamless, transparent credit tracking and prevent double-counting through integration with the Meta Registry®, significantly improving market integrity and efficiency. The platform aims to support Africa’s high-integrity climate projects—such as mangrove restoration and forest protection—by providing credible, verifiable mechanisms to attract international buyers and ensure community benefits.
metadata.categories: Environmental Markets, Climate Finance, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: BECCS Capture American Biogas Council Launches Carbon Accounting Tool For Biogas Projects
metadata.indicator: The American Biogas Council (ABC), in collaboration with EcoEngineers, has launched the Biogas Carbon Accounting Tool (Biogas CAT), a specialized tool that enables biogas project developers to accurately measure full lifecycle emissions, addressing gaps in existing carbon accounting systems like GREET, which primarily focuses on transportation fuels and overlooks biogas’s broader environmental benefits. The tool supports voluntary carbon markets by providing reliable, project-specific emissions data, allowing companies to meet climate reporting obligations and fairly value biogas as a low-carbon energy source.
metadata.categories: Biogas, Carbon Accounting, Environmental Technology, Climate Change

metadata.title: Capture Storage Carbon Storage Growth Rate Questioned By Imperial College Study
metadata.indicator: A new study by Imperial College London challenges existing projections for the pace of carbon storage deployment, arguing that current estimates of 1–30 gigatonnes of CO2 per year by 2050 are unfeasible. Using a novel modeling approach that incorporates geological suitability, institutional capacity, and growth patterns from industries like mining and renewables, the researchers propose a more realistic target of 6–16 gigatonnes per year. The study highlights the lack of governmental and international support as a key barrier to scaling up carbon storage, and emphasizes the need for more grounded, data-driven projections to inform climate policy.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Storage, Environmental Research

The study highlights the lack of governmental and international support as a key barrier to scaling up carbon storage, and emphasizes the need for more grounded, data-driven projections to inform climate policy.

metadata.title: Policy Removal Researchers Warn Of Legal Risks If We Rely Too Much On Carbon Removal
metadata.indicator: Researchers from the University of Oxford and Imperial College London warn that governments relying heavily on carbon dioxide removal (CDR) to meet climate targets may violate international law and face legal challenges, citing precedents like *Urgenda Foundation v. State of the Netherlands*. The study, published in *Science*, argues that overdependence on CDR—especially without substantial near-term emissions reductions—poses risks including leakage, overshooting climate goals, and land-use conflicts with agriculture, undermining commitments to "fair and ambitious" net-zero targets. It calls for urgent policy action to prioritize emissions cuts over future removals, warning that such reliance could become a focal point for climate litigation ahead of COP28.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Legal Risks, Carbon Removal, Environmental Law

State of the Netherlands*. The study, published in *Science*, argues that overdependence on CDR—especially without substantial near-term emissions reductions—poses risks including leakage, overshooting climate goals, and land-use conflicts with agriculture, undermining commitments to "fair and ambitious" net-zero targets. It calls for urgent policy action to prioritize emissions cuts over future removals, warning that such reliance could become a focal point for climate litigation ahead of COP28.

metadata.title: Capture Cory And Imperial College London Join Forces To Advance Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: Cory Group is partnering with Imperial College London to advance carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, combining Cory’s industrial expertise in waste management and energy recovery with Imperial’s leading academic research in chemical engineering. The collaboration centers on Cory’s Riverside energy-from-waste site in London, where it aims to capture 1.4 million metric tons of CO₂ annually from two facilities, transporting the captured carbon by ship to the Port of Immingham for storage in depleted gas fields—a potential first in CO₂ shipping. The initiative leverages Imperial’s four-floor Carbon Capture Pilot Plant to provide hands-on training and promote STEM education, while also addressing workforce development and the UK’s low-carbon transition.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, Environmental Technology, Sustainability, Research and Development

metadata.title: Capture Peak Cluster Taps Arup For Largest Cement Decarbonization Scheme
metadata.indicator: Arup has been appointed as lead consultant for the Peak Cluster project, a large-scale decarbonization initiative targeting the UK’s cement and lime sector, which accounts for over 3 million metric tons of annual CO₂ emissions. The project will install carbon capture units at facilities operated by Tarmac, Buxton Lime, Breedon, and Holcim, with captured CO₂ transported via an underground pipeline to Spirit Energy’s Morecambe Net Zero (MNZ) project in the Irish Sea for permanent storage in depleted reservoirs. The initiative includes comprehensive environmental impact assessments and development consent processes, supported by investment from the UK National Wealth Fund and aimed at creating low-carbon cement products while preserving regional jobs and advancing industrial decarbonization.
metadata.categories: Decarbonization, Cement Industry, Carbon Capture

metadata.title: Capture DNV Skylark Project Targets Safer CO2 Pipelines Expansion For Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: DNV is leading the Skylark project, a three-year joint industry initiative aimed at improving the safety of carbon dioxide (CO2) pipelines as carbon capture and storage (CCS) networks expand globally. The project, developed in collaboration with the UK Health and Safety Executive, University of Arkansas, Ricardo, NCAS, and the UK Department for Energy Security and Net Zero, conducts full-scale pipeline failure tests and wind tunnel experiments to study CO2 dispersion and crater formation under varied conditions. Results will inform risk assessments, refine dispersion models, and support the development of regulatory frameworks to ensure safe, large-scale deployment of CO2 pipelines.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Climate Change

metadata.title: Capture Opinion: Net Zero By 2050 May Be Out Of Reach, But The World Must Still Face Up To Its Carbon Challenge
metadata.indicator: DNV’s Energy Transition Outlook 2025 warns that achieving net zero global emissions by 2050 is no longer feasible, with the world instead projected to reach net zero around 2090, resulting in a 2.2°C global temperature rise. The report attributes this delay to persistent emissions from fossil fuels, slow decarbonisation in hard-to-abate sectors like steel and cement, and insufficient scaling of carbon capture and storage (CCS) and carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies. While CCS and BECCS are expected to grow significantly—capturing up to 2.6 GtCO₂ annually by 2060—these efforts will still fall short of offsetting emissions, and CDR technologies like direct air capture remain expensive and limited, at USD 350 per tonne by 2060.
metadata.categories: Energy Transition, Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Capture DNV And Shipbuilding Giants To Develop Onboard Carbon Capture Tech
metadata.indicator: DNV has partnered with HD Korea Shipbuilding and Offshore Engineering (HD KSOE) and HD Hydrogen to develop and validate Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) technology for carbon capture in marine environments, specifically integrating it with Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC). The joint effort, part of a Joint Industry Project (JIP), targets a 40% improvement in energy efficiency over traditional marine CO₂ absorption systems and aims to support maritime decarbonization by enabling onboard carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). This initiative responds to global emissions regulations and leverages the efficiency of SOFCs, which can operate on natural gas, ammonia, or hydrogen, to reduce carbon emissions in shipping operations.
metadata.categories: Maritime Industry, Carbon Capture Technology, Climate Change

metadata.title: Capture DNV And Shipbuilding Giants To Develop Onboard Carbon Capture Tech
metadata.indicator: DNV has partnered with HD Korea Shipbuilding and Offshore Engineering (HD KSOE) and HD Hydrogen to develop and validate Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) technology for carbon capture in marine environments, specifically integrating it with Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC). The joint effort, part of a Joint Industry Project (JIP), targets a 40% improvement in energy efficiency over traditional marine CO₂ absorption systems and aims to support maritime decarbonization by enabling onboard carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). This initiative responds to global emissions regulations and leverages the efficiency of SOFCs, which can operate on natural gas, ammonia, or hydrogen, to reduce carbon emissions in shipping operations.
metadata.categories: Maritime Industry, Carbon Capture Technology, Climate Change

__data__.text:
# Capture DNV And Shipbuilding Giants To Develop Onboard Carbon Capture Tech

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/dnv-and-shipbuilding-giants-to-develop-onboard-carbon-capture-tech
- Published: 2025-03-21
- Technology: Renewable
- TRL: 5
- Dimension: Tech

**Summary (Indicator):**
DNV has partnered with HD Korea Shipbuilding and Offshore Engineering (HD KSOE) and HD Hydrogen to develop and validate Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) technology for carbon capture in marine environments, specifically integrating it with Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC). The joint effort, part of a Joint Industry Project (JIP), targets a 40% improvement in energy efficiency over traditional marine CO₂ absorption systems and aims to support maritime decarbonization by enabling onboard carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). This initiative responds to global emissions regulations and leverages the efficiency of SOFCs, which can operate on natural gas, ammonia, or hydrogen, to reduce carbon emissions in shipping operations.

metadata.title: DNV: Carbon Capture Hits Inflection Point, Set To Quadruple By 2030
metadata.indicator: Global carbon capture and storage (CCS) is entering a critical growth phase, with DNV forecasting a fourfold increase in capture and storage capacity by 2030 and an annual global capture volume rising from 41 million to 1.3 billion metric tons by 2050—equivalent to 6% of global emissions. The expansion is being driven primarily by North America and Europe, with natural gas processing as the current dominant application, while long-term deployment will be essential for decarbonizing hard-to-abate industries like steel and cement, which are expected to account for 41% of total captured CO2 by 2050. Onboard carbon capture in shipping is projected to begin in the 2040s, and technologies like bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) are expected to dominate due to cost efficiency, while direct air capture (DAC), despite higher costs of $350 per ton, will contribute 84 million tons annually by 2050 through compliance and voluntary markets.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy Transition, Environmental Technologies

The expansion is being driven primarily by North America and Europe, with natural gas processing as the current dominant application, while long-term deployment will be essential for decarbonizing hard-to-abate industries like steel and cement, which are expected to account for 41% of total captured CO2 by 2050. Onboard carbon capture in shipping is projected to begin in the 2040s, and technologies like bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) are expected to dominate due to cost efficiency, while direct air capture (DAC), despite higher costs of $350 per ton, will contribute 84 million tons annually by 2050 through compliance and voluntary markets.

__data__.text:
# DNV: Carbon Capture Hits Inflection Point, Set To Quadruple By 2030

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/dnv-carbon-capture-hits-inflection-point-set-to-quadruple-by-2030
- Published: 2025-06-12
- TRL: 6
- Dimension: Env&S

**Summary (Indicator):**
Global carbon capture and storage (CCS) is entering a critical growth phase, with DNV forecasting a fourfold increase in capture and storage capacity by 2030 and an annual global capture volume rising from 41 million to 1.3 billion metric tons by 2050—equivalent to 6% of global emissions. The expansion is being driven primarily by North America and Europe, with natural gas processing as the current dominant application, while long-term deployment will be essential for decarbonizing hard-to-abate industries like steel and cement, which are expected to account for 41% of total captured CO2 by 2050. Onboard carbon capture in shipping is projected to begin in the 2040s, and technologies like bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) are expected to dominate due to cost efficiency, while direct air capture (DAC), despite higher costs of $350 per ton, will contribute 84 million tons annually by 2050 through compliance and voluntary markets.

metadata.title: Capture DNV Inspection To Oversee Quality For Two Pioneering UK CCS Projects
metadata.indicator: DNV Inspection has been appointed to provide quality assurance, site inspections, and on-the-ground support for two pioneering UK carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects: Net Zero Teesside Power (NZT Power) and the Northern Endurance Partnership (NEP). The contracts cover verification of equipment and materials against strict industry standards as the projects transition from construction to operation, with NZT Power aiming to become the world’s first gas-fired power station with integrated carbon capture, delivering up to 742 megawatts of low-carbon electricity. NEP, a joint venture between bp, Equinor, and TotalEnergies, is developing offshore pipelines and facilities to transport captured CO2 from Teesside and Humber to North Sea storage sites.
metadata.categories: Energy Transition, Carbon Capture and Storage, UK Energy Infrastructure

The contracts cover verification of equipment and materials against strict industry standards as the projects transition from construction to operation, with NZT Power aiming to become the world’s first gas-fired power station with integrated carbon capture, delivering up to 742 megawatts of low-carbon electricity. NEP, a joint venture between bp, Equinor, and TotalEnergies, is developing offshore pipelines and facilities to transport captured CO2 from Teesside and Humber to North Sea storage sites.

metadata.title: Opinion: Crunch Time In The UK’s Quest To Collar Its Carbon Emissions
metadata.indicator: The UK is advancing its carbon capture, utilisation, and storage (CCUS) initiatives, with key projects like the Northern Endurance Partnership and Net Zero Teesside Power securing final investment decisions, but current capacity is far below target—projected at just 5 MtCO2/year by 2030 versus a government goal of 20–30 MtCO2/year. Delays in Track 1 cluster developments and inconsistent policy support have undermined progress, while carbon prices remain low, with emissions from fossil fuels still cheaper than capture costs until the mid-2030s. Despite £21.7 billion in government funding and a growing pipeline, the sector faces significant implementation gaps, risking missed carbon budgets and failure to meet its 2050 net-zero pledge.
metadata.categories: Energy Transition, Carbon Capture and Storage, UK Climate Policy, Renewable Energy

__data__.text:
# Opinion: Crunch Time In The UK’s Quest To Collar Its Carbon Emissions

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/opinion-crunch-time-in-the-uks-quest-to-collar-its-carbon-emissions
- Published: 2025-03-21
- TRL: 5
- Dimension: Env&S

**Summary (Indicator):**
The UK is advancing its carbon capture, utilisation, and storage (CCUS) initiatives, with key projects like the Northern Endurance Partnership and Net Zero Teesside Power securing final investment decisions, but current capacity is far below target—projected at just 5 MtCO2/year by 2030 versus a government goal of 20–30 MtCO2/year. Delays in Track 1 cluster developments and inconsistent policy support have undermined progress, while carbon prices remain low, with emissions from fossil fuels still cheaper than capture costs until the mid-2030s. Despite £21.7 billion in government funding and a growing pipeline, the sector faces significant implementation gaps, risking missed carbon budgets and failure to meet its 2050 net-zero pledge.

metadata.title: The Vita Group Receives Outstanding Platinum EcoVadis Rating
metadata.indicator: The Vita Group, a UK-based foam manufacturer, has earned a platinum EcoVadis sustainability rating, scoring 83 out of 100 and ranking in the top 1% of global companies assessed by the benchmarking platform. This recognition is based on evaluations across environmental, labor, ethical, and procurement practices, with a key innovation being its Orbis sustainable foam, which uses recycled raw materials from end-of-life foams to achieve a closed-loop circular model in flexible polyurethane production. The company has also developed a custom Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) tool to enhance supply chain transparency and align supplier performance with sustainability goals.
metadata.categories: Technology, Sustainability, EcoVadis, Corporate Social Responsibility

metadata.title: Companies Sublime Systems Taps Industry Veteran Rob Davies As CEO To Lead Commercial Expansion
metadata.indicator: Sublime Systems, a Massachusetts-based startup developing low-carbon cement through electrochemical technology, has appointed Rob Davies, a veteran with 30+ years in industrial manufacturing and cement operations, as its new CEO to drive commercial expansion. Davies, formerly of Blue Circle, Lafarge, and Holcim, joins from a role as Chief Operating Officer and brings extensive experience in scaling industrial technologies, while co-founder Dr. Leah Ellis remains involved to support the transition. The company has secured a multi-year deal with Microsoft for up to 622,500 metric tons of Sublime Cement® and received $75 million in funding from global cement giants Holcim and CRH to advance pilot production and plant expansion.
metadata.categories: Industry Leadership, Construction Materials, Low-Carbon Technology

metadata.title: Companies Markets Removal Developing Countries Call On SBTi To Push For Companies To Be Able To Use Carbon Offsets
metadata.indicator: A group of 10 West African countries, including Burkina Faso, Senegal, and Ghana, has urged the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBTi) to allow corporations to use carbon offsets—particularly for Scope 3 emissions—to meet their net-zero goals, arguing that such mechanisms are essential for financing climate and conservation initiatives in developing nations. The request comes amid growing debate over the credibility and transparency of carbon offset projects, with the UN Secretary-General warning against "dubious carbon offsets" that fail to deliver real climate benefits. SBTi has acknowledged the possibility of allowing offsets under strict rules, but experts emphasize the need for scientific validation and clear accountability to prevent greenwashing and ensure that offset projects genuinely contribute to emission reductions.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Environmental Policy, Sustainability

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/developing-countries-call-on-sbti-to-push-for-companies-to-be-able-to-use-carbon-offsets
- Published: 2024-06-11
- TRL: 5
- Dimension: Social&E

**Summary (Indicator):**
A group of 10 West African countries, including Burkina Faso, Senegal, and Ghana, has urged the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBTi) to allow corporations to use carbon offsets—particularly for Scope 3 emissions—to meet their net-zero goals, arguing that such mechanisms are essential for financing climate and conservation initiatives in developing nations. The request comes amid growing debate over the credibility and transparency of carbon offset projects, with the UN Secretary-General warning against "dubious carbon offsets" that fail to deliver real climate benefits. SBTi has acknowledged the possibility of allowing offsets under strict rules, but experts emphasize the need for scientific validation and clear accountability to prevent greenwashing and ensure that offset projects genuinely contribute to emission reductions.

metadata.title: Companies Ocean Removal Equatic Gears Up For Gigaton CO2 Removal Scale With New Leadership
metadata.indicator: Ocean-based carbon removal company Equatic is scaling up to achieve gigaton-level CO2 removal by appointing Edward Sanders as CEO and Jarred W. Guthrie as Chief Project Officer, with Sanders bringing experience in climate and commercial operations and Guthrie expertise in renewable energy and hydrogen projects. The company is reinforcing its technical and strategic oversight with the addition of Dame Dervilla Mitchell to its Industry Advisory Board and establishing a first-ever Science Advisory Board of eight academic and public sector experts to ensure responsible and high-quality carbon removal. Equatic aims to deliver the world’s largest ocean-based CO2 removal plant, targeting cost-effective carbon removal at under $30 per tonne by the end of the decade.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Removal, Ocean Technology, Renewable Energy

metadata.title: Aon Unveils Industry-First Insurance For Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: Aon has launched the industry's first international insurance product tailored for carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects, addressing key financial and operational risks associated with transporting and storing CO₂. The policy, developed over 18 months with collaboration from leading underwriters and legal experts, provides comprehensive coverage across construction, asset repurposing, and operational phases of CCS projects. The product supports major energy players like Eni UK, bp, Equinor, and TotalEnergies through the HyNet North West and Northern Endurance Partnership initiatives, helping to de-risk investment and promote net-zero ambitions in energy and industrial sectors.
metadata.categories: Environmental, Insurance, Energy

metadata.title: Markets Removal Uncategorized Swiss Re And Goodcarbon Introduce Pioneering Insurance For Carbon Credit Investments
metadata.indicator: Swiss Re and goodcarbon have launched a first-of-its-kind insurance product for 5-year forward carbon credit portfolios, offering “in-kind replacements” or refunds to investors if carbon credits fail to deliver promised emissions reductions. The insurance covers non-delivery risks from political instability, natural catastrophes, and weather events, with initial focus on afforestation and reforestation projects. By pooling a small percentage of credits into a buffer mechanism and providing refunds if the buffer is insufficient, the product enhances investor confidence and addresses key market risks in nature-based carbon removal.
metadata.categories: Finance, Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Insurance

metadata.title: Capture Companies Press Release Aker Carbon Capture Secures Pre-FEED Contract From Statkraft
metadata.indicator: Aker Carbon Capture has secured a pre-FEED contract with Statkraft to implement carbon capture at the Heimdal waste-to-energy facility in Trondheim, Norway, targeting the capture of approximately 220,000 tons of CO2 annually—potentially reducing Trondheim’s CO2 emissions by 25%. The project will involve full engineering design for carbon dioxide compression, purification, liquefaction, temporary storage, and potential transportation to permanent geological storage. This collaboration marks a significant advancement in integrating carbon capture into waste-to-energy operations, supporting Norway’s goal of a 55% emissions reduction by 2030 and demonstrating a scalable model for decarbonizing industrial sectors.
metadata.categories: Environment, Climate Change, Renewable Energy, Carbon Capture

metadata.title: Capture Companies Investment Captura Gets Two New Investors, Reaches $45.3M In Series A Funding
metadata.indicator: Direct ocean capture (DOC) startup Captura has secured $45.3 million in Series A funding, with new investors National Grid Partners and Japan Airlines Innovation Fund joining existing backers. The company’s technology directly extracts carbon dioxide from seawater, leveraging the ocean’s natural carbon absorption capacity without adding chemicals or by-products, offering a cost-effective and environmentally sustainable approach to carbon removal. With two operational pilot plants in California and a planned facility in Norway in partnership with Equinor, Captura aims to remove tens of thousands of tons of CO2 annually, with potential for CO2 reuse in low-carbon fuel production to support hard-to-abate sectors like aviation and shipping.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Capture and Storage, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Heidelberg Materials Announces Milestone With The Edmonton Carbon Capture Project
metadata.indicator: Heidelberg Materials North America has awarded front-end engineering design (FEED) contracts to MHI-LCSC (a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries) and Kiewit for the development of carbon capture technology at its Edmonton, Alberta CCUS project, marking a key milestone toward deploying the world’s first full-scale net-zero cement plant. The project will utilize MHI’s Advanced KM CDR Process™ with the KS-21™ solvent, designed in collaboration with Kansai Electric Power Co., Inc., to capture and store up to 1 million metric tons of CO₂ annually—equivalent to removing 220,000 cars from roads. The initiative represents a pioneering effort in the cement industry to achieve carbon neutrality through carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), with a final investment decision expected in 2024 pending federal and provincial funding agreements.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Sustainable Industry

metadata.title: Heidelberg Materials Announces Milestone With The Edmonton Carbon Capture Project
metadata.indicator: Heidelberg Materials North America has awarded front-end engineering design (FEED) contracts to MHI-LCSC (a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries) and Kiewit for the development of carbon capture technology at its Edmonton, Alberta CCUS project, marking a key milestone toward deploying the world’s first full-scale net-zero cement plant. The project will utilize MHI’s Advanced KM CDR Process™ with the KS-21™ solvent, designed in collaboration with Kansai Electric Power Co., Inc., to capture and store up to 1 million metric tons of CO₂ annually—equivalent to removing 220,000 cars from roads. The initiative represents a pioneering effort in the cement industry to achieve carbon neutrality through carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), with a final investment decision expected in 2024 pending federal and provincial funding agreements.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Sustainable Industry

**Summary (Indicator):**

The project will utilize MHI’s Advanced KM CDR Process™ with the KS-21™ solvent, designed in collaboration with Kansai Electric Power Co., Inc., to capture and store up to 1 million metric tons of CO₂ annually—equivalent to removing 220,000 cars from roads. The initiative represents a pioneering effort in the cement industry to achieve carbon neutrality through carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), with a final investment decision expected in 2024 pending federal and provincial funding agreements.

metadata.title: Capture Companies Exterra, Énergir Join Forces To Advance Carbon Sequestration In Quebec
metadata.indicator: Exterra Carbon Solutions, a Quebec-based startup, has formed a strategic partnership with Énergir Development to advance carbon capture and sequestration efforts, leveraging Exterra’s innovative technology that uses mining residues to store carbon dioxide (CO2). The collaboration aims to develop decarbonization solutions for high-emission industries like aluminum smelters and cement factories, with a pilot project currently sequestering 300 tons of CO2 annually and targeting a 3,000-ton pre-commercial demonstration plant by 2025. By 2026, Exterra plans to launch Hub 1, the world’s largest surface-based CO2 sequestration site, capable of removing emissions equivalent to 100,000 gasoline vehicles annually.
metadata.categories: Environmental Technology, Carbon Capture and Sequestration, Renewable Energy, Industrial Decarbonization

metadata.title: Companies Markets Removal ClimateHQ Releases Its First Report Revealing Key Corporate Climate Action Data by Petya Trendafilova
metadata.indicator: ClimateHQ, a new market intelligence startup, has released its first report analyzing corporate climate action data for 100 U.S. Fortune 100 companies with revenues exceeding $11 trillion, examining their sustainability reports, net zero targets, and voluntary carbon market activities. The report reveals that only 33 of the 100 companies have set a net zero target, with 11 having pending SBTI commitments, and highlights a stark disparity in financial performance per ton of CO2 emitted—commercial banks and financials earn $39,942 per ton, while oil, mining, and refining sectors earn just $329 per ton. The analysis leverages over one million data points across 99 reports and covers more than 50,000 companies and 20,000 sustainability reports, offering a comprehensive view of corporate climate commitments and emissions transparency.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Corporate Sustainability, Carbon Markets

The report reveals that only 33 of the 100 companies have set a net zero target, with 11 having pending SBTI commitments, and highlights a stark disparity in financial performance per ton of CO2 emitted—commercial banks and financials earn $39,942 per ton, while oil, mining, and refining sectors earn just $329 per ton. The analysis leverages over one million data points across 99 reports and covers more than 50,000 companies and 20,000 sustainability reports, offering a comprehensive view of corporate climate commitments and emissions transparency.

metadata.title: Carbon Accounting Companies Watershed Introduces Specialized Software For EU CSRD Reporting
metadata.indicator: Enterprise climate software platform Watershed has launched Watershed for CSRD, a specialized software solution designed to help companies comply with the European Union’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which mandates comprehensive ESG disclosures and aligns sustainability data with financial reporting standards. The tool enables organizations to collect, calculate, and manage over 1,100 ESG data points, identify reporting gaps, and ensure audit readiness, while integrating with frameworks like CDP and TCFD. It is already deployed in leading global firms and supports the upcoming 2024–2025 CSRD reporting wave, marking a key development in standardized, transparent, and leadership-driven ESG reporting.
metadata.categories: Sustainability, Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG), Climate Reporting

metadata.title: Artio Secures $709,000 To Revolutionize Early-Stage Carbon Insurance
metadata.indicator: Climate insurtech startup Artio has raised £550k (~$709k) to develop insurance products for early-stage carbon removal projects using a proprietary risk modelling platform, addressing the delivery and financing risks that prevent investment in these high-potential but uncertain projects. The funding, led by Lifetime Ventures and co-invested by SFC Capital, will accelerate product development and support the launch of its first carbon removal insurance products in early 2025, in partnership with Lloyd’s Lab. By providing risk mitigation from day one, Artio aims to boost investor confidence and scale high-integrity carbon credits essential for net-zero commitments.
metadata.categories: Climate Tech, Insurance, Carbon Markets

metadata.indicator: remove has launched Cohort 7 of its Europe Accelerator Program, selecting eight carbon dioxide removal (CDR) startups—including Octavia Carbon, Atmosfuture, SuperDAC, Bloomineral, and neo-fossil—to receive mentorship and operational guidance over five months. The cohort spans direct air capture (DAC), carbon mineralization, biochar, climate fintech, and insurance, with innovations such as Atmosfuture’s Reverse Fractionation of Carbon Capture (REVFRACC) using liquid nitrogen to liquefy and repurpose CO2 and nitrogen, and Octavia Carbon building the first DAC facility in the Global South in Kenya. Selected startups will receive expertise in policy, life cycle assessment, fundraising, and IP management, with a focus on scaling CDR technologies in Europe and beyond.

metadata.title: Markets Artio Launches Carbon Insurance With Lloyd’s Coverholder Status
metadata.indicator: Artio, a carbon project insurance firm founded by Bilal Hussain and Ibrahim Sarwar, has been granted Lloyd’s coverholder status, enabling it to issue insurance policies for early-phase carbon projects before any activities begin. Backed by major insurers including Tokio Marine HCC, Markel, and Apollo, Artio offers a data-driven risk assessment model that evaluates financial, climatic, political, and technical risks to underwrite projects at inception, addressing a critical gap in the carbon market. The company currently insures afforestation, reforestation, and biochar projects and plans to expand into direct air capture and enhanced rock weathering in 2025.
metadata.categories: Finance, Climate Change, Insurance, Carbon Markets

metadata.title: Markets Removal Gold Standard Releases Framework For High-Integrity Engineered Carbon Removals
metadata.indicator: Gold Standard has released the Engineered Removals Activity Requirements, a new framework to certify high-integrity carbon dioxide removal (CDR) projects through rigorous scientific and stakeholder validation. The framework mandates safeguards for sustainable development, buffer contributions, and reversal risk mitigation, and aligns with international standards including the EU Carbon Removal Certification Framework, CORSIA, and Article 6.4 of the Paris Agreement. It supports projects such as accelerated carbonation of concrete aggregate, carbon mineralisation using reactive mineral waste, and biomass fermentation with carbon capture and geologic storage, with at least three Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) required per project.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Removal, Voluntary Carbon Market

metadata.title: Markets Removal ICVCM Approves Six New Carbon Removal Methodologies
metadata.indicator: The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) has approved six engineered carbon dioxide removal (CDR) methodologies, including Gold Standard’s Accelerated Carbonation of Concrete Aggregate and Isometric’s Biomass Geological Storage, Bio-oil Geological Storage, Subsurface Biomass Carbon Removal, Biogenic Carbon Capture and Storage, and Direct Air Capture. These methodologies now qualify for CCP-labelled credits, with Isometric’s frameworks already supporting 24 registered projects and potential annual issuance of over 3.2 million credits, while Gold Standard’s approach could generate more than 9,000 credits annually. Additionally, two land-based methods—CAR Mexico Forest Protocol v3 and VM0047 v1.1—received full approval, expanding eligibility for forest and reforestation projects with potential for nearly 10 million annual credits.
metadata.categories: Carbon Removal, Climate Policy, Voluntary Carbon Market

metadata.title: Markets Ecuador Partners With Gold Standard To Advance National Carbon Offset Program
metadata.indicator: Ecuador has formalized a partnership with Gold Standard to advance its national carbon offset program, PECC (Ecuador Carbono Cero – PECC), through a two-year Memorandum of Understanding signed by the Ministry of Environment, Water, and Ecological Transition (MAATE). The collaboration aims to establish credible carbon offset standards, address procedural gaps, develop certification protocols, and build local auditor capacity, all aligned with international best practices and the Paris Agreement. The partnership strengthens Ecuador’s Zero Carbon Program by integrating transparent, internationally recognized verification mechanisms into its climate strategy.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Offset, International Collaboration

metadata.title: Markets Xpansiv Introduces Spot Contract to Boost CORSIA Trading
metadata.indicator: Xpansiv has launched the CBL GEO® CORSIA Phase 1 (GEO CP1) standardized spot contract, enabling trading of CORSIA-eligible emissions units (EEUs) on its CBL Spot Exchange and through affiliated platforms including the Aviation Carbon Exchange (ACE) and the JSE Ventures Carbon Market. The contract aligns with ICAO’s CORSIA compliance framework and offers standardized, transparent access to EEUs from registries such as ART TREES, ACR, Climate Action Reserve, Gold Standard, and Verra, with an innovative sub-account system allowing participants to trade without requiring primary registry accounts. The launch follows ICAO’s approval of new methodologies and responds to market demand for 100–150 million tons of EEUs in the first compliance phase (2024–2026), while addressing procedural delays in issuing Letters of Authorization that have previously hampered compliance.
metadata.categories: Carbon Markets, Climate Neutrality, Energy Transition

metadata.title: Markets Nonprofits Urge EU To Include International Flights Emissions In Carbon Market
metadata.indicator: Two major climate nonprofits, Opportunity Green and Carbon Market Watch, are urging the European Union to include international flight emissions in its Emissions Trading System (ETS), ending a 2012 exemption that allowed over 1.1 billion tonnes of CO2—equivalent to more than Greece’s total emissions—to go unregulated. They argue that the current global aviation offset mechanism, CORSIA, is ineffective and that the EU must act decisively during its 2026 ETS review to reclaim climate leadership and put a price on aviation pollution. The nonprofits highlight that this exemption resulted in $30 billion in lost climate revenue and warn against succumbing to pressure from the U.S. and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), which they say failed to act for over three decades.

# Markets Nonprofits Urge EU To Include International Flights Emissions In Carbon Market

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/nonprofits-urge-eu-to-include-international-flights-emissions-in-carbon-market
- Published: 2025-06-25
- TRL: 6
- Dimension: Pol

**Summary (Indicator):**
Two major climate nonprofits, Opportunity Green and Carbon Market Watch, are urging the European Union to include international flight emissions in its Emissions Trading System (ETS), ending a 2012 exemption that allowed over 1.1 billion tonnes of CO2—equivalent to more than Greece’s total emissions—to go unregulated. They argue that the current global aviation offset mechanism, CORSIA, is ineffective and that the EU must act decisively during its 2026 ETS review to reclaim climate leadership and put a price on aviation pollution. The nonprofits highlight that this exemption resulted in $30 billion in lost climate revenue and warn against succumbing to pressure from the U.S. and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), which they say failed to act for over three decades.

metadata.title: Markets Removal Vietnam To Join Global Aviation Carbon Offset Scheme By 2026
metadata.indicator: Vietnam will join the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) beginning January 1, 2026, marking its commitment to achieving carbon-neutral growth in international aviation through market-based mechanisms. The Civil Aviation Authority of Vietnam (CAAV) has submitted a formal proposal to the Ministry of Construction and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), having already implemented a Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (MRV) system for aviation CO2 emissions and established regulations for fuel use and emissions tracking. Vietnam’s participation aligns with its broader climate goals and signals readiness for the mandatory CORSIA phase beginning in 2027, with annual carbon offset expenditures estimated between USD 5.6 million and USD 37.5 million.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Aviation, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Markets Removal Isometric Receives Landmark ICAO Approval To Issue Credits Under CORSIA
metadata.indicator: Isometric, a carbon registry, has received landmark approval from the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) to issue carbon dioxide removal credits under the CORSIA framework, a globally mandated program requiring airlines to offset emissions above 2019 levels. The approval recognizes Isometric’s adherence to high standards of transparency, integrity, and scientific rigor, making it one of a select group of registries authorized to issue verified carbon removal credits. This milestone enables airlines to access credible, science-based carbon removals, with British Airways highlighting its role as the largest global buyer of such credits and planning for a third of its future emissions reductions to come from removals.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Carbon Markets, Aviation
