metadata.title: Markets Voluntary TEM’s Papua New Guinea Cookstove Project First To Earn Credits Under Verra’s VM0050
metadata.indicator: Tasman Environmental Markets (TEM) has achieved a landmark milestone by becoming the first organization to issue Verified Carbon Units (VCUs) under Verra’s VM0050 methodology in Papua New Guinea, where its "Healthier Homes, Healthier Forests" cookstove project delivers improved cookstoves to households in the Southern Highlands at no cost. The project reduces indoor air pollution, decreases firewood consumption, and prevents nearly 3 million tonnes of CO2 emissions over ten years, while also supporting deforestation reduction and community health. The initiative, supported by local governments and PNG’s Climate Change and Development Authority, aims to distribute 200,000 stoves to reach 50,000 households by 2026, aligning with PNG’s Nationally Determined Contribution and delivering co-benefits in social and economic development.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Credits, Renewable Energy, Community Projects

metadata.title: Markets New Study Suggests Carbon Credits From Cookstoves Are Worthless
metadata.indicator: A peer-reviewed study by UC Berkeley researchers reveals that cookstove-based carbon credits in the voluntary carbon market (VCM) are significantly overstated, with emissions avoided being 9.2 times lower than claimed—despite representing 20% of all VCM credits. The study scrutinized 40% of these cookstove projects and found systemic flaws in emission measurement, raising concerns about the credibility of carbon offsetting in the sector. While major registries like Verra and Gold Standard have responded with criticism and plans to improve methodologies, the findings have prompted major buyers—including British Airways and easyJet—to pause or halt purchases, underscoring the market’s growing instability.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Environmental Policy

# Markets New Study Suggests Carbon Credits From Cookstoves Are Worthless

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/new-study-suggests-carbon-credits-from-cookstoves-are-worthless
- Published: 2024-01-25
- TRL: 5
- Dimension: Env&S

**Summary (Indicator):**
A peer-reviewed study by UC Berkeley researchers reveals that cookstove-based carbon credits in the voluntary carbon market (VCM) are significantly overstated, with emissions avoided being 9.2 times lower than claimed—despite representing 20% of all VCM credits. The study scrutinized 40% of these cookstove projects and found systemic flaws in emission measurement, raising concerns about the credibility of carbon offsetting in the sector. While major registries like Verra and Gold Standard have responded with criticism and plans to improve methodologies, the findings have prompted major buyers—including British Airways and easyJet—to pause or halt purchases, underscoring the market’s growing instability.

metadata.title: Article 6 Markets Zimbabwe Breaks Ground With Carbon Credits With Corresponding Adjustments Under Article 6
metadata.indicator: Zimbabwe has launched the first private-sector-generated Article 6 carbon credits with Corresponding Adjustments (CAs) through the Gold Standard registry, driven by a clean cookstove project led by Cicada Carbon, a member of the Zimbabwe Carbon Association. The project generated 112,000 CAs, with up to 3 million projected over five years, marking a global first in private-sector CAs and positioning Zimbabwe to access international compliance markets like CORSIA. The CA mechanism ensures no double-counting of emissions reductions, and if approved, the project could become only the second globally to meet CORSIA eligibility, following Guyana’s REDD+ initiative.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Markets, Environmental Policy

metadata.title: Direct Air Capture Markets Removal Aviation Industry Turns To CDR In Race To Net Zero By 2050
metadata.indicator: The aviation industry is increasingly turning to carbon dioxide removal (CDR) technologies, particularly direct air capture (DAC), to address residual emissions in its path to net zero by 2050, with IATA’s new 2025 guide outlining the role of DAC and other CDR methods like bio-based and enhanced rock weathering solutions. The guide, co-developed with Climeworks, highlights how captured CO₂ can be used in power-to-liquid (PtL) fuel production and emphasizes the growing market for CDR credits, including their certification and trading mechanisms. Despite challenges around scalability, cost, and regulatory alignment, the report signals a rising trend in market activity and calls for coordinated efforts across airlines, technology providers, financiers, and regulators to advance CDR adoption.
metadata.categories: Aviation, Carbon Removal, Climate Change, Sustainable Aviation

metadata.title: Capture Storage CATF Roadmap Charts Cost-Effective CCS Deployment For Central and Eastern Europe
metadata.indicator: A new policy brief by the Clean Air Task Force (CATF) outlines a strategic roadmap for reducing the cost of carbon capture and storage (CCS) deployment in Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) through coordinated government action, including alignment of capture, transport, and storage planning, blending EU and national funding mechanisms, and supporting early-stage projects. The report highlights that developing regional CO2 storage could cut transport and storage costs by up to 48%, and avoid annual subsidies of up to €23.5 million for a 500,000-metric-ton CO2 project without domestic storage. CATF recommends that CEE governments prioritize policy clarity, permitting efficiency, and revenue certainty to de-risk CCS investment and ensure industrial decarbonization without sacrificing competitiveness or jobs.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Storage, European Energy, Industrial Decarbonization

metadata.title: Capture Companies Technip Energies To Direct FEED Phase For Viking CCS Project
metadata.indicator: Technip Energies has been appointed to lead the front-end engineering design (FEED) phase for the Viking Link CCS project in the UK, responsible for designing the CO2 transportation system. This marks a critical step toward a final investment decision in Q1 2025, with the project aiming to capture and store 10 million tonnes of CO2 annually by 2030—equivalent to one-third of the UK’s overall CCS target. The initiative, led by Harbour Energy and BP, will transport CO2 from the Humber region to depleted Viking gas fields, with a total storage capacity of 300 million tonnes and potential to generate £7 billion in investment and £4 billion in gross value added to the local economy.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy, UK, Climate Change

metadata.title: Capture Policy Storage Utilization Malaysia Enacts CCUS Act 2025 With Royal Endorsement
metadata.indicator: Malaysia has enacted the Carbon Capture, Utilization and Storage (CCUS) Act 2025 with royal assent, establishing a comprehensive legal framework for the capture, transport, reuse, and long-term storage of carbon dioxide. The legislation aims to mitigate climate change impacts while promoting the development of Malaysia’s carbon management sector as a catalyst for economic growth. The law was approved during the First Meeting of the Fourth Session of the 15th Parliament and formally announced with endorsement from Sultan Ibrahim.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Climate Change, Legislation, Malaysia

metadata.title: Capture Storage Petronas CEO Sees Carbon Capture As Future Revenue Stream
metadata.indicator: Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned energy company, is positioning carbon capture and storage (CCS) as a future revenue stream, with CEO Tengku Muhammad Taufik Tengku Aziz highlighting the company's efforts to advance low-carbon technologies. The firm is also preparing Malaysia to handle liquefied natural gas imports, while the government has introduced a CCUS Bill to establish a competitive levy and support carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) infrastructure. The bill, set for a second reading in Parliament, marks a significant step toward Malaysia's leadership in low-carbon energy solutions.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Malaysia

metadata.title: Capture Energy Can Carbon Capture Clean Up Natural Gas For The Data Center Boom?
metadata.indicator: A new whitepaper by Carbon Direct proposes natural gas with carbon capture and storage (CCS) as a cost-competitive, rapidly deployable solution to meet the surging electricity demand of U.S. data centers, with captured CO₂ being stored in geologic formations. The model offers a “capture-commited” approach—delivering clean power within 18 months, followed by full decarbonization within 18–24 months—enabling rapid deployment without sacrificing emissions goals. At $70–$100 per MWh, CCS for natural gas competes with new nuclear, and retrofitting existing plants could reduce costs to $40–$60/MWh, leveraging existing infrastructure and federal incentives like the Inflation Reduction Act’s 45Q tax credit. However, the strategy is highly policy-dependent, with risks of increased costs and project delays if key incentives like 45Q are repealed, and a growing capability gap among utilities and corporate buyers limits in-house development.
metadata.categories: Energy, Decarbonization, Natural Gas, Carbon Capture and Storage, Data Centers

metadata.title: Capture Policy Singapore Backs Carbon Capture To Cut Power Sector Emissions
metadata.indicator: Singapore’s Energy Market Authority (EMA) has awarded co-funding to five feasibility studies on carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, selected from three local power companies—Keppel, PacificLight Power, and YTL PowerSeraya. The projects explore two CCS approaches: post-combustion capture at natural gas power plants and pre-combustion capture during hydrogen production, both aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions from power generation. The initiative, launched in October 2024 with a completion target of 2026, will assess technical viability, infrastructure needs, and site-specific requirements to support future large-scale deployment.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy Innovation, Singapore

metadata.title: Capture Policy Singapore Backs Carbon Capture To Cut Power Sector Emissions
metadata.indicator: Singapore’s Energy Market Authority (EMA) has awarded co-funding to five feasibility studies on carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, selected from three local power companies—Keppel, PacificLight Power, and YTL PowerSeraya. The projects explore two CCS approaches: post-combustion capture at natural gas power plants and pre-combustion capture during hydrogen production, both aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions from power generation. The initiative, launched in October 2024 with a completion target of 2026, will assess technical viability, infrastructure needs, and site-specific requirements to support future large-scale deployment.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Capture and Storage, Energy Innovation, Singapore

__data__.text:
# Capture Policy Singapore Backs Carbon Capture To Cut Power Sector Emissions

**Metadata:**
- URL: https://carbonherald.com/singapore-backs-carbon-capture-to-cut-power-sector-emissions
- Published: 2025-07-17
- TRL: 4
- Dimension: Pol

**Summary (Indicator):**
Singapore’s Energy Market Authority (EMA) has awarded co-funding to five feasibility studies on carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, selected from three local power companies—Keppel, PacificLight Power, and YTL PowerSeraya. The projects explore two CCS approaches: post-combustion capture at natural gas power plants and pre-combustion capture during hydrogen production, both aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions from power generation. The initiative, launched in October 2024 with a completion target of 2026, will assess technical viability, infrastructure needs, and site-specific requirements to support future large-scale deployment.

metadata.title: UAE Researchers Turn Used Coffee Grounds Into Carbon Capture Material
metadata.indicator: Researchers at the University of Sharjah in the UAE have developed a patented carbon capture technology that transforms spent coffee grounds and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic waste into a high-surface-area activated carbon using potassium hydroxide as an activating agent. The process, involving co-pyrolysis of coffee and plastic waste, produces a porous material capable of efficiently adsorbing carbon dioxide from industrial flue gases, offering a low-cost, circular economy solution that tackles both waste management and carbon emissions.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Carbon Capture, Waste Management, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture Energy Storage Carbon TerraVault And Net Power Partner For 1GW Natural Gas California Project With Carbon Capture
metadata.indicator: California Resources Corporation and Carbon TerraVault have entered a partnership with Net Power Inc. to develop up to 1 GW of ultra-low emission natural gas power plants in Northern California, leveraging Net Power’s modular, near-zero-emission power technology and CTV’s existing underground carbon storage vaults for permanent CO₂ sequestration. The collaboration aims to reduce transportation and midstream costs by siting the plants near CTV’s storage reservoirs, with the potential to capture up to 3.6 MMTPA of CO₂ annually and support 2.1 GW of new low-carbon power capacity in the state.
metadata.categories: Energy Storage, Carbon Capture, Natural Gas, Power Generation, Environmental Technology

metadata.title: Capture Fuels BASF And Forestal Pave Way For E-Methanol Via CO2 Capture
metadata.indicator: BASF and Spanish chemicals company Forestal del Atlántico have launched an early disclosure agreement to develop a pilot-scale e-methanol production facility in Galicia, Spain, using BASF’s OASE blue gas technology to capture carbon dioxide from flue gases. The captured CO2 will be converted into e-methanol through reaction with renewable hydrogen, with the Triskelion project targeting 156 metric tons of e-methanol per day, scalable to 40,000 tons annually. The project, expected to begin operations in January 2028, will support front-end engineering design and assess both technical and economic viability of sustainable fuel production.
metadata.categories: Energy, Carbon Capture, Sustainable Fuels, Chemicals

metadata.title: Capture Markets Houston-Based CO2 Energy Transition Goes Public With $69M IPO
metadata.indicator: Houston-based CO2 Energy Transition Corp. (Nasdaq: NOEM), a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), has completed its $69 million IPO by raising funds through the sale of 6 million units at $10 each, with an additional 900,000 units exercised under the underwriter’s over-allotment option. The SPAC aims to acquire or merge with mid-sized carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) companies valued between $150 million and $250 million, targeting the growing market for carbon reduction technologies. The offering includes warrants and contingent share rights, and the company highlights bipartisan support for CCUS legislation, positioning itself at the intersection of climate policy and emerging clean energy solutions.
metadata.categories: Carbon Capture, SPAC, Energy Transition, Sustainable Energy

metadata.title: Markets Removal BlueLayer To Provide dMRV & Project Data Infrastructure For Puro.earth
metadata.indicator: BlueLayer has partnered with Puro.earth to integrate its digital monitoring, reporting, and verification (dMRV) platform into Puro.earth’s carbon dioxide removal (CDR) credit infrastructure, enabling CDR suppliers to streamline and automate data collection, verification, and credit issuance across project lifecycles. The platform centralizes machine, sensor, and operational data, offering standardized, methodology-specific templates that enhance data accuracy and accelerate verification for buyers and investors. This collaboration aims to improve transparency, efficiency, and trust in the carbon market by providing a scalable, digital dMRV solution for CDR project developers.
metadata.categories: Carbon Markets, Digital Monitoring and Verification, Carbon Removal

metadata.title: Article 6 Markets Singapore Teams With Mongolia For 10th Bilateral Carbon Credit Deal
metadata.indicator: Singapore and Mongolia have signed a legally binding Article 6 carbon credit agreement, marking Singapore’s 10th such deal under the Paris Agreement’s framework, with the agreement enabling high-integrity carbon credit transfers for emission offsetting in both countries. The deal includes a 2% cancellation of initially issued credits to ensure they are not counted toward national targets, and a commitment to allocate 5% of credit value to climate adaptation efforts in Mongolia, supporting local development, job creation, and pollution reduction. The agreement expands Singapore’s International Carbon Credits (ICC) portfolio and strengthens bilateral cooperation in climate action, aligning with global efforts to build a transparent and verifiable carbon market under Article 6.4.
metadata.categories: Climate Policy, Carbon Credits, International Cooperation

metadata.title: Markets Carbon Market Watchdog ICVCM Sets Up First Physical Hub In Singapore
metadata.indicator: The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) has established its first physical office in Singapore, marking a significant step in enhancing oversight and credibility for Asia’s emerging carbon markets. The regional hub, co-developed with Singapore’s Economic Development Board, will focus on evaluating carbon credit methodologies aligned with regional priorities such as coal power retirement and peatland restoration, using its ten science-based Core Carbon Principles (CCPs) that emphasize environmental integrity and human rights, especially Indigenous rights. The office supports regional carbon market development by working with governments and domestic programs and strengthens alignment with Article 6 of the Paris Agreement and multilateral initiatives like the Coalition to Grow Carbon Markets.
metadata.categories: Carbon Market, Environmental Policy, Asia-Pacific

metadata.title: Markets Policy Pennsylvania Governor Wants To Create Independent Cap-and-trade Program
metadata.indicator: Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro has announced plans to withdraw the state from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) and establish an independent cap-and-trade program known as the Pennsylvania Climate Emissions Reduction Initiative (PACER). The new program would impose a carbon fee on energy industry emissions, with 70% of revenues redirected to electricity bill rebates and the remainder allocated to low-income support, energy efficiency, renewable energy, and carbon capture for existing natural gas plants. This move follows a 2023 working group recommendation and responds to a prior Commonwealth Court ruling that challenged RGGI’s constitutionality, with Shapiro’s office appealing the decision.
metadata.categories: Environmental Policy, Climate Change, Energy

metadata.title: Farming Removal Groundwork BioAg And Anew Climate To Commercialize 500,000 Tons Of Soil CDR Credits
metadata.indicator: Groundwork BioAg, a soil carbon removal company, has partnered with Anew Climate to commercialize 500,000 tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e) credits through its Rootella Carbon® program, which uses mycorrhizal fungi to sequester carbon in agricultural soils. The program, verified by SCS Global, reports an average of 3.89 tCO2e per acre over one year from 9,000 acres and offers farmers up to 70% of net credit sales, creating a new revenue stream tied to soil health and climate mitigation. The initiative aligns with Verra’s VM0042 methodology and aims to scale carbon removal across 270 million acres of reduced-tillage farmland in the U.S., Canada, and Brazil, enhancing farm resilience, water retention, and biodiversity.
metadata.categories: Climate Change, Soil Carbon Removal, Carbon Credits, Sustainable Agriculture

metadata.title: Farming Removal Key Carbon & InSoil Launch $114M Partnership To Accelerate Regenerative Agriculture In Europe
metadata.indicator: Key Carbon, a Vancouver-based climate-focused private equity firm, has launched a $114 million partnership with InSoil, a Lithuania-based regenerative agriculture technology company, to accelerate soil-based carbon removal across Europe. The funding supports InSoil’s zero-interest Green Loans to small and medium-sized farms, with an additional $4.2 million allocated to expand operations across 2.5 million acres by 2026, enabling the sequestration of over 35 million tons of CO2. The initiative leverages InSoil’s lab-grade soil sampling, remote sensing, and MRV (Measurement, Reporting, and Verification) platform to deliver transparent, science-backed carbon credits aligned with the EU Carbon Removals Certification Framework.
metadata.categories: Climate Finance, Regenerative Agriculture, Carbon Markets, Sustainable Farming
